questions.text: A 1 year and 1 month old child presented with developmental delay with her peripheral smear showing macrocytic anaemia. There is no B12 or folic acid deficiency. The compound given in the picture is excreted in the urine. Her peripheral smear is also given. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario is orotic aciduria.

Points in favour of orotic aciduria in the case above:

  • Developmental delay
  • Megaloblastic anemia, peripheral smear – hypersegmented neutrophils
  • Absence of B12 and folic acid deficiency
  • The compound given in the picture is Orotic acid which is excreted in urine.

Orotic aciduria: It is a rare autosomal recessive condition, involving error in the de novo synthesis of pyrimidines.

  • Type I: Deficiency of both orotate phosphoribosyl tranferase and OMP decarboxylase (together called UMPsynthase).
  • Type II: Deficiency of only orotidylate decarboxylase.

Confirmation of diagnosis requires assay of the transferase and decarboxylase enzymes in the patients erythrocytes. Anemia responds promptly to administration of uridine.

questions.text: In the following flowchart representing natural history of disease, The duration between point A to B is called as?
questions.solution:
The period between the first possible time of detection (point A) and the first critical point of diagnosis (point B) is called Screening time.

The period between the first possible time of detection (point A) and the usual time of diagnosis (point C) is called lead time.

Related Pearl: Lead Time in Screening

Lead time is the advantage gained by screening which is the period between diagnosis by early detection and diagnosis by other means.

questions.text: A 45-year-old hypertensive male presents for a regular checkup. He is not on any medications. His blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg. The presence of which of the following in him will help us diagnose metabolic syndrome, as per NCEP- ATP III?

choices.text: Triglycerides of 100 mg/dL and waist circumference of 105 cm
Waist circumference of 105 cm and fasting glucose of 110 mg/dL
Fasting glucose of 110 mg/dL and HDL cholesterol of 60 mg/dL
HDL Cholesterol of 60 mg/dL and triglycerides of 100 mg/dL

questions.solution:
In this patient with the blood pressure of 140/90 mm Hg, a waist circumference of 105 cm and fasting glucose of 110 mg/dL helps diagnose metabolic syndrome. 

Metabolic syndrome is present if three or more of the following five criteria are met, which is given by NCEP-ATP III (National Cholesterol Education Program and Adult Treatment Panel III). It includes:

  • Central obesity: waist circumference >102 cm (M), >88 cm (F)
  • Hypertriglyceridemia: triglyceride level ≥ 150 mg/dL
  • Low HDL cholesterol: <40 mg/dL and <50 mg/dL for men and women, respectively.
  • Hypertension: blood pressure ≥130 mmHg systolic or ≥ 85 mmHg diastolic.
  • Fasting plasma glucose level: ≥100 mg/dL or previously diagnosed type 2 diabetes.

questions.text: The image below shows finding seen on eliciting plantar reflex in a patient in the neurology ward. All of the following signs may be seen in this patient except:
questions.solution:
The image shows extensor plantar response (positive Babinski sign), suggestive of an upper motor neuron (UMN) lesion. Fasciculations are seen in lower motor neuron lesions (not UMN).

Babinski sign refers to dorsiflexion of the great toe and fanning of other toes when the lateral aspect of the sole of the foot is scratched. It is a sign of upper motor neuron lesion. In normal adults, the response is plantar flexion of the toes.

 

The image below shows a positive Babinski sign in an adult, which is abnormal and indicative of a UMN lesion. 

 

In infants whose corticospinal tracts are still underdeveloped, dorsiflexion of the great toe and fanning of other toes is a normal response to scratching of the sole of the foot.

The image below shows an extensor response in an infant, which is normal.

 

Other signs as seen in patients with UMN lesions are spasticity, hypertonia and hyperreflexia. 

Related Pearl: Features of Motor Neuron Lesions

Upper Motor Neuron Lesion

Lower Motor Neuron Lesion

Upper motor neuron typically refer to corticospinal tract neurons that innervate spinal motor neurons, but they can also include brainstem neurons that control spinal motor neurons

Lower motor neurons are those whose axons terminate on skeletal muscles

Little or no muscle wasting . UMN lesions result in weakness of relatively large group of muscles

Muscle atrophy → muscle weakness of an individual and specific muscle

Hypertonia

Hypotonia

Increased or exaggerated deep tendon reflexes (hyperreflexia)

Hyporeflexia or areflexia

Spasticity

Flaccidity

Positive Babinski sign (abnormal plantar extensor reflex)

Fasciculations

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes with complaints of warty lesions on the vulva. On examination, multiple warty growths on the vulva and around the anal canal are seen. This condition is most likely seen in?
questions.solution:
Multiple warty growths on the vulva and around the anal canal are suggestive of condyloma acuminata (genital warts).

The verrucous growths may appear discrete or coalesce to form large cauliflower-like growths (as shown in the image below). Human papillomaviruses are implicated in causing this condition.

Genital warts:

Genital warts/ venereal warts/ condyloma acuminata are verrucous growths that affect the skin of the labia majora, perineum, perianal region, and vulva. They are most commonly caused by infection with human papillomavirus (HPV) types 6 and 11. The growths may be discrete or coalesce to form cauliflower-like growth. The disease is sexually transmitted. The growth of the warts is favored by vaginal discharge, the use of oral contraceptives, and pregnancy.

HPV causes structural changes in the epithelial cells of the skin. These abnormal epithelial cells are called koilocytes, and their presence is characteristic of HPV infection. The koilocytes have large hyperchromatic nuclei and a perinuclear halo.

Diagnosis is made by colposcopic studies. The lesions on the vulva are stained by toluidine blue. The skin with abnormal nuclei retains the blue dye. These abnormal areas are then biopsied for histopathological examination.

Treatment: 

  • Local application of podophyllin 25% in alcohol or podophyllin 20% in tincture benzoin or podophyllin cream
  • 25% trichloroacetic acid plus 5% fluorouracil
  • Diathermy loop, laser ablation, cryotherapy for larger lesions
  • Surgical excision
  • Interferon ointment or local injection

 

Option B: Molluscum contagiosum presents as a crop of small domed vesicles with central umbilication. It is caused by the pox virus and it spreads by close sexual or nonsexual contact and by autoinoculation.

Option C: Chancroid appears as small papules that develop into painful ulcerating pustules. They are associated with unilateral inguinal lymphadenopathy. It is caused by H. ducreyi.

Option D: Herpes appears as multiple crops of vesicles and ulcers.

questions.text: A child in your unit is diagnosed with severe acute malnutrition (SAM). According  to the WHO criteria, SAM is defined best by:
questions.solution:
Severe acute malnutrition (SAM) is best defined as weight for height less than median minus -3SD

Severe acute malnutrition (SAM) in children of ages 6 to 59 months is defined by the WHO as any of the following:

  1. Weight-for-length (or height) below −3 SD of the WHO Child Growth Standards.
  2. Presence of bipedal oedema
  3. Mid-upper arm circumference <11.5 cm

Related Pearl: Indicators for Body fat

The indicators for body fat are:

  • Body weight:  +3SD (standard deviations) from the median weight for height as a cut-off point for obesity. For adults, some people calculate various other indicators such as:
    • Body mass index (Quetelet's index): Weight (kg) / Square of height in metres
    • Ponderal index : Weight(g) x 100/(Length in cm)3
    • Corpulence index:Actual weight /desirable weight.(Should not exceed 1.2)
  • Broaca's index = Height (cm) - 100 . 
  • Lorentz's formula 
    Ht (cm) - 100 - [ (Ht (cm) - 150) / 2 for women or 4 for men ]
  • Skinfold thickness: Four sites mid-triceps, biceps, subscapular and suprailiac regions. The sum of the measurements should be less than 40 mm in boys and 50 mm in girls.
  • Waist circumference and waist-hip ratio: At the mid point between the lower border of the rib cage and the iliac crest. There is an increased risk of metabolic complications for men with a waist circumference~ 102 cm, and women with a waist circumference~ 88 cm. A high WHR (> 1.0 in men and> 0.85 in women) indicates abdominal fat accumulation.
  • Total body water
  • Total body potassium
  • Body density

questions.text: Which of the following fractures is most prone to non-union?
questions.solution:
Among the given fractures, proximal scaphoid fractures are most prone to non-union. 

Since the nutrient artery enters the scaphoid near its distal end, proximal fractures are associated with avascular necrosis and non-union. The more proximal the fracture in the scaphoid, the higher the chances of avascular necrosis and non-union.

Certain bones have a relatively limited or watershed blood supply that can potentially get interrupted by fracture.  These include:

  •  Talar neck
  •  Waist of the scaphoid
  •  Proximal metaphyseal-diaphyseal junction of the fifth metatarsal
  •  Femoral neck

Fractures in these sites have a higher risk for non-union or development of osteonecrosis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with halitosis and regurgitation underwent a barium swallow scan showing a herniation due to weakness in an area. This area is present between?
questions.solution:
Killian's dehiscence is seen between the cricopharyngeus and thyropharyngeus muscles.

The inferior constrictor muscle is made up of 2 parts: The upper thyropharyngeus made of oblique fibres and the lower cricopharyngeus made of transverse fibres. Between the two muscles, there is a potential gap which is called as the pharyngeal dimple or Killian's dehiscence.

This is the site of weakness in the pharyngeal wall and therefore is the potential site for the development of the diverticula- Zenker's diverticula.

Another site of weakness in the pharyngeal wall is the Laimer's triangle, which is present between the cricopharyngeus and the circular muscle of the oesophagus.

Related Pearl: Zenker’s Diverticulum

Zenker's diverticulum occurs due to herniation of mucosa and submucosa through the Killian's triangle, which is a weak area between two parts of the inferior constrictor - (thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus) in the posterior pharyngeal wall. It is usually seen in elderly patients (>60 years).

Characteristics of Zenker's diverticulum:

  • Hypopharyngeal
  • False diverticula - doesn't have a muscle coat
  • Acquired 
  • Pulsion diverticulum 

Pathophysiology: Impaired relaxation and spasm of the cricopharyngeus muscle after swallowing can result in increased pressure within the distal pharynx, and cause the diverticulum.Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia
  • Regurgitation
  • Halitosis
  • Aspiration
  • Gurgling sound during swallowing

The investigation of choice is barium swallow (lateral X-ray).

It is treated with:

  • Cricopharyngeal myotomy
  • Surgical diverticulectomy
  • Marsupialization
  • Dohlman’s procedure

questions.text: You are an anesthetist who needs to administer general anesthesia to an obese patient with a history of rheumatoid arthritis. Anticipating a difficult airway, preoperatively you assess the airway using the Modified Mallampati classification and conclude that the patient falls under class III. How does her airway probably look?
questions.solution:
The patient’s airway looks like the image in Option 3, which is Mallampati Class III -  soft palate and base of the uvula is seen.

The Modified Mallampati classification is used to predict difficulty in tracheal intubation.

The patient has to be seated, head neutral, mouth open, tongue protruded, and no phonation. In this position, the visibility of the faucial pillars, uvula and soft palate is assessed and assigned a class from I-IV. 

The initial Mallampati classification included only class I-III. It was modified by Samsoon and Young to include class IV. 

In addition to class I-IV, a fifth class also exists called class 0. In this, the epiglottis can be seen on mouth opening and tongue protrusion. However, it is still not proven by studies whether the class 0 is a sign of easy intubation or not. 

Other options-

Option 1 - Mallampati class IV: Soft palate is not visible at all.

Option 2 - Mallampati class I: Soft palate, fauces, uvula, and pillars are seen.

Option 4 - Mallampati class II: Soft palate, fauces, and portion of uvula are visible.

 

Related Pearl: Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification

Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification is used to predict the ease of endotracheal intubation.

  • Class I: soft palate, fauces, entire uvula, pillars;
  • Class II: soft palate, fauces, the portion of uvula;
  • Class III: soft palate, the base of uvula;
  • Class IV: hard palate only.

Initially, the Mallampatti scoring system (1985) had only 3 classes. This was modified by Samsoon and Young to include class 4. Later class 0 was also added.

Related Pearl: Predictors of Difficult Airway

Risk factors:

  1. Obstructive sleep apnea
  2. History of snoring
  3. Obesity
  4. Facial and neck deformities from previous surgery
  5. Previous head and neck radiation
  6. Head and neck trauma
  7. Congenital abnormalities of the head and neck
  8. Rheumatoid arthritis
  9. Down syndrome
  10. Scleroderma
  11. Cervical spine disease or previous cervical spine surgery

Specific tests for assessment:

  1. Mallampati scores (III and IV)
  2. Thyromental distance less than 7 cm with head in maximum extension
  3. Sterno-mental distance <12.5 cm with head in maximum extension
  4. Increased neck circumference >17 inches in men or >16 inches in women
  5. Upper lip bite test: Inability to protrude the mandible or lower teeth in front of the upper teeth
  6. Cormack and Lehane (laryngoscopic view) - Grade III and IV

Although the presence of these risk factors may not be sensitive in detecting difficult intubation, the absence of these findings indicates ease with intubation.

questions.text: Which of the following is the predominant pathogen to infect renal transplant recipients in the period of around 1 to 4 months following the transplantation?
questions.solution:
The predominant pathogen to infect the renal transplant recipients in the period around 1 to 4 months following the transplantation is cytomegalovirus (CMV).

The most common CMV presentation in kidney transplant patients is fever (most common), leukopenia, hepatosplenomegaly, myalgia, and arthralgia. 

JC virus, BK virus, and Epstein-Barr virus also have the propensity to cause infections during this period, but in lesser frequencies than CMV.

Related Pearl: AIDS-defining opportunistic infections and neoplasms found in patients with HIV infection

Infections

  • Protozoal and Helminthic Infections
    • Cryptosporidiosis or Isosporiasis (cystoisosporiasis) - Chronic intestinal
    • Toxoplasmosis (pneumonia or CNS infection)
  • Fungal Infections
    • Candidiasis (esophageal, tracheal, or pulmonary)
    • Cryptococcosis (CNS infection)
    • Coccidioidomycosis (disseminated)
    • Pneumocystosis (pneumonia or disseminated infection)
    • Histoplasmosis (disseminated)
  • Bacterial Infections
    • Mycobacteriosis (“atypical,” e.g., Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare) disseminated or extrapulmonary
    • Mycobacterium tuberculosis (pulmonary or extrapulmonary)
    • Nocardiosis (pneumonia, meningitis, disseminated)
    • Salmonella infections, disseminated
  • Viral Infections
    • Cytomegalovirus (pulmonary, intestinal, retinitis, or CNS infections)
    • Herpes simplex virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Varicella-zoster virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy

Neoplasms

  • Kaposi sarcoma
  • Primary lymphoma of brain
  • Invasive cancer of uterine cervix 

 

One-liners about HIV

  • Sexual contact is the least efficacious yet most common mode of spread of HIV infection
  • ELISA is used for the detection of antibodies against viral proteins. This is the most sensitive and the best screening test for the diagnosis of AIDS.
  • Western blot is the most specific or the confirmatory test for HIV.
  • Candidiasis is the most common fungal infection in patients with AIDS.
  • Cytomegalovirus (CMV) chorioretinitis exclusively in patients with CD4+ T cell counts less than 50 per microliter.
  • Toxoplasma gondii causes encephalitis and is responsible for 50% of all mass lesions in the central nervous system.
  • John Cunningham virus (JC virus) is a human papovavirus that causes progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy.
  • Persistent diarrhea in AIDS is caused by Cryptosporidium, Isospora belli, or microsporidia.
  • AIDS-dementia complex is the most common neurological manifestation of HIV infection.
  • Inflammatory myopathy is the commonest skeletal muscle disorder in HIV.

questions.text: You are conducting a health and wellness survey of the employees of your hospital. Which of the following scales will you not use to classify their socio-economic statuses?
questions.solution:
Likert scale is not a scale used for socio-economic status (SES). It is a psychometric scale used to understand the attitude of people from their responses. It is a scale widely used in questionnaire-based research.

Scales that have been used for SES are:

  • Udai Pareek scale
  • Kuppuswamy scale
  • Radhukar scale
  • Jalota scale
  • Shirvastava scale
  • Bharadwaj scale
  • Kulshestra scale
  • Hollingshead scale.

Related Pearl: Socio-Economic Status and the modified Kuppuswamy’s Socio-economic Status Scale, 2017

Socio-Economic Status:

  • The socio-economic status (SES) is a person’s position in the societal hierarchy, which in turn is an important determinant of health.
  • SES may be inherited but in most situations, it is achieved on the basis of occupation, income, type of housing, neighbourhood, material possessions, etc.
  • Many composite scales have been developed to classify SES. Some of them are listed below:

Scale

Used for:

BG Prasad scale

Urban and rural areas

Kuppuswamy scale

Urban and peri-urban areas

Uday Pareek

Rural areas

Some other scales that have been used are Radhukar scale, Jalota scale, Shirvastava scale, Bharadwaj scale, Kulshestra scale and the Hollingshead scale.

 

The Kuppuswamy scale:

The Kuppuswamy scale was designed to classify the socio-economic status in urban and peri-urban areas.

It was devised in 1976 by Kuppuswamy and was later modified to be called the Modified Kuppuswamy Scale.

This scale uses the following components:

  • Education of head of the family
  • Occupation of the head of the family
  • Monthly income of the family

Each indicator is given a score and the final score from 3–29 reveals the Socio-Economic Score and class of the person.

The scale requires regular upgrades owing to the changing value of the currency and for this, the changes are based on the Consumer Price Index for industrial workers (CPI IW) with the year 2001 as the base year.

Modified Kuppuswamy scale(2019):

questions.text: The condition shown in the given image is due to elevated levels of a particular hormone secreted from a pituitary tumor. This hormone is also seen to be elevated in all of the following, except
questions.solution:
The condition shown in the given image is Cushing's disease caused by a pituitary adenoma secreting adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH). Levels of ACTH decrease at midnight, while asleep.

Cushing's syndrome is caused by hypersecretion of cortisol from the adrenal cortex. When Cushing’s syndrome is secondary to excessive secretion of ACTH by the anterior pituitary, it is referred to as Cushing’s disease.

Any type of physical or mental stress can increase the levels of ACTH to within minutes. This, in turn, elevates cortisol levels up to 20 times normal. Pain stimuli due to physical stress or tissue damage are transmitted to the median eminence of the hypothalamus which secretes corticotropin-releasing factor (CRF). Within minutes, this leads to large quantities of cortisol in the blood.

Mental stress may cause an equally rapid increase in ACTH secretion as a result of increased activity in the limbic system which transmits signals to the hypothalamus.

Prolonged lack of sleep can elevate ACTH levels.

The secretory rates of CRF, ACTH, and cortisol are high in the early morning but low in the late evening. This is a result of a 24-hour cyclical alteration in the signals from the hypothalamus. When a person changes daily sleeping habits, the cycle changes correspondingly.

Related Pearl: Initial Tests for Diagnosing Cushing's Syndrome

These include two steps:

1. Tests to detect hypercortisolism

  • Midnight salivary or serum cortisol (highly sensitive test): The presence of cortisol in the saliva or serum at midnight signifies loss of diurnal variation of cortisol
  • 24-hour urinary free cortisol excretion: Increased three times the normal value
  • Overnight dexamethasone suppression test (DST): Plasma cortisol >1.8 μg/dL at 8 a.m after overnight exposure to dexamethasone (1 mg given at 11 p.m)
  • Low dose DST (highly specific test): Plasma cortisol >1.8 μg/dL at 8 a.m. on the third day after giving 0.5 mg dexamethasone every 6 hours for 2 days

2. Test to rule out pseudo Cushing's syndrome

  • Low-dose DST + CRH stimulation test: Plasma cortisol levels are increased in true Cushing’s but remain unaffected in pseudo Cushing's. Dexa-induced negative feedback is overcome by CRH in true Cushing’s.

Related Pearl: Causes of Cushing's Syndrome

Iatrogenic (Most common cause)

  • Exogenous administration of glucocorticoids

Endogenous Causes

  • ACTH Dependent – (90 % of endogenous causes)
  • Cushing’s disease – ACTH-producing pituitary adenoma
  • Ectopic ACTH syndrome – Due to ACTH secretion by
  • Bronchial or pancreatic carcinoid tumors
  • Small-cell lung cancer
  • Medullary thyroid carcinoma
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • ACTH Independent – (10% )
  • Adrenocortical adenoma
  • Adrenocortical carcinoma

Rare causes

  • Macronodular adrenal hyperplasia
  • Primary pigmented nodular adrenal disease
  • McCune – Albright syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following is false about the mucocele of the gall bladder?
questions.solution:
The gall bladder is easily palpable in mucocele.

  • Mucocele is due to prolonged obstruction of the cystic duct usually by a large solitary calculus.
  • Obstructed GB lumen is progressively distended by mucus or by a clear transudate produced by mucous epithelial cells.
  • Clinical features:
    • A visible, easily palpable, non-tender gall bladder
    • Frequently remains asymptomatic.
  • Treatment: early cholecystectomy

questions.text: A capnograph obtained from an intubated patient undergoing controlled ventilation is given below. Which of the following is a likely cause of the finding seen?
questions.solution:
The curare notch in the plateau phase of the capnograph indicates that the patient is trying to breathe spontaneously. The patient's inspiratory effort causes some fresh gas to be sucked in the capnometer, resulting in a lower carbon dioxide concentration and a notch.

Image below shows a capnograph with clefts during phase III which indicates spontaneous breathing efforts by the patient during controlled mechanical ventilation. It is also known as a curare notch or cleft.

Related Pearl: Various capnography waveforms:

A- Obstructive airway or bronchospasm
B- Expiratory valve malfunctioning
C- Inspiratory valve malfunction
D- Normal physiological variant seen in pregnant subjects under GA
E- Curare cleft
F- Rebreathing
G- Esophageal intubation
H- Spontaneous breathing
I-Dual capnogram in one lung transplantation patient. The first peak in phase III is from the transplanted normal lung, whereas the second peak is from the native disease lung. A variation of dual capnogram (steeple sign capnogram – dotted line) is seen if there is a leak around the sidestream sensor port at the monitor
J- Malignant hyperthermia
K- Classic ripple effect during the expiratory pause showing cardiogenic oscillations
L- Sudden rise of baseline and end-tidal PCO2 (PETCO2) due to contamination of the sensor with secretions or water vapor.
The gradual rise of baseline and PETCO2 occurs when soda lime is exhausted. 
M -Intermittent mechanical ventilation (IMV) breaths in the midst of spontaneously breathing patient.
N -Cardiopulmonary resuscitation: capnogram showing positive waveforms during each compression. 
O-Capnogram showing rebreathing during inspiration. This is normal in rebreathing circuits such as Mapleson D or Bain circuit.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the given image?

choices.text: It is inserted by withdrawal technique
The copper in this device has a surface area of 380 square mm
It is used in emergency contraception
It has a life-span of 5 years

questions.solution:
The given image is CuT 380 A as it has copper in both the stem as well as the horizontal arms and it has the highest life span of 10 years.

Copper T-380A (Paragard):

It is named so for the 380 mm2 of copper surface area. A higher surface area of copper results in higher contraceptive efficacy. 

It has a plastic T-shaped core with copper placed around the vertical stem and horizontal arms. A silver core within the copper sheath is included to prevent fragmentation of the copper, extending the lifespan of the Copper T-380A.

The frame is connected to a monofilament thread that protrudes through the cervical canal into the upper vagina. This facilitates easy removal and allows the user to ensure that the IUD remains in the uterus.

If an IUCD is inserted within 7 days after coitus, it serves as an emergency contraceptive and is more effective than levonorgestrel/ulipristal acetate regimens.

Related Pearl: Hormonal contraceptives

Oral pills:

  • Combined oral contraceptive pills (COC)
    • Mala D - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate
    • Mala N - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg + Ethinyl estradiol  0.03 mg + Ferrous fumarate (Govt. supply, free of cost)
  • Progesterone only pills (POP) - suitable for lactating women
    • Norethisterone 350 μg
    • Norgestrel 75 μg
    • Levonorgestrel (LNG) 30 μg
  • Once a month or long-acting pills - highly disappointing results
    • Quinestrol (long-acting estrogen) + short-acting progesterone
  • Gossypol - male pill : Cottonseed derivative and causes azoospermia and severe oligospermia
  • Post-coital pills or interceptive
    • Levonorgestrel 0.75 mg, 2 doses, 12 hours apart
    • Mifepristone 10-600 mg
    • Ulipristal 30 mg, within 5 days of intercourse
    • Centchroman 60 mg, 2 tablets, within 24 hrs of intercourse
    • GnRH agonists  
    • CuT IUCD, inserted within 5 days

Injectable contraceptives

  • Progesterone only injectables
    • DMPA 150 mg IM every 3 months
    • NET-EN 200 mg IM every 2 months
  • Combined injectables
    • Cyclofem - DMPA 25 mg + Estradiol cypionate 5 mg
    • Mesigyna - NET-EN 50 mg  + Estradiol valerate 5 mg

Subdermal implants

  • Norplant I - Levonorgestrel 35 mg
  • Norplant II or Jadelle - 2 rods with levonorgestrel 70 mg in each and released at a rate of 50 μg/day  

Others

  • Hormonal IUCD - Mirena which contains LNG 52 mg with release rate of 20 μg/day
  • Orthoevra patch - Norelgestomin + Ethinyl estradiol weekly for 3 weeks, then patch free for 1 week
  • Vaginal ring or Nuvaring - Etonogestrel + ethinyl estradiol daily release, use for 3 weeks with withdrawal for 1 week

questions.text: A female patient on lithium tested positive for a urine pregnancy test. Lithium usage in pregnancy can lead to which of the following teratogenic effects?
questions.solution:
Lithium use in pregnancy can lead to cardiac defects. 

Ebstein's anomaly is the specific cardiac defect with lithium use in pregnancy.

In Ebstein’s anomaly, the radiological sign seen is a box-shaped heart.

Related Pearl: Teratogenic drugs and the birth defects

Drugs Adverse effects
Penicillamine Cutis laxa syndrome
Lithium Ebstein anomaly
Isotretinoin Facial-ear anomalies, heart disease, CNS anomalies
Progesterone Masculinization of the female fetus
Quinine Abortion, thrombocytopenia, deafness
Topiramate Cleft lip
Valproate Spina bifida, limb defects, autism spectrum disorder, facial and cardiac anomalies, Coarctation of the aorta, Aortic stenosis, Pulmonary atresia, Ventricular Septal Defect. 
Vitamin D Supravalvular aortic stenosis
Warfarin Fetal bleeding, hypoplastic nasal structures
Statins Vertebral, anal, cardiac, tracheoesophageal fistula, renal, arterial, limb (VACTERAL) defects
Phenytoin Ventricular septal defect, Atrial Septal Defect, Coarctation of the aorta, Patent Ductus Arteriosus
Alcohol Atrial Septal Defect, Ventricular Septal Defect

questions.text: The degree of prolapse shown in the image given below is _______
questions.solution: The image shows external os lying at the level of introitus. Hence it is second degree uterine prolapse.

questions.text: A surgeon while performing a laparotomy procedure uses the following instrument. Which of the following option is true about this instrument?

choices.text: Safer in procedures closer to vital structures

questions.solution:
The given instrument is Monopolar electrocautery. Both cutting and coagulation modes are possible with monopolar electrocautery.

  • Application of Low voltage, high amplitude, continuous waveforms is responsible for the cutting of tissues.
  • Application of High voltage current for a short duration(intermittent waveform) is responsible for the coagulating of tissues

A short circuit is established in bipolar electrocautery between the tips of the instrument. This makes the chances of burns lesser compared to monopolar electrocautery. Bipolar electrocautery has less lateral dissipation of current so it is safer in procedures closure to vital structures. Bipolar cautery can be seen in the image below.

Related Pearl: Diathermy/Cautery:

Features Monopolar Bipolar
Flow of current

Cautery pencil –> tissue –> cautery pad –> machine/ground

Hence more chance of burns

Only between tips of the instrument

Hence less chance of burns
Modes

Cutting – Low voltage, high amplitude, continuous waveforms

Coagulation – Alternate waveforms (Bursts)

Dessication – Low power

Fulguration – High power

 Only coagulation
Dissipation

More thermal dissipation of current

Hence can cause damage to nerves and other vital structures

Less lateral dissipation of current

Hence safer in procedures closer to vital structures

questions.text: A 45-year-old chronic alcoholic is brought to the hospital due to fever and abdominal pain. He was diagnosed to have a cirrhotic liver 2 years back. The ascitic fluid shows a neutrophil count of 360 cell/ microliter. Which of the following is the drug of choice in this patient?
questions.solution:
Cefotaxime is the drug of choice in this patient.

This patient’s clinical features are suggestive of spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP).

Spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) is an acute bacterial infection of the ascitic fluid. It is commonly seen in adults in association with liver cirrhosis. The pathogens involved are Escherichia coli, streptococci, enterococci, and pneumococci. 

In a patient with ascites, SBP presents with fever, and acute abdominal pain. On examination, tachycardia, tachypnea, and signs of peritonitis are seen. Hepatic encephalopathy and gastrointestinal bleeding may also occur. 

Diagnosis is by paracentesis, and an ascitic fluid neutrophil count of >250/mm3 is suggestive of spontaneous bacterial peritonitis. Ascitic fluid culture may reveal the pathogenic organisms.

Management is mainly by third-generation cephalosporins such as cefotaxime. Albumin infusion can be given as it decreases the risk of renal failure and improves patient survival. Early diagnosis and treatment improve the prognosis.

questions.text: Identify the fetal position in the given image.
questions.solution:
The given vertex presentation is right occipito anterior, where the vertex is occupying the right anterior quadrant of the pelvis.

Fetal position refers to the bony fixed point of reference on presenting part with respect to different quadrants of the pelvis.

questions.text: A 51-year-old man complains of abdominal pain and blood-stained stools. The barium study of his intestines shows the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the radiological images suggest intussusception.

In intussusception, the occluding mass prolapsing into the lumen has been termed the coiled spring appearance (barium in the lumen of the intussusceptum and in the intraluminal space). In adults, it develops due to a tumor of the bowel.

Causes of intussusception are:

Idiopathic - most common cause in children
Pathological lead points include enlarged submucosal Peyer's patch, lymphoma, intestinal polyp, leiomyomas, etc.
Meckel's diverticulum
A recent upper GI or respiratory infection, rotavirus vaccination has also shown some association with intussusception in children
In adults, it develops due to a tumor of the bowel.

The intussusception appears as a sausage-shaped mass in a longitudinal plane or a target mass in the transverse plane on CT and USG. 

Ultrasound signs include:

  • Target sign (also known as the doughnut sign)
  • Pseudokidney sign- this is seen in the longitudinal section of the bowel
    • the edematous bowel resembles renal parenchyma and
    • the mesentery which is dragged into the intussusception resembles renal hilum

Crescent in a doughnut sign.
The following ultrasound image shows the target sign seen in intussusception. 

Option B: Volvulus presents with constipation, abdominal bloating, nausea, and/or vomiting. It shows a coffee bean sign

Option C: Diverticulitis presents with pain in the left iliac fossa

Option D: Ulcerative colitis causes backwash ileitis.

questions.text: A surgical consultation is requested for a neonate currently in the neonatal intensive care. On examination, the following findings were found along with a bifid uvula. Which of the following is the most appropriate management in this child?

choices.text: Cleft soft palate repair at 9 to 12 months
Cleft lip and soft palate repair at 5 to 6 months
Cleft soft and hard palate repair at 12-15 months

questions.solution:
The most appropriate management for this patient would be cleft lip and soft palate repair at 5 to 6 months. As the neonate in question has a unilateral right-sided cleft lip along with cleft hard and soft palate, the appropriate management for this patient would be (two separate procedures):

  1. Cleft lip and soft palate repair at 5 to 6 months, followed by 
  2. Hard palate repair with or without a revision surgery for the lip and soft palate at 15 to 18 months.

The different types of facial clefts are shown below:

  1. Unilateral cleft lip with alveolar involvement
  2. Bilateral cleft lip with alveolar involvement
  3. Unilateral cleft lip associated with cleft palate
  4. Bilateral cleft lip and palate
  5. Cleft palate only

Clefts of the lip, alveolus, hard and soft palate are the common congenital anomalies of the orofacial structures.

questions.text: A patient presented with unilateral proptosis and bilateral abducent palsy. What is the most probable cause ?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cavernous sinus thrombosis.

Features of cavernous sinus thrombosis include early involvement lateral rectus palsy (abducent nerve involvement) since it runs through the cavernous sinus. Oculomotor and trochlear nerve palsy occur later as they are related to the lateral wall of the cavernous sinus. Other signs are proptosis, severe supraorbital pain, edema in the mastoid region, absence of corneal sensation, and dilated pupil.

Options A- Retinoblastoma occurs in young children and presents with unilateral proptosis with leukocoria, buphthalmos, and squint.

Option B- Orbital pseudotumor presents with unilateral proptosis with diplopia, conjunctival chemosis. The inflammation is responsive to systemic corticosteroids.

Option C- Orbital cellulitis presents with unilateral proptosis with pain and decreased ocular motility.

questions.text: Identify the following logo:
questions.solution:
Option A: Cytotoxic Waste

Option B: Biohazard

Option C: Radiation

questions.text: A child is starting to walk and gaining upright posture. Which of the following spinal curvatures develops secondarily due to the development of this function?
questions.solution:
Lumbar curvature develops secondarily when the child starts walking and gaining upright posture.

Both the primary curves (thoracic and pelvic) that appear during embryonic life are convex dorsally. After birth, functional muscle development results in the appearance of secondary cervical and lumbar spinal curvatures in the sagittal plane.

  • The secondary cervical curvature occurs with the development of function in the muscles responsible for the head extension.
  • The secondary lumbar curvature occurs with the development of function in the muscles responsible for sitting upright and walking.

questions.text: A young patient is brought to the psychiatrist by his wife. The patient accuses his wife of cheating on him despite the wife denying it. The patient constantly keeps checking his wife's phone and has hacked into her social media account on multiple occasions previously. The wife says that the patient has become very jealous and insecure. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario the patient is suffering from Othello syndrome. It is a rare psychiatric condition marked by morbid, pathological, or delusional jealousy. Eg: Suspecting a faithful partner of infidelity, with accompanying jealousy.

DELUSIONAL MISIDENTIFICATION SYNDROMES

Capgras syndrome: The delusion in Capgras syndrome is the belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an imposter.

Fregoli’s syndrome: Fregoli syndrome is a disorder in which a person holds a delusional belief that different people/strangers are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Syndrome of intermetamorphosis: A very rare delusion that familiar persons can change themselves into other persons at will.

Doppleganger syndrome: A person feels he has his own impostor(duplicate) – Delusion of subjective doubles.

This is a recent AIIMS question. Named delusions and themes of delusions are repeatedly being asked in AIIMS as well as NEET examination. A good understanding of this high yield topic will be helpful.

Related Pearl: Types of delusions

THE TYPES OF DELUSIONS

Delusion of control

False belief that a person’s will, thoughts, or feelings are being controlled by external forces.

Delusion of grandeur or Megalomania 

Exaggerated conception of one’s importance, power, or identity.

Delusion of infidelity or morbid jealousy or Othello syndrome

False belief that one’s lover is unfaithful. Sometimes called pathological jealousy.

Delusion of love or erotomania

False belief that another person is in love with them. In De Clerambault syndrome, the woman believes that a man, frequently older and of higher status, is in love with her.

Delusion of misidentification 

Capgras syndrome: Belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an exact double i.e. an impostor.

Fregoli syndrome: Person holds a delusional belief that different people are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Nihilistic delusion 

False belief that oneself, others or the world, is non-existent or about to end. When nihilistic delusion is accompanied by ideas concerning bodily function failure e.g. putrefaction of intestine etc, it is called Cotard syndrome.

Delusion of infestation 

False belief that one is infested with small but visible organisms. As a monosymptomatic delusional disorder, this is called Ekbom syndrome. 

Delusion of persecution

The most common delusion. False belief of being harassed or persecuted.

Delusion of poverty

The person strongly believes they are financially incapacitated.

Delusion of reference

False belief that the behavior of others has a particular and unusual significance, usually of a negative nature. The person may falsely feel that others are talking about them (e.g. the people on television are talking to or about the person).  

Delusion of self-accusation

False feeling of remorse and guilt. Seen in depression with psychotic features.

questions.text: A 29 year old female suffering from moderate depression and suicidal tendency slashed her wrist with a kitchen knife in an attempt to end her life. She was immediately taken to ER by her family and on examination, there was a deep laceration over the radial side of her left wrist. Which of the following structure is most likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
Median nerve is more likey to be injured in case of deep laceration of radial side of the wrist.

Wrist slash injuries:

A deep laceration on the radial side of the wrist may injure the radial artery, median nerve, flexor carpi radialis tendon, and palmaris longus tendon.

A deep laceration on the ulnar side of the wrist may injure the ulnar artery, ulnar nerve, and flexor carpi ulnaris tendon.

Brachial Plexus

  • C5 to T1
  • Roots (from spinal cord) > Trunks (in the neck)> Divisions (passing behind clavicle) > Cords and Branches (in the axilla).
  • Covered by prevertebral fascia extension called "axillary sheath"

  • Upper trunk: C5 and C6
  • Middle trunk: C7.
  • Lower trunk: C8 and T1

Divisions:

  • Anterior divisions - Forms lateral and medial cords supplying mainly flexors 
  • Posterior divisions - Forms posterior cord which suppy mainly extensors 

Cords:

  • Lateral cord: Formed by anterior divisions of the upper and middle trunks.
  • Posterior cord: Formed by all 3 posterior divisions 
  • Medial cord: Formed by anterior division of the lower trunk.

questions.text: A 35-year-old primigravida who conceived after in-vitro fertilization therapy came for an antenatal checkup at 38 weeks of gestation. Her obstetric history revealed that she was pregnant with DCDA twins. On examination, the first twin was found to be in a breech position and the maternal blood pressure was found to be greater than 140/90 mm Hg on two occasions with grade 1+ proteinuria. What should be done next?

choices.text: Monitor BP and terminate pregnancy if BP rises
Terminate pregnancy at 40 weeks of gestation

questions.solution:
Immediate caesarean section is done as the first twin is in breech presentation. Uncomplicated dichorionic diamniotic twin pregnancies are terminated at 38 weeks of gestation.

Timing of delivery depends on the type of twin pregnancy:

Type of twin pregnancy Timing of delivery
Dichorionic diamniotic 38 weeks
Monochorionic diamniotic 34 - 37 weeks + 6 days
Monochorionic monoamniotic 32 - 34 weeks by Caesarean section

 Mode of delivery depends on the 1st twin:

1st twin presentation Mode of delivery
Vertex Vaginal
Breech Caesarean section
Transverse Caesarean section

After delivery of 1st twin, if the 2nd twin is in breech, assisted breech delivery is done. If the 2nd twin is in transverse lie, internal podalic version is done under GA in the OT followed by breech extraction.

Complications in attempting vaginal delivery in non-vertex presentation (i.e) transverse and breech:

  • Interlocking of twins
  • Fetal head trapping above the cervix
  • Umbilical cord prolapse

According to ACOG criteria (2019), preeclampsia requires proteinuria of grade 2+ or more. In a case of pre-eclampsia, termination of pregnancy must be done at 37 weeks.

According to the updated criteria, this patient does not have pre-eclampsia. Hence, Caesarean section can be done at 38 weeks as for any uncomplicated DCDA twin pregnancy.

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones (indicated by the arrow in the image below) giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: In which of the following tissues does gluconeogenesis take place?
questions.solution:
Liver and kidney are the two major locations where gluconeogenesis takes place.

During short periods of fasting, most of gluconeogenesis takes place in the liver, while the remaining takes place in the kidneys. However, during periods of prolonged fasting, the kidneys become a major site of gluconeogenesis.

Gluconeogenesis:

  • Gluconeogenesis is the process of synthesizing glucose or glycogen from non-carbohydrate precursors.
  • Gluconeogenesis occurs in cytosol and mitochondria of the liver and kidney.
  • Significant substrates are glucogenic amino acids, lactate, glycerol, and propionate.
  • Lactate generated in various tissues is transported to the liver and is converted to back to pyruvate and enters gluconeogenesis. This pathway is referred to as Cori’s cycle.
  • Glucose-alanine cycle is referred to as Cahill cycle.
  • Muscle cannot participate in gluconeogenesis since it lacks glucose-6-phosphatase.

Related Pearl: Irreversible enzymes in gluconeogenesis pathway

The enzymes can be remembered using the mnemonic Pathway Produces Fresh Glucose.

Enzymes Reaction and site Cofactors
Pyruvate carboxylase

Pyruvate → Oxaloacetate

mitochondria

Biotin, ATP

Activated by acetyl-CoA
Phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase Oxaloacetate → PhosphoenolPyruvate (cytosol) GTP
Fructose-1,6-bisphosphatase Fructose-1,6-bisphosphate → fructose-6-phosphate (cytosol)

Citrate(+ve)

Fructose 2,6 bisphosphate (-ve)
Glucose-6-phosphatase Glucose-6-phosphate → glucose Endoplasmic reticulum

Laryngeal carcinoma is an indication for high tracheostomy.

Laryngo-tracheal stenosis, Juvenile onset respiratory papillomatosis, Crush injury to larynx.

Related Pearl: Types of Tracheostomy

High tracheostomy

  • Done through the 1st tracheal ring
  • An opening is made above the isthmus of the thyroid gland 
  • Done in case of malignancy of the larynx
  • Increased risk of perichondritis and subglottic stenosis

Mid tracheostomy

questions.text: The following instrument is used for:
questions.solution:
The above image shows a myringotome and myringotomy/tympanostomy is done by a sharp myringotome. 

Acute necrotizing otitis media is treated by antibiotics and cortical mastoidectomy if antibiotic therapy fails.

Myringotome is a surgical knife used for paracentesis of the eardrum. 

Indications of myringotomy:
  • Acute suppurative otitis media and its complications
  • Recurrent acute otitis media
  • Serous otitis media.
  • Aero-otitis media (to drain fluid and “unlock” the eustachian tube)
  • Atelectatic ear (treated along with grommet insertion)

Contraindication of myringotomy: It is contraindicated in suspected cases of intratympanic glomus tumor, as it can cause profuse bleeding in such patients.

 

Related Pearl: Myringotomy

Indications:
  • Acute suppurative otitis media:
    • Severe earache with the bulging tympanic membrane.
    • Incomplete resolution with opaque drum and persistent conductive deafness.
    • Complications of acute otitis media,e.g.facialparalysis, labyrinthitis or meningitis with the bulging tympanic membrane.
  • Serous otitis media.
  • Aero-otitis media (to drain fluid and “unlock” the eustachian tube).
  • Atelectatic ear (grommet is often inserted for long-term aeration).

Contraindication: Suspected intratympanic glomus tumor.

Incisions: 

  • In acute suppurative otitis media, a circumferential incision is made in the posteroinferior quadrant of the tympanic membrane, midway between the handle of malleus and tympanic annulus, avoiding injury to the incudostapedial joint.
  • In serous otitis media, a small radial incision is given in the posteroinferior or anteroinferior quadrant and all the effusion is sucked out.

Complications:

  • Injury to incudostapedial joint or stapes.
  • Injury to jugular bulb with profuse bleeding, if jugular bulb is high and floor of the middle ear dehiscent.
  • Middle ear infection.

questions.text: The given phenomenon is not shown by _____
questions.solution:
The given image depicts the Iceberg phenomenon of disease. It is not shown by Measles.

Diseases like tuberculosis, diabetes, malnutrition, anemia, hypertension, mental illnesses show the iceberg phenomenon of disease.

The iceberg phenomenon of diseases is not shown by diseases such as tetanus, rabies, and measles.

Iceberg phenomenon is shown by:

  • Polio
  • Influenza
  • Rubella
  • Mumps
  • Japanese Encephalitis
  • Diphtheria
  • Hepatitis A and B

Note: Rubella shows a large number of subclinical infections. Thus, it is considered to show the iceberg phenomenon.

questions.text: Macula densa is formed by which part of the nephron?
questions.solution:
Macula densa is formed by specialized tubular epithelial cells of the distal convoluted tubule.

The juxtaglomerular apparatus consists of the following parts:

  • Macula densa: At the end of the thick ascending limb of Henle, and at the beginning of the distal tubule, the tubular epithelial cells are specialized to form the macula densa 
  • Lacis cells: Extraglomerular mesangial cells situated between afferent and efferent arteriole.
  • Granular cells/JG cells: Modified smooth muscle cells of the afferent arteriole, they secrete renin. Fall in pressure in afferent arteriole stimulates renin release (mechanoreceptor), which, in turn, increases blood pressure.

questions.text: Identify the instrument given in the image below:
questions.solution:
The image given is of a Morris retractor, which is a large retractor useful for providing maximum exposure in large incisions e.g., abdominal incisions.

It can be used to improve visibility on one side of an incision. Thus, it is valuable during the initial phase of a laparotomy.

questions.text: Which of the following is not part of the pupillary light reflex pathway?
questions.solution:
The lateral geniculate body is not a part of the pupillary reflex pathway. It is part of the accommodation reflex and the visual pathway.

Pupillary light reflex pathway:

  • First-order neurons (sensory) connect each retina with both pretectal nuclei in the midbrain at the level of the superior colliculi. The sensory fibers are carried through the optic nerve. 
  • Second-order neurons (internuncial) connect each pretectal nucleus to bilateral Edinger–Westphal nuclei.
  • Third-order neurons (preganglionic motor) connect the Edinger–Westphal nucleus to the ciliary ganglion. These parasympathetic fibers pass via the oculomotor nerve. 
  • Fourth-order neurons (postganglionic motor) leave the ciliary ganglion and pass into the short ciliary nerves to innervate the sphincter pupillae in both the eyes. 

When light is shone in one eye, the pupils of both eyes constrict. 

  • Constriction of the pupil of the same eye is called direct reflex.
  • Constriction of the contralateral pupil is called consensual reflex/indirect reflex.  

Image: Pupillary reflex pathways

questions.text: A patient with a complex psychiatric history is on a mono-amine oxidase (MAO) inhibitor. She visits her primary care physician with increasing depression. The physician adds a serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI). Which of the following is she most likely to develop?

choices.text: Fever, rigidity, dilated pupils, and hyperreflexia
Fever, hyporeflexia, rigidity and normal pupils
Fever, normotonia, dilated pupils and normal reflexes
Fever, rigidity, normal pupils and reduced bowel sounds

questions.solution:
This patient, who is on a MAO inhibitor + an SSRI, can develop serotonin syndrome, characterised by fever, rigidity, hyperreflexia and dilated pupils.

Serotonin syndrome is characterized by a triad of:

  • Autonomic instability - hyperthermia, hypertension, tachycardia, diaphoresis, vomiting, diarrhea.
  • Altered mental status - agitation, confusion, delirium.
  • Neuromuscular hyperactivity - tremor, hyperreflexia, myoclonus.

Serotonin syndrome rarely occurs with a single serotonergic drug used at therapeutic doses. More commonly, it occurs due to the combined side effects with any drug that increases serum serotonin levels like MAOIs (monoamine oxidase inhibitors), SSRIs (selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors), SNRIs (serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors), TCAs (tricyclic antidepressants), tramadol, ondansetron, triptans, linezolid, MDMA (amphetamine), dextromethorphan, etc.

It is treated with cyproheptadine (5-HT2 receptor antagonist). 

Other Options:

Option B: This is seen in neuroleptic malignant syndrome, which occurs due to certain antipsychotics.

Option C: This is seen in anticholinergic toxicity.

Option D: This is seen in malignant hyperthermia.

Related Pearl: Psychiatric emergency: Fever with altered mental status

In a clinical setting of fever with altered mental status, it is important to differentiate between the following.

 Syndrome
Neuroleptic malignant syndrome
Serotonin syndrome
Anticholinergic syndrome
Malignant hyperthermia
 Cause
Dysregulation of dopaminergic pathways
Co-prescription of MAO-I and SSRIs leading to increased serotonin and norepinephrine levels
Anticholinergic intoxication
Halogenated anesthetics and succinylcholine leading to a
hypermetabolic response causing an increased intracellular calcium level
Fever and altered mental status
Present
Present
Present
Present
Muscle tone
Rigid
Rigid
Normal
Rigid
Skin and mucosa
Wet
Wet
Dry
Wet
Pupils
Normal
Dilated
Dilated
Normal
Bowel sounds
Normal
Increased
Decreased
Decreased
Reflexes
Bradyreflexia
Increased
Normal
Decreased
Treatment
Stop antipsychotic;
give dantrolene, bromocriptine and monitor CPK levels
Change the drug; 
give cyproheptadine
Discontinue drug;
give i.v. physostigmine
Cooling, dantrolene, insulin, and glucose

questions.text: Which of the following amino acid is used for the conversion of norepinephrine to epinephrine?
questions.solution:
Methionine in the form of S-adenosyl methionine is used during the conversion of norepinephrine to epinephrine.

The function of S-Adenosyl methionine:

1. Transmethylation reactions:

  • Norepinephrine to Epinephrine
  • Ethanolamine to Choline
  • Acetyl serotonin to Melatonin
  • Guanidinoacetate to Creatine

2.  DNA methylation

3.  Polyamine synthesis:

  • Cadaverine
  • Putrescine
  • Spermidine
  • Spermine

Related Pearl: Metabolism of phenylalanine and tyrosine

questions.text: Which of the following is not derived from surface ectoderm?
questions.solution:
Iris epithelium is not derived from surface ectoderm. It is derived from neural ectoderm.

Lens, corneal epithelium, and conjunctival epithelium are all derivatives of surface ectoderm.

Related Pearl: Embryological derivatives of the eye

Neural Ectoderm

questions.text: A 5-year-old female child with polyneuropathy, sensorineural deafness, and cerebellar ataxia has the following finding on fundus examination. Lab reveals increased blood levels of phytanic acid. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows fundoscopy findings of retinitis pigmentosa. This along with the given clinical scenario is suggestive of Refsum’s disease. It is a neurologic disorder that results from the defect in alpha oxidation of fatty acids such as phytanic acid in the peroxisome leading to elevated levels of phytanic acid in the blood.  

Option B- Usher syndrome is characterized by sensorineural deafness and retinitis pigmentosa (but symptoms are not affected by restricting phytanic acid)

Option C- Zellweger Syndrome is also known as cerebrohepatorenal syndrome. It is caused by mutations in the PEX family of genes also called peroxins involved in peroxisome biogenesis /peroxisomal enzymes themselves. Biochemical findings include accumulation of very-long-chain fatty acids, abnormalities of the synthesis of bile acids, marked reduction of plasmalogens. 

Option D- Adrenoleukodystrophy is an X-linked recessive disorder of β-oxidation of fatty acids. There is a very large chain fatty acids buildup in the adrenal glands, the white matter of the brain, and testes. It is a progressive disease that can lead to adrenal gland crisis, coma, and death.

questions.text: A patient with chronic constipation undergoes anorectal manometry. Considering the normal physiological defecation reflex, the first urge to defecate occurs when rectal pressure is increased to:
questions.solution:
The first urge to defecate occurs when rectal pressure is increased to 18 mm Hg.

When this pressure reaches 55 mm Hg, the external and the internal sphinc­ter relax, and there is reflex expulsion of the contents of the rectum.

Defecation reflex: Distension of the rectum and colon stimulates stretch receptors in the rectal wall. Then, the defecation reflexes travel from the colon and rectum to the spinal cord and back again to produce the powerful colonic, rectal, and abdominal contractions required for defecation.

questions.text: A young mother presented with dribbling of urine on coughing or sneezing. Marshall and Bonney's test was positive. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of stress incontinence. In this case, the first line of treatment is conservative management.

Stress incontinence is managed as follows:

Conservative management:

  • It is the first line of treatment.
  • It includes:
    • Kegel pelvic floor exercises for 4–6 months
    • Electric/magnetic stimulation for nerve damage, magnetic stimulation
    • Artificial urinary sphincter in neurological condition
    • Vaginal cones
  • It is also done in case surgery fails. 

Medical management:

  • Estrogen cream in menopausal woman
  • Venlafaxine 75 mg daily
  • Imipramine 10–20 mg BD

Surgical management:

  • Kelly's repair - vaginal approach
  • Marshall–Marchetti–Krantz operation - abdominal approach. It not done anymore as it causes osteitis of the pubis.
  • Burch colposuspension
  • Combined vaginal and abdominal suspension - Pereyra operation
  • Slings
    • Tension-free vaginal taping
    • Transobturator taping
  • Laparoscopic suspension of the bladder neck
  • Periurethral collagen injection

questions.text: You are a resident assisting in vaginal delivery. The pregnancy was uncomplicated.  The mother gives birth to a male newborn at term, who does not cry at birth, despite stimulation. The heart rate is 98 beats/minute. Respiration is not noted. What should your next step be?
questions.solution:
A term neonate who remains apnoeic despite stimulation should be given positive pressure ventilation by a bag and mask. 
 
The response to neonatal resuscitation at various steps is assessed based on the heart rate.
  • If the heart rate is less than 100, PPV is provided with bag and mask and SPO2 monitoring is done and adequate ventilation is ensured.
  • If the heart rate is below 60, then chest compressions are initiated over the lower third of the sternum at a rate of 90 compressions/min. The ratio of compressions to ventilation is 3: 1.
  • If the heart rate still remains <60, despite effective compressions and ventilation, then IV epinephrine is given.

questions.text: Flask shaped ulcers in the colon are caused by:
questions.solution:
Flask shaped ulcers are classically seen in amoebiasis caused by Entamoeba histolytica.

In amoebiasis, amoeba attach themselves to the colonic epithelium, induces apoptosis, invade crypts, and burrow laterally into the lamina propria. This recruits neutrophils and causes tissue damage, resulting in flask-shaped ulcers with a narrow neck and broad base.

Clinical manifestations:

  • Amebic Colitis
    • Colicky abdominal pains and frequent bowel movements.
    • Diarrhea associated with tenesmus and heme-positive stool.
    • Trophozoites invade the intestinal mucosa, produce flask-shaped ulcers.
  • Amebic Liver Abscess
    • Fever is the hallmark of amebic liver abscess
    • It is associated with abdominal pain, abdominal distention, and enlargement and tenderness of the liver.
    • Changes at the base of the right lung, such as elevation of the diaphragm and atelectasis or effusion, may also occur.
    • The most common finding is a single abscess in the right hepatic lobe, detected on ultrasonography,computed tomography, or magnetic resonance imaging.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with a condition which is treated using the Dohlman’s  procedure. What condition does the patient most likely have?
questions.solution:
Dohlman’s procedure is done for Zenker’s diverticulum.

It is a transoral endoscopic approach, that ablates the septum between the diverticulum and the cervical esophagus. It can be used for diverticula between 2 and 5 cm in size.

Zenker’s Diverticulum

  • Hypopharyngeal diverticulum
  • False diverticulum
  • Pulsion diverticulum
  • Acquired diverticulum, seen in the elderly (>60 years)
  • Herniation is through the Killian’s triangle (a weak area between two parts of the inferior constrictor) in the posterior pharyngeal wall
  • Clinical features:
    • Dysphagia
    • Regurgitation
    • Halitosis
    • Aspiration
    • Gurgling sound during swallowing
  • Investigation of choice: Barium swallow (Lateral X rays)
  • Treatment
    • Cricopharyngeal myotomy
    • Surgical diverticulectomy
    • Marsupialization
    • Dohlman’s procedure

questions.text: Identify the condition given in the image below.
questions.solution:
The given image depicts a submucous type of uterine fibromyoma.

Uterine myomas are broadly classified into 3 types.

  • Intramural - remains within the myometrial wall.
  • Submucous - present inside the uterine cavity and covered only by a thin endometrium.
  • Subserous - present towards the peritoneal surface.

Treatment includes:

  • Hormones to shrink the fibroid
  • Uterine artery embolization.
  • Myomectomy.
  • Total/subtotal hysterectomy.

Related Pearl: Secondary changes and complications in fibromyomas

  • Hyaline change, cystic degeneration and atrophy

  • Calcareous degeneration, osseous degeneration

  • Red degeneration

  • Sarcomatous change

  • Torsion, hemorrhage

  • Infection/ ulceration, particularly in the dependent part of a submucous polyp

  • Inversion of the uterus

  • Endometrial carcinoma associated with fibromyoma

  • Endometrial and myohyperplasia

  • Accompanying adenomyosis

  • Parasitic fibroid

questions.text: A  patient with gout develops hypertension.  The uric acid level was found to be elevated. Which of the following is not administered?
questions.solution:
Hydrochlorothiazides are not given to this patient.

Gout is a metabolic disease associated with hyperuricemia. Hydrochlorothiazides inhibit renal Ca2+ excretion causing hypercalcemia and may precipitate gout. Hence, hydrochlorothiazides are not used to treat hypertension in gout patients. 

Adverse effects of thiazide diuretics like hydrochlorothiazide:
  • Hypokalemia
  • Hyponatremia
  • Hyperglycemia
  • Hyperuricemia
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Rashes
  • Headache
  • Gastrointestinal upset
  • Dizziness
  • Erectile dysfunction

Other options:

Option B: Atenolol is a beta-1 selective antagonist. Bradycardia, fatigue, and cold extremities are common adverse effects. It is used in combination with a diuretic, in elderly patients with isolated systolic hypertension. CNS side effects like depression and nightmares are seen. It does not precipitate gout.

Option C: Enalapril is an ACE inhibitor and its side effects include hypotension, hyperkalemia, dry cough, rashes, urticaria, dysgeusia, gastrointestinal upset, headache, and dizziness. It does not precipitate gout.

Option D: Prazosin is a selective α1 antagonist. It is generally not used as an initial agent to treat hypertension, except in symptomatic prostatism or nightmares linked to posttraumatic stress disorder. Headache is one of the side effects of prazosin.

Related Pearl: Drugs precipitating Gout

Drugs that precipitate gout are-

Cyclosporine or cancer drugs
Aspirin (low dose)
Niacin
Thiazide
Lasix (furosemide)
Ethambutol
Alcohol
Pyrazinamide

Mnemonic for drugs precipitating gout is 'CANT LEAP'

questions.text: What should be the minimum interval between the administration of two live vaccines?
questions.solution:
The minimum interval between the administration of two live vaccines is 4 weeks.

This is because decreasing the interval between two doses may interfere with the antibody response and protection. Thus, live vaccines can either be given on the same day according to the schedule or 4 weeks apart.

Note: In Park 25th ed. the minimum interval between two live vaccines is given as 3 weeks. However, several other standard sources including CDC and UNDP suggested an interval of 4 weeks. When both are given in options, it is recommended to mark 4 weeks as the correct answer.

questions.text: A young adult presents with intermittent non-foul smelling mucoid discharge from the left ear for the past few years. Otologic examination revealed a central perforation of the tympanic membrane. Which of the following statements is false regarding his condition?

choices.text: No evidence of bone destruction in CT scans
Mixed aerobic and anaerobic infections are seen
Aural polyp if present, should never be avulsed

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of intermittent mucoid discharge and central perforation of the tympanic membrane points to a diagnosis of tubotympanic type of CSOM, which is not associated with cholesteatoma. Atticoantral type is associated with cholesteatoma and it leads to dangerous complications due to its bone-eroding properties. 

Etiology of tubotympanic (benign or safe) type of CSOM:

  • As a sequela of acute otitis media
  • Ascending infection via the eustachian tube
  • Allergic conditions

Bone destruction is not present in this type.

Culture reveals mixed aerobic and anaerobic infection.

Aural polyp if present should be removed and not avulsed before starting local treatment. This is due to the fact that the polyp may be arising from the stapes, facial nerve, or horizontal canal and its avulsion can lead to facial paralysis or labyrinthitis.

Related Pearl: Classification of CSOM

  TUBO-TYMPANIC ATTICO-ANTRAL
Old name Safe type Unsafe ear
Recent name Mucosal variant Squamosal disease
Discharge

Profuse

Mucoid

Non-foul smelling

Non-blood stained

Scanty

Foul-smelling

May be blood stained
Site Mostly in the pro-tympanum, i.e., part of Middle ear around the Eustachian tube orifice Mostly involves the epi-tympanum/ attic and involves the mastoid antrum via the aditus
Perforation Central (most common: Antero-inferior quadrant)

Attic (Pars flaccida)

OR

Marginal (most common: Postero-superior)

Polyp Pale, rare Fleshy red, common
Cholesteatoma Absent Present
Complications Rare Common
Treatment Medical/ surgical (Tympanoplasty) Always surgical (Mastoidectomy)

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presented with difficulty in activities like climbing stairs, getting up from a chair, and combing hair. She is a known case of ovarian cancer. The following finding was noted on examination. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows upper eyelid lilac erythema or heliotrope rash. The given clinical presentation of proximal myopathy with the characteristic heliotrope rash and history of an internal malignancy point towards a diagnosis of dermatomyositis.

Classic cutaneous signs in dermatomyositis:

  • Heliotrope rash/ eyelid erythema- violaceous erythema of the upper eyelids. Pathognomonic of dermatomyositis.
  • V sign- confluent macular erythema over the lower anterior neck and upper anterior chest
  • Shawl sign- confluent macular erythema over the upper back and lateral aspect of arms
  • Gottron’s papules- erythematous papules and plaques over the extensor surface of the metacarpophalangeal and interphalangeal joints. Pathognomonic of dermatomyositis.
  • Gottron's sign- erythematous rash over the extensor surfaces of joints such as the knuckles, elbows, knees, and ankles
  • Mechanic’s hands- rough, hyperkeratotic lines on the lateral and palmer areas of the fingers
  • Scalp erythema and hair loss
  • Facial rash- confluent erythema in the malar distribution involving the cheeks, nasal bridge, and nasolabial folds
  • Nail fold changes
  • Flagellate erythema- linear erythema on the upper back with pruritus
  • Poikiloderma- mottled pattern of hyperpigmented and hypopigmented macules with telangiectasias
  • Cutaneous calcinosis- accumulation of calcium deposits in the skin

Facial rash in dermatomyositis-

Eyelid erythema/ heliotrope rash in dermatomyositis-

V- sign in dermatomyositis-

Shawl sign in dermatomyositis-

Flagellate erythema in dermatomyositis-

Gottron papules in dermatomyositis-

Poikilodermatous changes in dermatomyositis-

questions.text: A 20 yr old man presents with fever and malaise for 4 days and a rash for the past 2 days. It was initially on his back, but then it appeared on his arms and legs too. On examination, he has a pleomorphic rash with areas of papules, vesicles, and a few crusts. Until when should the patient be isolated?

choices.text: Until he finishes a course of acyclovir

questions.solution:
This patient most likely has chickenpox and needs to isolate himself until all the lesions are crusted, which takes approximately 6 days from onset of rash. Only symptomatic treatment is needed in this case. Acyclovir is recommended only if administered within 24 hours.

The period of infectivity is from ~48 h before the onset of the vesicular rash, during the period of vesicle formation that generally lasts 4–5 days, and until all vesicles are crusted.

Related Pearl: Periods of Isolation for Selected Diseases

Disease

 

Duration of Isolation

Chickenpox

 

Until all lesions are crusted – 6 days usually.

Measles

 

From onset of catarrhal stage to 7 days of rash.

Cholera, diphtheria

 

3 days after tetracycline start until 48 hours.

Shigellosis and salmonellosis

 

Until 3 consecutive negative stool cultures.

Hepatitis A

 

3 weeks.

Influenza

 

3 days after onset.

Polio

 

2 weeks in adult; 6 weeks in children.

Tuberculosis (sputum +)

 

Until 3 weeks of effective chemotherapy.

Herpes zoster

 

6 days after onset of rash.

Mumps

 

Until swelling subsides.

Pertussis

 

4 weeks or until paroxysms cease.

Meningococcal meningitis

 

Until first 24 hours of effective antibiotic therapy are completed

Streptococcal pharyngitis

 

Until first 6 hours of effective antibiotic therapy are completed

questions.text: Sympathetic ophthalmia is seen after ____________.
questions.solution:
Sympathetic ophthalmia is a bilateral granulomatous panuveitis seen after a penetrating trauma

Less frequently, the condition occurs following intraocular surgery, usually multiple vitreoretinal procedures.

Presentation in trauma-induced cases is between 2 weeks and 3 months after initial injury in 65%.

The earliest symptom is blurred near vision in the sympathizing eye. The earliest sign is a retrolental flare in the sympathizing eye. Anterior uveitis develops in both eyes. The fundus shows multifocal choroidal infiltrates develop in the mid-periphery, with sub-retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) infiltrates corresponding to Dalen–Fuchs nodules (a granuloma situated between Bruch membrane and the RPE).

Treatment

  • Steroids are the basis of treatment. High-dose oral prednisolone is given for several months.
  • Immunosuppressives such as azathioprine, cyclosporine, and methotrexate can be used in resistant cases or as steroid-sparing agents.
  • Enucleation of a severely injured eye with no visual potential within 2 weeks of injury prevents the occurrence of sympathetic ophthalmia.

questions.text: A study was conducted among the postgraduate students in a medical college to find out the time taken by them to complete various tasks in different clinical departments. Which management technique is being applied for this analysis?
questions.solution:
The management technique that is being applied for the above study is work sampling.

Work sampling is a quantitative management technique. It refers to the systematic observation and recording of the activities of one or more individuals. It is done at predetermined or random intervals. It mainly includes analyzing the type of activities performed and the time needed to perform the same.

These studies have been done on doctors, nurses, pharmacists, and laboratory technicians. This technique can find the appropriateness of the current staff, job description, and training. This may standardize the methods of performing activities and determine the manpower needed in an organization.

Management is the purposeful and effective use of resources such as manpower, materials, and finances for the fulfillment of a pre-determined objective. They consist of four basic activities: planning, organizing, communicating, and monitoring.

Management techniques are of two types:

Quantitative methods

Methods based on behavioral sciences
  • Cost-Benefit analysis
  • Cost-Effective analysis
  • Cost-Accounting
  • Input-Output analysis
  • Model
  • Systems analysis
  • Network analysis
    • Program Evaluation and Review Technique (PERT)
    • Critical Path Method (CPM)
  • Planning–Programming–Budgeting System (PPBS)
  • Work sampling
  • Decision making
  • Organizational design
  • Personnel management
  • Communication
  • Information systems
  • Management by objectives (MBO)

Other options:

Option A: Cost-effective analysis is a management technique in which the economic benefits of any program are compared with the cost of the program. The benefits are expressed in terms of the results achieved. (Eg: number of lives saved or number of days free from disease).

Option C: Critical pathway method is a type of network analysis technique. The longest path in the network is called the critical path. If any delay in activity along the critical pathway, the entire study will be delayed.

Option D: Input-output analysis is an economic technique to analyze the amount of input needed to produce a unit amount of output. In the health field, input refers to all health service activities that consume resources (manpower, money, materials, and time). Output refers to useful outcomes such as cases treated, lives saved, or inoculations performed.

questions.text: In patients with which of the following conditions would you expect a t(8;14) translocation?
questions.solution:
Burkitt's lymphoma is associated with the following chromosomal abnormalities:

  • t(8;14) or MYC-IGH - 75-85% of cases
  • t(8;22 )
  • t(2;8)

Burkitt lymphoma, also known as small non-cleaved-cell lymphoma, is a highly aggressive B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma. It is the most common NHL in children <15 years.  It is characterized by the translocation and deregulation of the c-myc gene on chromosome 8. The translocation most commonly seen in Burkitt's lymphoma is t(8;14).

It can occur in 3 forms mainly presenting in children or young adults

  • African (endemic) Burkitt lymphoma - it often presents as a mass involving the mandible. It may also involve the abdominal viscera, particularly the kidneys, ovaries, and adrenal glands. 
  • Sporadic (non-endemic) Burkitt lymphoma - it most often appears as a mass involving the ileocecum and peritoneum
  • Aggressive lymphoma or acute leukaemia - it is seen in immunocompromised individuals

Histopathology

Tumour cells show multiple small nucleoli, minimal cytoplasm and a high mitotic index. They are closely apposed to each other forming a dark blue background (sky).

The macrophages get stuffed in between along with cellular debris. They are called tingible body macrophages. Upon fixation, the cytoplasm of these phagocytes washes away leaving behind white spaces filled with debris (the stars).

Treatment is by Radiotherapy and Chemotherapy(Cyclophosphamide, methotrexate and orthomelphalan). Surgery is usually not indicated unless it is localised or in case of involvement of ovaries. The prognosis is good.

Related Pearl: Malignancies, Translocations and Affected Genes
