Related Pearl: Burkitt Lymphoma

 

  • It is the most common NHL in children <15 years
  • Burkitt's leukemia (Bone marrow involvement) is ALL-L3 .It is associated with c-myc dysregulation.
  •  Important translocations are: t (8;14), t (2;8), t (8,22)
  • Three distinct clinical forms:
    • Endemic: affects children in Africa, affects jaw, maxilla and is EBV-associated
    • Sporadic: in adults in western countries 
    • Immunodeficiency associated: HIV infection
  • Most patients present with peripheral lymphadenopathy and intrabdominal mass and it rapidly progresses and metastasize to CNS.
  • It is the most rapidly proliferating human tumor, Ki-67 stains for 100% of cells .
  • Histology: Starry sky pattern
  • Immunophenotype: 
    • The tumor cells express  B cell-associated antigens (CD19, CD20, CD22, CD79a), germinal center-associated markers (CD10 & BCL-6), & CD43. BCL-2 may be present in upto 20%. 
    • Expression of CD21 -the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV)/C3d receptor, is dependent on EBV status of the tumors.
      • Endemic BL are EBV positive, express CD21
      • Non-endemic BL in non-immunosuppressed patients are EBV negative and lack CD21 expression
  • Treatment:
    • Begins immediately after the diagnosis in both children and adults with the use of an intensive combination of chemotherapy regimens with high doses of cyclophosphamide
    • Prophylactic therapy to the CNS is mandatory
  • Cure rate is 70-80% (good prognosis)

questions.text: A boy is diagnosed with Meckel's diverticulum. Which of the following is not true about this condition?

choices.text: Gastric mucosa is the most common heterotropic mucosa seen.
Intestinal obstruction is the most common presentation in children.

questions.solution:
Intestinal obstruction is the most common presentation in adults with Meckel’s diverticula. Bleeding is the most common manifestation in children.

Meckel’s Diverticulum:

  • Meckel’s diverticulum is caused by a failure of normal regression of the vitelline duct that develops during weeks 5 to 7 of gestation.
  • The rule of 2s (Mnemonic for Meckel’s diverticulum) :
    • 2 types of heterotopic mucosa (gastric & pancreatic)
    • 2% incidence
    • located within 2 feet of the ileocecal valve
    • approximately 2 inches in length
    • Usually symptomatic by 2 years of age
  • Most common presentation is painless, massive, lower GI bleed in children younger than 5 years.
  • A Meckel's can be the lead point for ileoileal or ileocolic intussusception.
  • The bleeding Meckel's diverticulum may be confirmed by a 99 mTc-pertechnetate isotope scan to detect gastric mucosa.
  • Surgical treatment is the definitive therapy for Meckel’s diverticulum. A simple V-shaped diverticulectomy with transverse closure of the ileum is the ideal surgical approach.

Related Pearl: Rule of two’s in Meckel's diverticulum

  • 2% prevalence
  • 2:1 male predominance
  • Location 2 feet (60 cm) proximal to the ileocecal valve in adults
  • 2 inches in length
  • Half of those who are symptomatic are under 2 years of age.

questions.text: A 2-year-old male child is brought with testicular swelling. USG shows a 3cm solid mass within the body of the testis. Serum AFP is 230 ng/ml. The orchidectomy specimen revealed a nonencapsulated tumor having a homogeneous, yellow-white, mucinous appearance. The microscopy image is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis of the above clinical scenario is the yolk sac tumor of the testis (Endodermal sinus tumour). 

The given microscopic image shows a lacelike reticular network of cuboidal tumour cells and Schiller duval bodies.

Yolk sac tumor is the most common testicular tumor in infants and children up to 3 years of age. In this age group, it has a very good prognosis. 

Eosinophilic, hyaline-like globules may be present within and outside the cytoplasm in which α-fetoprotein (AFP) and α1-antitrypsin can be demonstrated by immunocytochemical staining.

Histology of yolk sac tumour of the testis showing schiller duval bodies (arrow).

questions.text: The term 'choking' as understood in ballistics, applies to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Choking is a modification applied to the barrel of a shotgun.

Choke - This is where the barrel is modified such that it slightly tapers towards the muzzle. This will produce a narrower cone of shot, when the ammunition is fired and thus, prevent dispersion of pellets. This can thus affect estimation of range of firing when examining the entry wound. 

Types of choking:

  • Improved cylinder
  • Modified choke
  • Half-choke
  • Full-choke

questions.text: According to the national framework for malaria elimination in India, states were categorized based on ______.
questions.solution:
The annual parasite incidence (API) is used to categorize states/union territories under the national framework for malaria elimination in India.

The national framework for malaria elimination in India was launched in February 2016 with the following goals:

  • Eliminate malaria throughout the entire country by 2030
  • Maintain malaria-free status in areas where transmission has been interrupted and prevent re-introduction

It uses the annual parasite index to classify states/union territories into four categories.

  • Category 0 (Prevention of re-establishment phase): States/union territories with zero cases
  • Category 1 (Elimination phase): States/union territories with all their districts having API <1
  • Category 2 (pre-elimination phase): States/union territories with API <1, but some of their districts having API≥1
  • Category 3 (Intensified control phase): States/union territories with API≥1

API is calculated by the formula: confirmed cases during one year X 1000 / population under surveillance.

Regions with API≥ 2 are considered high-risk areas and are eligible for vector control.

Other options:

Option B: Slide positivity rate is used to describe the percentage of slides positive for the malarial parasite. The type of species is not taken into account.

Option C: Slide falciparum rate is the percentage of slides that are positive for Plasmodium falciparum species. 

Option D: Annual blood examination rate is derived by the formula - number of slides examined X 100/ Population. It is considered an index of operational efficiency.

Related Pearl: Malaria in the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP)

National Framework for Malaria Elimination in India (2016)

  • Goals: To eliminate malaria and maintain malaria-free status.
  • Objectives:
    • By 2022, transmission of malaria interrupted and zero indigenous cases.
    • By 2024, incidence of malaria to be reduced to less than 1 case per 1000 population.
    • By 2030, malaria to be eliminated throughout the country.

Categories according to the Annual Parasite Index (API):

 

Category  Definition  Major measures:
Category 0  States/UTs with zero indigenous cases  Detect re-introduced cases and notify and maintain malaria-free status. 
Category 1  Elimination phase – States/UTs with API <1 and all their districts reporting API <1  Interruption of local transmission.
Category 2  Pre-elimination phase – States/UTs with API <1 but some districts reporting API ≥ 1. 

Screening. 

Setting up one-stop mobile centres/clinics. 

 
Category 3  Intensified control phase – States/UTs with API ≥ 1.   Same as category 2

questions.text: What is the chromosome number of a partial hydatidiform mole?
questions.solution:
Partial hydatidiform mole has 69XXY or 69XXX karyotype.

Hydatidiform moles may be either partial or complete:

Partial moles:

  • They occur due to the fertilization of an egg with two sperms.
  • The karyotype is usually triploid (69, XXY) or occasionally tetraploid (92, XXXY).
  • Fetal tissues are typically present.
  • They are associated with an increased risk of persistent molar disease but are not associated with choriocarcinoma.

Complete moles:

  • They occur due to the fertilization of an egg that has lost its female chromosomes.
  • In about 90% of the cases, the genetic material of one sperm is duplicated, resulting in a diploid 46, XX karyotype.
  • In the remaining 10% of the cases, the empty egg is fertilized by two sperms, resulting in a diploid karyotype, which is either 46, XX, or 46, XY.
  • In complete moles, the embryo usually dies early in the development, and hence, cannot be identified. 

Related Pearl: Complete vs. Partial Mole

Feature Partial mole Complete mole
Karyotype 69 XXX or 69 XXY 46 XX or 46 XY
Diagnosis Missed abortion Molar gestation
Uterus size Small for date Large for date
Theca-lutein cysts Rare 25–30% of cases
Initial hCG levels <1 lakh mIU/ml >1 lakh mIU/ml
Medical complications Rare Uncommon
Rate of subsequent GTN 1–5% 15–20%
Embryo-fetus  Often present Absent
Amnion, fetal erythrocytes Often present Absent
Villous edema  Focal Widespread
Trophoblastic proliferation Focal, slight to moderate Slight to severe
Trophoblast atypia Mild Marked
p57KIP2 immunostaining Positive Negative

questions.text:
A 50-year-old smoker and hypertensive male, complaints of exertional angina. He says it occurs almost daily now, from a very long time. ECG shows ST depression. On cardiac evaluation, there is no increase in the levels of cardiac biomarkers. What could be the most probable diagnosis of the patient?

Non-ST elevation myocardial infarction- NSTEMI

ST-elevation myocardial infarction- STEMI
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is unstable angina.

Unstable angina is chest discomfort or pain due to insufficient blood flow and oxygen to the heart. It occurs due to the development of the thrombus on a pre-existing disrupted atherosclerotic plaque and is non-occlusive. The patients develop chest pain radiating to the jaws or arms and shortness of breath. 

An electrocardiogram may show hyperacute T-wave, T-wave flattening, inverted T-waves, and ST depression in unstable angina. Unstable angina is diagnosed in patients with symptoms suggestive of acute coronary syndrome with no elevation of cardiac biomarkers. If cardiac biomarkers are elevated in these patients, then the diagnosis of myocardial infarction is considered.

Acute coronary syndromes (ACS) include:

  • Unstable angina(UA).
  • Non-ST elevation myocardial infarction(NSTEMI).
  • ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI).

Other options:

Option A: NSTEMI is one of the components of ACS in which there are ST-segment depression and deep T-wave inversions. The cardiac biomarkers are elevated in NSTEMI unlike in unstable angina.

Option B: STEMI is one of the components of ACS in which there is ST-segment elevation with T-wave changes. The cardiac biomarkers are elevated in STEMI.

Option C: Left heart failure results due to dysfunction of the left ventricle, leading to insufficient delivery of blood to vital organs. The electrocardiogram shows non-specific ischemic changes, left ventricle hypertrophy or arrhythmias. The cardiac biomarker like brain natriuretic peptide may be elevated.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man undergoing treatment for TB visits your OPD for a follow-up. His wife states that recently he keeps forgetting the names of his colleagues and neighbors, but later recollects them correctly. Which drug is implicated to cause this condition?
questions.solution:
Isoniazid is the antitubercular drug that is implicated in the causation of transient memory loss.

Neurological toxicities like peripheral neuropathy, optic neuritis, and seizures can occur with isoniazid therapy. It is also associated with abnormalities like:

  • Euphoria
  • Transient memory loss
  • Separation of ideas and reality
  • Loss of self-control
  • Florid psychosis

Pyridoxine therapy can prevent and reverse most of the neurological toxicity and mental abnormalities.

Related Pearl: Key points on the first line drugs used in the treatment of TB

Drugs Isoniazid Rifamycins Pyrazinamide Ethambutol
Mechanism of action Blocks mycolic acid synthesis. Inhibition of RNA polymerase, leading to the inhibition of RNA synthesis. Inhibition of fatty acid synthase-I, leading to the inhibition of the cell membrane. Inhibition of arabinosyl transferase, leading to a reduction in arabinogalactan needed for the cell wall.
Unique side effects

Shoulder hand syndrome and CNS side effects.

 Orange urine, sweat, and tears. Flu-like symptoms with intermittent dosing.

The most hepatotoxic drug. It also causes hyperuricemia.

Optic neuritis and hence, not preferred in children.
Mechanism of resistance

Kat G mutation- the most severe form of resistance.

Inh a gene overexpression-  confers cross-resistance with ethionamide.

Mutation in rpoB- the gene coding for the β subunit of RNA polymerase.

 Mutation of the Pnca gene.

Mutations in the embB gene.

questions.text: A 6-foot 5-inch man undergoing a routine physical examination was found to have an early diastolic murmur. His family pedigree chart is given below. Identify the mode of inheritance of this condition.
questions.solution:
The patient's height and the presence of early diastolic murmur suggest that the condition could be Marfan syndrome, which is inherited in an autosomal dominant mode. The family pedigree confirms the mode of inheritance.

Patients with Marfan syndrome are tall and have an decreased upper to lower segment ratio with long arms, hands, and fingers. Deformities of the chest wall, vertebral column, and foot arches may be present.

Associated cardiovascular abnormalities include mitral valve prolapse leading to mitral regurgitation and dilatation of aortic root/sinuses of Valsalva leading to aortic regurgitation, aortic dissection, and rupture.

The following flow chart helps in making out the pattern of inheritance from a given pedigree chart.

questions.text: A patient comes to the OPD with a history significant of a mood disorder. Her moods can be charted as shown in the image. What will be the best drug for her?
questions.solution:
The patient is suffering from rapid cycling bipolar disorder. Lithium is used to treat this condition.

Diagnosis of rapid cycling bipolar disorder:

  • 4 or more mood disturbances in a year
  • Episodes either have a partial or full remission for atleast 2 months or switch to the opposite polarity

Lithium is a mood stabilizer with a very narrow therapeutic index and is the first line of management in bipolar disorder. It decreases the rate of suicide and is also used in depression with inadequate response to monotherapy and cases of recurrent depression.

Lithium has a very narrow therapeutic index of 0.8-1.2 mEq/L. The severity of lithium toxicity is often divided into the following three grades: 

Grade

Sr. lithium concentration (in mEq/L)

 Symptoms
Mild symptoms 1.5-2.5  nausea, vomiting, tremor, and fatigue
Moderate intoxication 2.5-3.5  confusion, agitation, delirium, tachycardia, and hypertonia
Severe intoxication >3.5  coma, seizures, hyperthermia, and hypotension

Treatment options include gastric lavage and whole bowel irrigation for patients presenting early to the emergency department. Hemodialysis is done for patients demonstrating any signs and symptoms of severe lithium poisoning.

Related Pearl: Lithium in bipolar disorder

Guidelines for Lithium therapy
Indications:
Mania, hypomania, bipolar disorder, etc.

Blood levels of lithium:

For therapeutic purpose (treatment of acute mania) : 0.8-1.2 mEq/L

For prophylaxis (to prevent relapse of bipolar disorder): 0.5-0.8 mEq/L

Toxic levels of lithium: >/= 1.5 mEq/L
Contraindications:
  • CKD
  • Heart disease
  • Hyponatremia or diuretic use
Baseline studies:
  • BUN (Blood Urea Nitrogen), Creatinine, Calcium, Urine analysis
  • Thyroid function test
  • ECG in patients with coronary risk factors
Acute adverse effects:
  • Tremor, ataxia, weakness
  • Polyuria, polydipsia
  • Vomiting, diarrhea
  • Cognitive impairment
Chronic adverse effects:
  • Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus
  • Thyroid dysfunction
  • Hyperparathyroidism

questions.text: A 48-year-old male presents with complaints of urinary incontinence. His history is notable for increasing forgetfulness and the physical examination reveals an abnormal gait. His fundus looks normal, he has no tremors.  Which of the following conditions is it most likely to be?
questions.solution:
Based on the given clinical scenario the probable diagnosis is normal pressure hydrocephalus. 

Normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH) is a reversible cause of dementia, typically presenting with the classic triad of dementia, ataxia, and urinary incontinence. With early diagnosis and prompt treatment, symptoms can often be reversed.

NPH occurs due to impaired cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) flow and delayed absorption, often resulting from scarring of the basilar meninges. It is characterized by communicating hydrocephalus and the hallmark triad (dementia, ataxia, and urinary incontinence). Papilledema is not observed. Neuroimaging typically reveals enlarged lateral ventricles with little or no cortical atrophy, while the Sylvian fissures may appear enlarged, a phenomenon known as "boxcarring," which can be confused with perisylvian atrophy. The preferred treatment is ventriculoperitoneal shunting, and CSF parameters are generally normal.

Related Pearl: Differential diagnosis of dementia

CONDITION FEATURES
Alzheimer’s disease
  • Insidious onset
  • Short-term memory loss
  • Language deficits and spatial disorientation
  • Later, personality changes
Vascular Dementia
  • Stepwise decline
  • Early executive dysfunction
  • Cerebral infarction &/or deep white matter changes on neuroimaging
Frontotemporal dementia
(Pick’s disease)
  • Early personality changes
  • Apathy, disinhibition & compulsive behaviors
  • Frontotemporal atrophy on neuroimaging
Dementia with Lewy bodies
  • Visual Hallucination
  • Spontaneous parkinsonism
  • Fluctuating cognition
Normal-pressure hydrocephalus
  • Gait abnormalities 
  • Urinary Incontinence
  • Dementia
  • Dilated ventricles on neuroimaging
Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease
(Prion disease)
  • Behavioral changes
  • Rapidly progressive
  • Myoclonus &/or seizures

questions.text: A 25-year-old diabetic woman presents to the OPD with the following skin lesions. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image showing irregular plaques with yellowish discoloration and telangiectasias are suggestive of necrobiosis lipoidica diabeticorum.

It is an inflammatory granulomatous disorder of the skin due to collagen degeneration and lipid deposition. It is usually seen in young women with diabetes mellitus.

The lesions usually begin in the pretibial region. It begins as papules that gradually enlarge and darken to form erythematous plaques with irregular margins, atrophic centers, and central ulceration.

Option A: Necrolytic migratory erythema is a feature of glucagonoma. It is a waxing and waning rash that appears as shown below.

Option B: Diabetic dermopathy or shin spots are commonly seen in elderly men. It presents as pigmented pretibial papules as shown below.

Option D: Granuloma annulare presents with small papules arranged in an annular pattern. There is no yellowish discoloration or telangiectasias, as shown below.

questions.text: Identify the condition given in the image :
questions.solution:
The condition in the given image is acanthosis nigricans.

It is a skin condition is characterized by thickened, gray-brown velvety plaques seen in flexural areas such as the back of the neck, axillae, inframammary creases, waist, and groin.

The causal mechanism is due to the secretion of epidermal growth factor in the region involved. It can be benign or malignancy-associated.

Benign acanthosis nigricans is often associated with obesity or insulin resistance, it is common and usually mild.

Malignancy associated acanthosis nigricans is much less common. It is usually associated with gastric carcinoma, lung carcinoma, and uterine carcinoma.

Acanthosis nigricans can also be seen in the following:

  • Drugs such as Nicotinic acid used to treat hyperlipidemia 
  • Sudden onset of multiple seborrhoeic keratosis

Related Pearl: Paraneoplastic dermatoses

Cutaneous markers and their commonly associated internal malignancy:

questions.text: Histopathological examination of lesions in sarcoidosis shows all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Histopathological examination of lesions in sarcoidosis does not show Birbeck bodies. These bodies are seen in Langerhans cell histiocytosis.

Birbeck bodies are tennis racket-shaped structures found in the Langerhans cells of Langerhans cell histiocytosis (shown in the image below). Although it can occur in adults, it is seen more commonly in children. Lesions similar to seborrheic eruptions are seen on the back, scalp, and trunk.

The cardinal histopathologic feature of sarcoidosis, irrespective of the organ involved, is the non-caseating granuloma. Two other microscopic features are sometimes seen in the granulomas: 

  • Schaumann bodies: Inclusion bodies with concentric rings of calcification
  • Asteroid bodies: Stellate inclusions in the giant cells

Noncaseating granulomas can also be seen in:

  • Berylliosis
  • Crohn's disease
  • Foreign body granuloma

questions.text: Which of the following organisms produces superantigen?
questions.solution:
Streptococcus pyogenes produces streptococcal pyrogenic exotoxin (SPE), which is a superantigen.

Superantigens are protein toxins that stimulate large numbers of T cells, irrespective of antigen specificity. They bind to the class II MHC molecule outside the peptide-binding groove and Vβ region of the TCR.

Some examples of superantigens are staphylococcal enterotoxins, toxic shock syndrome toxin, and group A streptococcal pyrogenic exotoxin.

The below image shows the binding of superantigen to T-cell receptor.

questions.text: Which one of the following is not a feature in cerebral palsy?
questions.solution:
Flaccid paralysis is not a feature of cerebral palsy (CP). It is a feature of lower motor neuron disease.

CP is a static encephalopathy and a disorder of posture and movement often associated with:

  • A deficit in the motor, language, and social milestones
  • Microcephaly is a feature of cerebral palsy because of the insult to the developing brain.
  • Dystonic CP is associated with hypotonia
  • Extrapyramidal CP is associated with ataxia
  • It is an upper motor neuron disease characterized by rigidity and scissoring gait.
  • Spastic CP is the commonest type (65%)

Scissoring gait is a characteristic feature of cerebral palsy as shown in the GIF below-

questions.text: Which of the following is true about breast milk jaundice?

choices.text: It is seen in the first week of life

questions.solution:
The true statement about breast milk jaundice is that breastfeeding is to be continued.

Breastfeeding is not contraindicated in breast milk jaundice. Mothers are advised to continue breastfeeding at frequent intervals.

Breast Milk jaundice is seen in about 2–4 % of exclusively breastfed babies. There is significant unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia after the 7th day and may last for 2–3 weeks. This is due to the enzyme β-glucuronidase which deconjugates intestinal bilirubin and promotes its absorption. Persistently high bilirubin levels may require treatment with phototherapy, without cessation of breastfeeding.

Breastfeeding jaundice (BFJ)

  • Early-onset, unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia of breastfed infants.
  • Occurs in the 1st week after birth (usually appears after 24 - 72 hours of birth) 
  • Due to decreased milk intake with dehydration and/or reduced caloric intake. (Breastfeeding failure jaundice)
  • Treatment: Continue breastfeeding and supplementation with formula feeds if needed.

Breast milk jaundice (BMJ)

  • Late-onset, unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia of breastfed infants.
  • Occurs after the 7th day with maximal concentrations as high as 10–30 mg/dl reached during the 2nd-3rd week
  • Due to the presence of glucuronidase in breast milk (etiology not entirely clear).
  • Treatment: Continue breastfeeding and the bilirubin gradually decreases but may persist for 3-10 weeks at lower levels; phototherapy may be of benefit in some cases.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient is posted for abscess drainage from the ischioanal fossa. While draining the abscess, the surgeon injures the nerve present in the Alcock's canal. Which nerve is injured in the given scenario?
questions.solution:
The nerve that is injured in the given scenario is the pudendal nerve. 

The pudendal nerve arises from the ventral divisions of the 2nd, 3rd and 4th ventral sacral rami. It originates in the pelvis and enters the gluteal region via the greater sciatic foramen close to its attachment at the ischial spine. It then passes through the lesser sciatic foramen into the pudendal (Alcock's) canal. In the pudendal canal, the pudendal nerve gives off the inferior rectal nerve, perineal nerve and dorsal nerve of the penis or clitoris.

Alcock's canal is an enclosed fascia along the lateral wall of the ischioanal fossa. Its contents include:

  • Internal pudendal artery
  • Internal pudendal vein
  • Pudendal nerve

Therefore, injury to the nerve in the Alcock's canal is to the pudendal nerve.

Pudendal neuralgia is a chronic pain syndrome that occurs due to damage or irritation to the pudendal nerve. It is characterized by perineal pain which gets aggravated by sitting. The common causes are prolonged sitting, repetitive hip flexions like in sports activities, direct trauma like falls, pelvic surgeries, and radiation therapy for pelvic cancers. It can be treated with nerve protection strategies, medications like gabapentin or amitriptyline, pudendal nerve blocks or decompression surgeries.

Note: Ischioanal fossa is a wedge-shaped space on either side of the anal canal in the anorectal triangle. It has a pad of fat. The boundaries include:

  • Anterior: Posterior border of the perineal membrane
  • Posterior: Gluteus maximus muscle, sacrotuberous ligament
  • Lateral: Ischial tuberosity, obturator internus
  • Medial: Sphincter ani externus, pelvic diaphragm (levator ani).

Clinical significance:

Ischioanal fossa provides a relatively bloodless field during resection of anal cancers, therefore it is an important surgical plane.

Other options:

Option A: Obturator nerve is a branch of the lumbar plexus that emerges near the L5 vertebra. It descends within the psoas major and then on the lateral wall of the pelvis before entering the obturator foramen to enter the thigh. It has no branches in the abdomen or pelvis.

Option B: Genitofemoral nerve arises from the L1 and L2. It pierces the psoas major and emerges out on the anterior surface. It descends and crosses obliquely behind the ureter and divides into genital and femoral branches. The genital branch passes through the inguinal canal and supplies the cremaster muscle and skin of the external genitalia. The femoral branch supplies the skin of the upper part of the femoral triangle. 

Option D: Accessory obturator nerve is formed from the L3 and L4. It emerges out along the medial border and travels on the posterior surface of the superior pubic ramus. It supplies the pectineus and hip joint.

questions.text: The instrument shown in the given image used for ______.
questions.solution:
The above image shows a manual vacuum aspiration syringe, used in manual vacuum aspiration.

It is used for early pregnancy failures or elective termination for up to 12 weeks. A Negative pressure of 660 mmHg is created and products of conception are aspirated.

This procedure takes less time and is less traumatic. It can be done on OPD basis.

questions.text: If the percentage of thymine residues in DNA is 28%. What is the percentage of cytosine?
questions.solution:
The percentage of cytosine in the DNA is 22%.

As per the Chargaff's rule, in the DNA molecules, the concentration of deoxyadenosine (A) equals that of thymidine (T), and the concentration of deoxyguanosine (G) equals that of deoxycytidine (C). Therefore, A=T and G=C.

In the question, the concentration of thymine is given as 28%, therefore the concentration of adenine is also 28%, both of which add up to 56%. The remaining 44% (100-56) of the DNA consists of G-C base pairs. Of which the guanine constitutes 22% and the cytosine constitutes another 22%.

questions.text: The type of potentiation in hippocampus is ______
questions.solution:
Long-term potentiation (LTP) occurs in the hippocampus.

  • Long-term Potentiation (LTP)
    • A rapidly developing persistent enhancement of the post-synaptic potential response to presynaptic stimulation, after rapidly repeated stimulation of presynaptic neuron
    • Characteristically observed in the hippocampus
    • NMDA receptors are involved in LTP.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy has swelling of knee joints and non-blanching rashes as seen in the picture. A urine exam reveals haematuria +++ and proteinuria +. Platelet levels are normal. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The boy in the above clinical scenario has the characteristic features of Henoch Schonlein purpura (HSP).

Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP), also known as IgA vasculitis, is a common small vessel vasculitis affecting children of 3-8 years of age. It is a type III hypersensitivity reaction characterised by the deposition of IgA in the small vessels of the skin, joints, gastrointestinal tract, and kidney, resulting in vasculitis.

The exact etiology of HSP remains unknown. But, it usually occurs following an upper respiratory tract infection caused by group A Streptococcus, Staphylococcus aureus, Mycoplasma, and Adenovirus.

Clinical features of HSP include: 

  • Palpable purpura is symmetric and occurs in the lower extremities, extensor aspect of the upper limbs, and buttocks
  • Arthralgia and arthritis - commonly affecting hip, knee, or ankle joints
  • Gastrointestinal manifestations - abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhea, and intussusception
  • Renal manifestations - microscopic hematuria, hypertension, and progressive glomerulonephritis

Laboratory findings seen in HSP are nonspecific and include leukocytosis, thrombocytosis, mild anemia, and elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP). The platelet count is usually normal. A skin biopsy specimen can be useful in confirming leukocytoclastic vasculitis with IgA and C3 deposition by immunofluorescence. Rarely, IgG and IgM deposits may also be seen.

Glucocorticoids such as prednisolone are used for the treatment of gastrointestinal manifestations in HSP. Nephritis due to IgA vasculitis should be treated with immunosuppressants like prednisolone and azathioprine.

questions.text: The memory disorder correctly matched with the pathology is?

choices.text: Korsakoff syndrome -  hyperactivation of mammillary bodies
Alzheimer's disease - early degeneration of frontal lobe
Frontotemporal dementia - mesial temporal lobe atrophy

questions.solution:
The cognitive decline in Alzheimer's disease is due to the loss of synapses and neuronal degeneration.

Microscopically, the following are seen:

  • Neuritic plaques - containing amyloid-β
  • Neurofibrillary tangles - containing abnormally phosphorylated tau proteins
  • Amyloid-β accumulation in the blood vessel walls of the cortex and leptomeninges.

Option A: In Korsakoff syndrome, there is inactivation (not hyperactivation) of mammillary bodies due to thiamine deficiency.

Option C: Alzheimer's disease initially affects the parietal and temporal lobe, followed by the frontal lobe in the later stages. Hence personality changes are a late feature of Alzheimer's. 

Option D: Mesial temporal lobe atrophy is very sensitive for Alzheimer's disease.

World Alzheimer’s Day is an international campaign to raise awareness and highlight issues faced by people affected by dementia, it takes place every year on 21 September. The theme for World Alzheimer's Month in 2020 is "Let's talk about dementia"

questions.text: Which of the following murmur increases on standing?
questions.solution:
The murmur of HOCM increases on standing.

Standing decreases the preload and it leads to an increase in the obstruction and intensity of the murmur.

The murmur of HOCM is a mid-systolic murmur best heard at the lower left sternal border. S1 is normal, S2 may show paradoxical splitting, and S4 is heard.

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) -

HCM is the leading cause of sudden death in young. It is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. It is characterized by predominant diastolic dysfunction presenting as exercise intolerance. 

The patients have a dynamic left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction due to septal hypertrophy and systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve leaflet (SAM). SAM leads to mitral regurgitation with the jet directed posteriorly. It is characterized by misalignment of the enlarged myofibrils and myocytes

Clinical features - While most patients are asymptomatic some of them may develop the following symptoms - dyspnea on exertion, fatigue, atypical or anginal chest pain, presyncope and syncope, and palpitation.

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HOCM) is associated with a mid-systolic murmur with the following features:

  • Loudest along the left sternal border
  • Increases in intensity by maneuvers that result in increasing degrees of outflow tract obstruction:
    • Reduction in preload or afterload: Valsalva, standing, vasodilators
    • Increased contractility: inotropic stimulation  
  • Decreases in intensity when there is
    • Increase in preload: squatting, passive leg raising, volume administration
    • Increase in afterload: squatting, vasopressors
    • Reduced contractility: β-adrenoreceptor blockers

Diagnosis - 

  • ECG - findings include -
    • Prominent abnormal Q waves
    • P wave abnormalities 
    • Left axis deviation.
    • Deeply inverted T waves 
  • Echocardiography -
    •  LV wall thickness ≥15 mm
    • Systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve
    • LVOT(left ventricular outflow tract) obstruction

Treatment -

  • For patients with LVOT obstruction - beta-blockers, non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers, and disopyramide may be used. Vasodilators and diuretics must be avoided in patients with LVOT obstruction.
  • Patients without LVOT obstruction with LVEF ≥50 percent - Initial monotherapy with either a beta-blocker or a non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker is started. Diuretics may be used as needed.

Related Pearl: Dynamic auscultation of murmurs

Bedside Manoeuvre Effect
Inspiration (↑venous return to right atrium) ↑ intensity of right sided sounds
Hand grip (↑afterload ) ↑ intensity of MR, AR and VSD murmurs
↓ hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and AS murmurs
MVP: delayed onset of click / murmur
Valsalva-Phase II, standing up (↓ preload) ↓ intensity of most murmurs (including AS)
↑ intensity of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy murmur
MVP: earlier onset of click /murmur
Rapid squatting (↑venous return,↑preload,
↑ afterload)		 ↓intensity of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy murmur
↑ intensity of AS, MR and VSD murmurs
MVP: later onset of click / murmur

questions.text: Which of the following was launched to ensure complete immunization of children?
questions.solution:
Mission Indradhanush was launched by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare in 2014 to fully immunize children (>90%) who are either partially immunized or completely unimmunized by 2020. It was later modified in 2017 to the Intensified Mission Indradhanush, to achieve the same goal by December 2018. 

Intensified Mission Indradhanush includes 12 vaccine-preventable diseases (updated from the 7 diseases that Mission Indradhanush focussed on). 4 rounds of immunization are proposed to be held for 7 days each month (from the 7th- 13th of each month).

The diseases included in Mission Indradhanush are:

  • TB
  • Polio
  • Hep B
  • Diphtheria
  • Pertussis
  • Tetanus
  • Measles

The diseases included recently in Intensified Mission Indradhanush are:

  • Rotavirus diarrhoea
  • Rubella (as MR vaccine)
  • H. influenzae B diseases (as part of the pentavalent vaccine)
  • Pneumococcal meningitis
  • Japanese Encephalitis

questions.text: A 2 week-old neonate developed meningitis following a scalp abscess. What is the likely route of spread?
questions.solution:
The infection has likely spread from the sub-aponeurotic tissue. 

The sub-aponeurotic loose areolar tissue of the scalp is referred to as the dangerous area of the scalp. Infection from this layer can pass into the cranial cavity through small emissary veins, which pass through parietal foramina in the calvaria. It can reach intracranial structures causing meningitis and intracranial abscesses. 

The scalp is a soft tissue that covers the calvaria of the skull. It consists of five layers (Mnemonic- SCALP):

  1. Skin
  2. Connective tissue (superficial fascia) with blood vessels and nerves
  3. Aponeurosis (galea aponeurotica) with occipitofrontalis muscle
  4. Loose areolar (sub-aponeurotic) tissue
  5. Pericranium

questions.text: Which of the following bones is most accurate for sex determination?
questions.solution:
The whole pelvis is the most reliable bone for sex determination.

Krogman’s degree of accuracy in sex determination from adult skeletal remains:

  • Entire skeleton – 100%
  • Pelvis alone – 95%
  • Skull alone – 90%
  • Pelvis plus skull – 98%
  • Long bones alone – 80-90%
  • Long bones and skull - 90-95%
  • Long bones and pelvis - >95%

Related Pearl: Indices for determination of race and sex of an individual

To determine the sex of an individual -

Krogman's degree of accuracy in sexing adult skeletal remains:

  • Entire skeleton – 100%
  • Pelvis alone – 95%
  • Skull alone – 90%
  • Pelvis plus skull – 98%
  • Long bones alone – 80%

questions.text: What is the ideal time for nuchal translucency evaluation?
questions.solution:
Nuchal translucency evaluation, a component of first-trimester aneuploidy screening, is done between 11-14 weeks.

It represents the maximum thickness of the subcutaneous translucent area between the skin and soft tissue, overlying the fetal spine, at the back of the neck. When the nuchal translucency is increased, the risk of fetal aneuploidy and structural anomalies such as heart defects is significantly elevated.

First trimester aneuploidy screening combines two maternal serum analytes and a sonographic measurement:

  1. Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG)
  2. Pregnancy-associated plasma protein A (PAPP-A)
  3. Nuchal translucency (NT)

It is performed between 11 and 14 weeks of gestation. In cases of fetal Down syndrome, the first-trimester serum-free β-hCG level is higher and the PAPP-A level is lower. With trisomy 18 and trisomy 13, levels of both analytes are lower.

Note: Nuchal fold is a normal fold of skin seen at the back of the fetal neck during the second trimester of pregnancy. Increased nuchal fold thickness is associated with fetal aneuploidy.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions does not show the finding seen in the image below?
questions.solution:
The cardiotocograph shows sinusoidal fetal heart rate pattern and is not seen in fetal head compression which shows early deceleration. Sinusoidal pattern is seen in the following conditions.

  • Fetal intracranial hemorrhage
  • Severe fetal asphyxia
  • Severe fetal anemia - Due to anti-D alloimmunization, feto-maternal haemorrhage, bleeding from vasa previa, parvovirus infection and twin-twin transfusion syndrome.
  • Administration of opioid analgesics - pethidine, morphine, alphaprodine, and butorphanol

The pattern is characterized by a stable baseline heart rate between 120-160 with regular sinusoidal oscillations. The amplitude of the oscillations is usually between 5-15 beats per minute and accelerations are absent.

Other cardiotocography patterns:

Early deceleration:

Seen in foetal head compression.

Late deceleration:

Seen in uteroplacental insufficiency, foetal hypoxia.  

Variable deceleration:

Seen in umbilical cord compression.

questions.text: Which of the following pairs is incorrect?

choices.text: Rosenbach sign - Pulsations of the liver
Traube's sign - Pulsations of the spleen
Muller's sign - Systolic pulsations of uvula

questions.solution:
The incorrect pair is Traube's sign - Pulsations of the spleen. Traube's sign is a pistol shot sound heard over femoral arteries seen in aortic regurgitation (AR).

Aortic regurgitation (AR) is a valvular disease of the aortic valve caused by primary valve disease, aortic root disease or their combination.

Auscultatory findings in AR are:

  • Soft S1 - due to the early closure of the mitral valve
  • Diminished or absent A2
  • S3 - due to increased left ventricular (LV) end-diastolic volume. The presence of S3 may be a sign of impaired LV function.
  • Early diastolic murmur -
    • High-pitched, blowing, decrescendo, early diastolic murmur
    • Best heard in the left-third intercostal space
    • Heard with the patient sitting up and leaning forward, with breath held in forced expiration
    • Duration of the murmur best correlates with the severity
  • Systolic ejection murmur - It is heard due to increased LV stroke volume and ejection rate.
  • Austin Flint murmur - a low-pitched, mid to late diastolic murmur. It is caused due to the large volume of regurgitant blood, hitting the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve or LV wall.

Other signs :

  • Gerhardt’s sign- Pulsations of the spleen, detected in the presence of splenomegaly (Option B)
  • Rosenbach sign- pulsations are felt over the liver (Option A)
  • Becker's sign is the presence of retinal artery pulsation on fundoscopy (Option C)
  • Muller's sign- systolic pulsations of the uvula (Option D)

Treatment of aortic regurgitation:

In non-severe AR, periodic monitoring can be done. Diuretics and vasodilators can manage the symptoms of dyspnea and decreased cardiac output.

In severe AR, surgery is indicated in the following conditions:

  • The patient is symptomatic
  • The patient is asymptomatic, but the LV ejection fraction is less than 50% or LV end-diastolic diameter is more than 65mm.
  • The patient is asymptomatic and undergoing other cardiac surgeries.

Related Pearl: Different signs in Aortic Regurgitation

Sign

Description

De Musset's sign

  Head nodding with each heartbeat

Collapsing/Water Hammer/Corrigan pulse

 It is a bounding pulse with rapid upstroke  and descent

Lighthouse sign

  Alternate flushing & blanching of the forehead

Landolfi’s sign

  Alternating constriction and dilation of the pupil

Becker’s sign

  Retinal artery pulsations

Quincke’s pulse

 Alternate flushing and paling of the skin at the root of the nail while pressure is applied to the tip of the nail
Rosenbach’s sign  Pulsation of liver
Gerhardt’s sign  Pulsation over the spleen, detected in the presence of splenomegaly

Traube’s sign

 A pistol shot sound over femoral arteries

Durozeiz’s sign

 To-and-fro murmur over the femoral artery when lightly compressed with a stethoscope

Hill’s sign

 The systolic blood pressure of the lower limb exceeds that of the upper limb at least by 20mm Hg

Muller’s sign

Systolic pulsation of the uvula

questions.text: A male patient is suspected to have pheochromocytoma. He has all the 3 symptoms making up the clinical triad of pheochromocytoma. Which of the following is not a part of this triad?
questions.solution:
The clinical triad of pheochromocytoma includes the following symptoms:

  • Headache
  • Profuse sweating
  • Palpitation (due to tachycardia)

Hypertension is the most predominant sign of pheochromocytoma. Though intermittent hypertension is a classical feature, sustained hypertension is also common.

Related Pearl: Pheochromocytoma

Features:

  • When pheochromocytoma is associated with the MEN syndrome it is rarely malignant.
  • Phaeochromocytomas are greyish-pink on the cut surface and are usually highly vascularised.
  • Zellbalen cells and nuclei with salt and pepper chromatin are seen.

Factors indicating more chances of malignancy:

  • An increased PASS (phaeochromocytoma of the adrenal gland scale score)
  • High number of Ki-67-positive cells
  • Vascular invasion or a breached capsule

Diagnosis:

  • Urinary catecholamine and VMA level assay are most sensitive screening test.
  • MRI is the IOC.
  • Biopsy and CT Contrast scan are contraindicated in order to avoid Hypertensive crisis.

Treatment:

  • Adrenalectomy is preferred TOC.
  • Size<5 cm -  Laparoscopic adrenalectomy
  • Preop Alpha blockers should be given
  • Mitotane should be started as adjuvant or palliative treatment

questions.text: Which is the most common cause of staphyloma at point D in the given image?
questions.solution:
Degenerative high axial myopia is the most common cause for posterior staphyloma (Point D)

Staphyloma:

  • It is an abnormal protrusion of the uveal tissue through a weak and thin portion of the cornea or sclera.
  • So, staphyloma is lined internally by uveal tissue and externally by weak cornea or sclera.
  • Types of Staphyloma:
    • Anterior staphyloma: It is characterized by ectasia of the pseudo-cornea, which occurs after the total sloughing of the cornea. It is lined internally by the iris and externally by the newly formed epithelium.
    • Intercalary staphyloma: This is located at the limbus and is lined by the root of the iris and the anterior-most part of the ciliary body
    • Ciliary staphyloma: It is characterized by ectasia of weak sclera lined by the ciliary body. This affects the ciliary zone, which includes the region up to 8 mm behind the limbus.
    • Equatorial staphyloma: This occurs at the equatorial region up to 14 mm behind the limbus of the eye.
    • Posterior staphyloma: This affects the posterior pole of the eye.
  • Note :
    • The most common cause for anterior staphyloma is sloughing corneal ulcer.
    • The most common cause for posterior staphyloma is degenerative high axial myopia.
  • In the image:
    • A: Intercalary staphyloma
    • B: Ciliary staphyloma
    • C: Equatorial staphyloma
    • D: Posterior staphyloma

questions.text: True statement about intermittent claudication:

choices.text: Most commonly felt in the calf muscles
Day to day distance is variable
Relived after getting out of bed

questions.solution:
Intermittent claudication is most commonly felt in the calf muscles because of the involvement of the superficial femoral artery in chronic vascular occlusive disease.

Intermittent claudication is the debilitating cramp-like pain felt in the leg muscles due to reduced blood flow brought on by peripheral arterial disease. It usually signifies mild to moderate chronic vascular occlusive disease.

The pain classically occurs during activity and is relieved with rest. The distance that a patient can walk without stopping till the pain is experienced in the muscles is known as claudication distance. This distance varies only slightly from day to day.

Rest pain signifies critical limb ischemia, occurring due to the worsening of perfusion to the muscle.

Related Pearl: Ankle–brachial Pressure Index (ABPI)

The ankle-brachial Pressure Index (ABPI) is the ratio of systolic pressure at the ankle to that in the arm.

The numerator is the highest pressure in the dorsalis pedis, posterior tibial, or peroneal artery and the denominator is the highest brachial systolic pressure.

ABPI Reading Interpretation
>0.91 < 1.3 Normal
<0.9 Diagnostic of occlusive arterial disease in patients with symptoms of claudication or other signs of ischemia
0.5 to 0.9 Arterial obstruction often associated with claudication
<0.3 Critical limb ischemia (multilevel obstruction i.e any combination of iliac, femoral or tibial vessel disease and may be associated with non-healing ulcerations, ischemic rest pain, or pedal gangrene.
>1.4 Signifies poor compressibility of the arteries. Mostly due to calcification because of increased age, diabetes etc.

Note: A fall in the resting ABPI of more than 20% after exercise is indicative of arterial disease.

questions.text: A patient comes with a ​history of clean-cut injury which is not lacerated. He says that he received his last dose of tetanus vaccination about 10 years ago. What should be given next?
questions.solution:
A single dose of tetanus toxoid is given as the wound is clean and the last dose was received more than 10 years ago.

Post exposure prophylaxis for tetanus:

Prophylaxis is given based on patient category:

  1. Full immunization or a booster dose within the past 5 years.
  2. Full immunization or a booster dose > 5 years ago but < 10 years.
  3. Full immunization or a booster dose > 10 years ago.
  4. Unknown or never taken immunization
Category Clean wound Unclean wound
A Only wound care Only wound care
B Wound care + TT single dose Wound care + TT single dose
C Wound care + TT single dose Wound care + TT single dose + Human tetanus immunoglobulin 
D Wound care + TT complete course Wound care + TT complete course + Human tetanus immunoglobulin

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman complains of difficulty swallowing for the past few months. She also complains of bluish discoloration of fingers on exposure to cold for the past 5 years. On examination, she is found to have thickening of the skin of the hands and multiple dilated capillaries over the face. Which of the following is most specific for this disease?
questions.solution:
Anti-centromere antibodies are most specific for this disease.

This patient's clinical features are suggestive of CREST syndrome / Limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis.

CREST syndrome consists of :

  • Calcinosis cutis
  • Raynaud’s phenomenon
  • Esophageal dysmotility
  • Sclerodactyly
  • Telangiectasia

Systemic sclerosis is a chronic autoimmune disease. Progressive fibrosis due to the deposition of extracellular matrix components in different tissues and organs is the prominent feature.

The characteristic features of systemic sclerosis are vascular damage, inflammation, and the presence of specific autoantibodies. 

Systemic sclerosis is classified into two based on the extent of skin involvement.

  • Limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis / CREST syndrome
  • Diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis

In limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (lcSSc), fibrosis in the skin of acral parts of the body, like the face and limbs (distal to elbow and knee) takes place. Skin fibrosis in limited type has a slow progression but microcirculation disturbances like Raynaud's phenomenon start long before the skin symptoms and are associated with the involvement of the lungs and esophagus. 

Since it has late and slow organ involvement, it is associated with a good prognosis with a 10-year survival of over 90%. 

Antinuclear antibodies (ANA) are present in 90 - 95% of cases with SSc.

Autoantibodies specific to limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis include,

  • Anti- centromere
  • Anti-Th/To
  • Anti-U1-RNP
  • Anti-hUBF

Management is based on disease-modifying and organ-specific drugs. For peripheral vasculopathy and digital ulcers, calcium channel blockers like nifedipine, amlodipine is used and for refractory cases, phosphodiesterase 5 inhibitors are recommended.

Intravenous prostanoids are used for the healing process of digital ulcers and the improvement of microcirculation. The commonly used immunosuppressants for skin fibrosis are methotrexate, cyclophosphamide, and mycophenolate mofetil. When these drugs are ineffective or contraindicated, low-dose glucocorticosteroids or rituximab (anti-CD20) are used. 

Related Pearl: Autoantibodies Seen in Autoimmune Diseases

         Autoantibody Associated disease
Antinuclear (ANA)

SLE (non-specific)
Anticardiolipin lupus anticoagulant SLE, APLA syndrome
Anti-ds DNA, anti-smith SLE
Anti-histone Drug-induced Lupus
Anti-U1 RNP Mixed connective tissue disease
Rheumatoid factor, anti-CCP Rheumatoid arthritis
Anti-Ro/SSA, Anti-La/SSB Sjögren’s syndrome
Anti-Scl-70 (anti-DNA topoisomerase) Diffuse scleroderma
Anticentromere CREST syndrome
Anti-SRP, Anti-Mi-2, Anti-Jo-1 Polymyositis, Dermatomyositis
p-ANCA/MPO Churg Strauss syndrome
c-ANCA Wegener (Granulomatosis with polyangiitis)

questions.text: A maid is playing with a child by spinning him while holding his hands. A few hours later, the child starts crying, does not use his arm, and does not let anybody touch him. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of a pulled elbow. 

Pulled elbow or nursemaid's elbow refers to the subluxation of the annular ligament over the radial head. The mechanism of injury is through axial traction on the extended and pronated forearm.  This happens when a child is pulled at the wrist to prevent a fall or is picked up from the floor by the hand.

Related Pearl: Important conditions of the elbow:

         Condition    Description      

Tennis elbow

 Lateral epicondylitis involving common extensor origin.

Golfer's elbow

 Medial epicondylitis involving the common flexor-pronator origin.

Baseball pitcher's elbow

Damage to the bones or soft tissue attached around the elbow due to repeated vigorous throwing activities. Hypertrophy of the lower humerus and incongruity of the joint, or loose body formation and osteoarthritis.

Little leaguer's elbow

 Partial avulsion of the medial epicondyle.

Javelin thrower's elbow

 Avulsion of the tip of olecranon due to overarm action.

Student's elbow/Miner's elbow

 Olecranon bursitis.

Pulled elbow/Nurse maid's elbow

 Downward dislocation of the radial head from the annular ligament.

questions.text: A 52-year-old diabetic male patient was found to have open-angle glaucoma and was started on a drug that increases uveoscleral flow. What is the drug given to this patient?
questions.solution:
Latanoprost is a prostaglandin drug, which acts by increasing the uveoscleral outflow and thereby lowers the intraocular pressure. 

Mechanism of action: Latanoprost is a prodrug and gets activated during its passage through the cornea. It acts by stimulating the prostanoid receptors on the ciliary muscles. This leads to the release of matrix metalloproteinases, which increases the uveoscleral outflow.

Topical prostaglandins like latanoprost, travoprost, bimatoprost, and tafluprost are now used as first-line agents to lower IOP. The major mechanism of action is by enhancing the uveoscleral outflow though they also increase trabecular outflow.

The most common ocular side effects are conjunctival hyperemia, eyelash thickening, iris hyperpigmentation, and loss of periorbital fat. These drugs are administered once every day at bedtime and are used with caution in inflamed eyes.

The systemic side effects are uncommon and include occasional headaches, malaise, myalgia, skin rash, and mild upper respiratory infections. Latanoprost is preferred as the first-line due to fewer ocular side effects.

Other options:

Option A: Dorzolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor. It reduces IOP by decreasing aqueous production. 

Option C: Mannitol is an osmotic agent, which lowers IOP by creating an osmotic gradient so that water is pulled from the vitreous into the blood vessels. It is used as a short-term treatment to reduce IOP in acute angle-closure glaucoma or prior to intraocular surgery.

Option D: Pilocarpine is a miotic that acts as a cholinergic agonist. In angle-closure glaucoma, cholinergic agents open the angle by contraction of the sphincter pupillae, pulling the iris away from the trabecula.

Related Pearl: Antiglaucoma drugs: Mechanism of lowering intraocular pressure (IOP) at a glance

Drugs that increase trabecular outflow

  • Miotics (e.g., pilocarpine)
  • Epinephrine, dipivefrine
  • Bimatoprost

Drugs that increase uveoscleral outflow

  • Prostaglandins (latanoprost)
  • Epinephrine, dipivefrine
  • Brimonidine
  • Apraclonidine

Drugs that decrease aqueous production

  • Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (e.g., acetazolamide, dorzolamide)
  • Alpha receptor stimulators in ciliary process (e.g., epinephrine, dipivefrine, clonidine, brimonidine, apraclonidine)
  • Beta-blockers

Hyperosmotic agents - (e.g., glycerol, mannitol, urea)
