questions.text: A baby born at 26 weeks of gestation presented with cyanosis, tachypnea, and grunting 3 hours after birth. Auscultation revealed decreased air entry and bilateral homogenous opacification of the lungs on the chest radiograph. This is likely due to a defect in the synthesis of?
questions.solution:
A preterm baby having respiratory distress along with homogenous opacification of the lungs is suggestive of respiratory distress syndrome which is likely due to a defect in the synthesis of dipalmitoyl lecithin.

Respiratory distress syndrome (RDS), also known as hyaline membrane disease, is due to the decreased production and secretion of the lung surfactant. It is primarily made of phospholipids such as dipalmitoyl lecithin (otherwise known as dipalmitoylphosphatidylcholine). The other minor components are phosphatidylglycerol, apoproteins, and cholesterol. It is synthesized in type II pneumocytes/granular pneumocytes in the endoplasmic reticulum (shown below). 

RDS is commonly seen in preterm babies less than 34 weeks of gestation. Surfactant deficiency leads to an increase in the surface tension over the alveoli causing the alveoli to collapse easily dring expiration. Therefore, the baby has to put more effort to expand the lungs. Tachypnea, cyanosis, nasal flaring, prominent expiratory grunting, and intercostal and subcostal retractions are some of the common findings seen in this condition. 

Chest X-ray shows features such as reticulogranular pattern, ground-glass opacity, and air bronchogram. White-out lungs can be seen on chest X-ray in severe disease.

Management in mild to moderate RDS is with continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) where the positive pressure keeps the alveoli open in a spontaneously breathing baby. Severe cases will require mechanical ventilation. Steroids increase the production of the surfactant and therefore steroids are administered antenatally to mothers with preterm labour.

questions.text: A 32 year old hypertensive male underwent a whole body check up. Which of the following is most likely associated with the condition seen in this CT image of this patient?
questions.solution:
Berry aneurysm is commonly associated with polycystic kidney disease. The CT shows the presence of multiple cysts in the kidney. This CT finding along with the age of the patient is suggestive of autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease.

ADPKD is inherited as an autosomal dominant trait with mutations in the PKD1(chromosome 16) and PKD2 genes (chromosome 4). 

The disease does not usually manifest before 30 years of age, and in some patients, it is never diagnosed. The progression of the disease is faster in males. 

Hypertension is the most common presentation. Renal manifestations of ADPKD include:

  • Flank/loin pain -  either due to hemorrhage inside cysts or due to renal stones (most commonly uric acid stones)
  • Irregular upper quadrant renal mass
  • Hematuria
  • Uremia
  • Renal failure (seen in 10–15% of the patients who receive hemodialysis)

The most common extrarenal manifestation is hepatic cysts, which are derived from the biliary epithelium. Other extra-renal manifestations of ADPKD:

  • Pancreatic cysts
  • Berry aneurysms (Rupture of cerebral aneurysms is an important cause of morbidity and The prevalence of intracranial aneurysms in patients with PKD is 40%.)
  • Colonic diverticula
  • Abdominal hernias
  • Mitral valve prolapse 

Rupture of cerebral aneurysms is an important cause of morbidity and mortality in patients with adult polycystic kidney disease (PKD).

The prevalence of intracranial aneurysms in patients with PKD is 40%. Screening cerebral angiography is strongly considered in all patients with PKD and a family history of cerebral aneurysm or subarachnoid hemorrhage.

questions.text: Pasteurization is done at  ______.
questions.solution:
Pasteurization: Milk is heated at either 

  • 63°C for 30 minutes: the Holder method or
  • 72°C for 15–20 seconds: the flash process

followed by cooling quickly to 13°C or lower.

All the non-sporing pathogens are killed except Coxiella burnetti, which may survive in Holder method.

Tests to check the efficiency of pasteurization:

  • Phosphatase test
  • Standard plate count
  • Coliform count

Methods of pasteurization:

  • Holder/Vat method: 63-66 °C for 30 minutes
  • HTST method (High temp short time): 72°C for 15 seconds
  • UHT method (Ultra-high temp): 125 °C for a few seconds

questions.text: The following ultrasound image signifies:
questions.solution:
The sign is double decidual sign, seen in normal pregnancy, depicting a normal gestational sac.

In the image, the empty head red arrow points to the concentric double rings that is outer decidua parietalis and inner decidua capsularis.

The filled head red arrow points to the yolk sac.

This sign can be seen in first trimester transvaginal sonogram.

Other options:

a) intrauterine death- Spalding sign.

c)neural tube defects (spine bifida)- lemon sign and banana sign.

d)duodenal atresia- double bubble sign.

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones (indicated by the arrow in the image below) giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: A diabetic patient is diagnosed with hypertension during his annual health check-up. What is the treatment of choice for him?
questions.solution:
ACE inhibitors such as captopril or ARBs can be considered as a treatment of choice in hypertensive patients with diabetes because of the renoprotective action. It benefits diabetic patients by reducing the risk of occurrence and progression of diabetic nephropathy. 

They are also recommended in patients with CKD irrespective of diabetes status as they can delay the progression of nephropathy.

Option A: Thiazide diuretics worsen glycemic control and are not preferred in diabetic patients.

Option B: Beta-blockers, especially non-selective blockers, worsen glycemic control.

Option D: Calcium channel blockers have a neutral effect on glycemic control and can be used in diabetes if ACE inhibitors or ARBs cannot be given.

questions.text: Which of the following helps in bacterial adhesion?
questions.solution:
Fimbriae help in bacterial adhesion.

Fimbriae, also called pili are hair-like surface appendage that projects from the cell surface as straight filaments. Fimbriae are classified based on the function as ordinary pili and sex pili.

Functions of pili:

  • Bacterial adhesion of symbiotic and pathogenic bacteria to host cells using adhesins.
  • Resistance to phagocytosis.
  • Antigenic pilin proteins are responsible for the immune response.
  • Twitching motility to bacteria.
  • Bacterial conjugation through sex pili, which transfer of genetic material occurs.

questions.text: You are an intern in the emergency room. You have just performed defibrillation on a patient with ventricular fibrillation. According to the ACLS guidelines, what should be your next step?
questions.solution:
Chest compressions should be resumed immediately following shock delivery.

Pulse check and reanalysis of the cardiac rhythm is performed only after 2 minutes of chest compression and rescue breaths. This is because the heart is temporarily stunned by a defibrillator shock and so chest compressions would benefit the patient by providing coronary blood flow during this period.

Defibrillation involves delivering an electrical current between two pads placed on the chest so as to interrupt disorganized cardiac activity and restore an organized cardiac rhythm or asystole for at least 5 seconds. It is of utmost necessity to defibrillate immediately because the chances of survival decrease by 7-10% every minute without defibrillation.

If after 2 minutes, the rhythm remains the same, then another shock is delivered. Chest compression and rescue breaths are resumed and 1 mg epinephrine is administered. Consideration is given for an advanced airway placement.

If after 2 minutes the rhythm still remains the same, the first dose of amiodarone 300mg bolus is given.

With the next cycle of CPR, a shock is delivered and 1 mg of epinephrine is given. And with the cycle of CPR after that, shock is delivered and the second dose of amiodarone- 150mg is given

questions.text: Axillary artery is divided into 3 parts by:
questions.solution:
The axillary artery is divided into 3 parts by the pectoralis minor muscle.

The axillary artery is the continuation of the subclavian artery. It extends from the outer border of 1st rib to the lower border of Teres Major.

Pectoralis Minor divides the artery into 3 parts.

  Relation to Pectoralis minor Branches
1st part Lies proximally Superior thoracic artery
2nd part Lies posteriorly Thoracoacromial trunk
3rd part Lies laterally

Subscapular artery

Anterior circumflex humeral artery

Posterior circumflex humeral artery

questions.text: An anxious patient with a black mole over his back presents to the clinic for evaluation. All of the following features according to the ABCDE rule will point towards a diagnosis of melanoma in this patient except?
questions.solution:
D stands for diameter >6 mm and not depth > 6mm.

Melanoma:

The ABCDE of Melanoma consists of the rules for the examination of a nevus to assess its malignant potential:

A : Asymmetry

  • Melanoma lesions are irregular, or not symmetrical, in shape.

B : Border irregular

  • Melanoma lesions usually have irregular borders that are ill defined.

C : Color variegation

  • The presence of multiple colors (blue, black, brown, tan, etc.) or the uneven distribution of color.

D : Diameter >6 mm

  • Melanoma lesions are often greater than 6 millimeters in diameter (approximately the size of a pencil eraser).

E : Evolution

  • There is a change in the size, shape, symptoms (such as itching or tenderness), surface (especially bleeding), or color of a mole.

questions.text: The insect shown below is a vector for a disease that is targeted under the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme. Identify the disease.
questions.solution:
The image shows a mosquito with a horizontal body and no stripes on the wings suggestive of the Culex species of mosquitoes, which is a vector for Japanese encephalitis and Bancroftian filariasis. 

Mansonia species is the vector for Malayan filariasis.

Related Pearl: The Mosquito

The mosquito as a vector:

  • Mosquitoes are global in distribution.
  • The main species of mosquitoes include the Anopheles, Culex, Aedes and Mansonia.
  • Flight range varies up to 11 kms, except Aedes for which it is 100 metres.
  • Life span of mosquitoes is around 8 to 34 days.
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a proboscis, a pair of palpi and a pair of antennae; a thorax and an abdomen.

Charateristics:

Characteristics Anopheles Culex Aedes Mansonia
EggsUsually 100-250. This stage lasts 1 – 2 days. Laid singly; boat-shaped with lateral floats. Laid in clusters or rafts. Laid singly. Laid in star shaped clusters.
Larval stageThis stage lasts for 5 -7 days.

No siphon tube.

Lies parallel to undersurface of water.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.
Adults Wings spotted. Wings unspotted. Wings unspotted. Stripped body. Wings unspotted.
Breeding areas Clean water Dirty and polluted water Artifical collections of water Water bodies containing aquatic vegetation
Diseases Malaria, filaria Bancroftian filariasis, Japanese encephalitis, West Nile fever, viral arthritis. Yellow fever, dengue, DHF, chikungunya, rift valley fever, filariasis,Zika virus Malayan filariasis
Comments Anopheline mosquitoes tend to sit with their heads low and their rear ends raised high, especially when feeding. 
  • Called "Nuisance mosquitoes"
  • These culicine female mosquitoes keep their bodies horizontal while feeding.

Called as tiger mosquitoes and they are day biters

They get the"tiger" name from white stripes  on its legs.

 Mansonia mosquitoes are big, black or brown mosquitoes with sparkling on their wings and legs. 

 

 

  • Culex mosquito, they keep their bodies horizontal while feeding:

 

  • Anopheles mosquito as seen in the image below, they tend to sit at an angle, with their heads low and their rear ends raised high:

 

  • Aedes mosquito (aegypti), as seen in the image below, their bodies are striped:

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents to you with the following lesion over the eye.  All the following statements regarding this condition are true except:

choices.text: It is usually a stationary condition
Associated with deposition of amorphous hyaline material in the conjunctiva
Temopral side is affected first and then the nasal side
There is elastotic degeneration of collagen fibres of conjunctiva

questions.solution:
The image shows pinguecula, which affects the nasal side first and then the temporal side.

Pinguecula is a degenerative condition of the conjunctiva, characterized by the formation of a yellowish-white patch on the bulbar conjunctiva near the limbus.

Features:

  • Usually found in elderly people, especially those exposed to strong sunlight, dust, wind, etc.
  • There is an elastotic degeneration of collagen fibres of the substantia propria of the conjunctiva, coupled with deposition of amorphous hyaline material in the substance of conjunctiva.
  • It is a stationary condition

Complications of pinguecula include its inflammation, intraepithelial abscess formation and rarely calcification.

No treatment is required. When inflamed, it is treated with topical steroid.

questions.text: A patient, known case of osteoarthritis is keen on taking the Kellgren and Lawrence scoring test. This scoring system is based on which of the following?
questions.solution:
The Kellgren and Lawrence scoring system uses radiographic changes (X-rays) to divide OA into five categories.

It is the most commonly used system.

  • Grade 0: no radiographic features of OA are present
  • Grade 1: doubtful joint space narrowing (JSN) and possible osteophytic lipping
  • Grade 2: definite osteophytes and possible JSN on anteroposterior weight-bearing radiograph
  • Grade 3: multiple osteophytes, definite JSN, sclerosis, possible bony deformity
  • Grade 4: large osteophytes, marked JSN, severe sclerosis and definite bony deformity 

Other radiological classification systems include Ahlbäck radiographic classification for knee OA.

The Outerbridge classification is based on cartilage damage as observed by arthroscopy.

questions.text: A person wants to study about the relationship between smoking and lung cancer, so he collects data about people diseased with lung cancer from government hospitals and the number of cigarette packets sold at the same time period. Which type of study is this?
questions.solution:
The type of study described is an ecological study as the unit of study is the population. The number of cigarette packets sold at the same time is data about the population.

Option A: The unit of study in a cross-sectional study is an individual.

Option C: There is no experiment done here. Hence, it is not experimental study.

Option D: Quasi-experiments are nonrandomized, pre-post intervention studies done when it is not feasible or ethical to conduct a randomized controlled trial. The unit of study is therefore patients or individuals and not population.

Related Pearl: Types of Epidemiological Study Designs

Types of Epidemiological Study Designs

The flow chart below gives a glance into the types of epidemiological study designs and where they are generally used.

Note: Descripitve study is used to formulate aetiological hypothesis of a disease. Whereas analytical study is used to test the hypothesis (i.e to accept or reject the hypothesis).

questions.text: All of the following are pillars of primary health care except:
questions.solution:
Health education is an element of primary health care, not a pillar.

Related Pearl: Elements and Principles of Primary Health Care

A. Elements of Primary Health Care

(Mnemonic: ELEMENTS)

  • Education about health problems and their prevention and control
  • Locally endemic diseases – prevention and control
  • Essential drugs
  • Maternal and child health care
  • Expanded programme of immunization against vaccine preventable diseases
  • Nutrition and proper food supply
  • Treatment of common diseases and injuries
  • Safe water and sanitation

B. Principles/Pillars of Primary Health Care

  • Equitable distribution
  • Community participation
  • Intersectoral coordination
  • Appropriate technology

questions.text: A surgeon was performing a laparoscopic cholecystectomy. He accidentally ligated the common hepatic artery. This will impair blood supply in:

choices.text: Right  gastric and right gastroepiploic artery
Right gastric and left gastric artery
Right gastroepiploic and short gastric vessels
Right gastric and short gastric vessels

questions.solution:
Ligation of the common hepatic artery will cause impairment in the blood supply through its branches i.e. right gastric artery and right gastroepiploic artery.

Blood supply of the stomach:

The arterial supply of the stomach is contributed exclusively by the branches of the celiac trunk. They are:

  • Left gastric artery - Supplies the lesser curvature of the stomach
  • Splenic artery- This further divides into:
    • Short gastric arteries- Supplies the fundus of the stomach
    • Left gastroepiploic artery- Supplies the greater curvature of the stomach
  • Common hepatic artery, which gives the following branches
    • Right gastric artery- Supplies the lesser curvature of the stomach
    • Gastroduodenal artery- The right gastroepiploic artery arises from this and supplies the greater curvature of the stomach.

questions.text: All of the following isotopes are used for thyroid imaging except:
questions.solution:
Iodine 127 is the stable isotope and does not emit radiation, so is not useful for thyroid imaging.

Iodine-123: A radioactive isotope used for diagnostic imaging. Emits gamma rays and has a short half-life (~13 hours), and provides detailed imaging with minimal radiation exposure.

Iodine-131: A radioactive isotope used for both imaging and therapeutic purposes. Emits both beta and gamma rays, with a longer half-life (~8 days), making it suitable for treating hyperthyroidism and thyroid cancer.

Tc 99m pertechnetate is also used for thyroid imaging. It is a radioactive tracer that provides valuable information about thyroid function and structure. Tc-99m pertechnetate is actively taken up by the thyroid gland through the sodium-iodide symporter (similar to iodine). However, unlike iodine, it is not incorporated into thyroid hormones. Tc-99m has a half-life of about 6 hours, minimizing radiation exposure.

questions.text: A newborn is brought with evisceration of bowel loops from a defect in the abdominal wall to the right of the umbilicus. The most probable diagnosis is
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis for the evisceration of bowel loops, coming out of a defect in the abdominal wall to the right of the umbilicus is gastroschisis. It occurs when there is a failure in the closure of the body wall in the abdominal region.

The defects seen in the ventral body wall include:

  • Gastroschisis: The intestinal loops herniate through the defect in the abdominal wall. The defect usually lies to one side of the umbilicus (right side commonly). The loops of the bowel are not covered by amnion as they herniate through the abdominal wall directly into the amniotic cavity. The affected bowel loops can be damaged by exposure to amniotic fluid.
  • Omphalocele: The bowel loops fail to return from the physiologic umbilical hernia. Since the umbilicus is covered by a reflection of the amnion, the omphalocele is also covered by amnion.
  • Congenital umbilical hernia: This is due to a failure of the umbilical ring to close after physiologic herniation of the intestines.

Related Pearl: Difference between gastroschisis and omphalocele

Characteristic Gastroschisis Omphalocele
Defect size (diameter) 2-3 cm 2-15 cm
Sac Never Always, may be ruptured
Gestational age Prematurity Term
Umbilical cord Adjacent to the defect (defect is seen usually on its right side)  Attached to sac
Herniated viscera Small bowel, stomach, colon Small bowel, stomach, colon, liver
Malrotation Yes Yes
Bowel character Inflammatory, edematous Normal
Enternal nutrition Delayed Normal
Associated abnormalities Uncommon (10% atresia) Common (50%)

questions.text: All are normal physiological changes in pregnancy except:

choices.text: Mild ST changes in inferior leads

questions.solution:
Pansystolic murmur is not a physiological change in pregnancy.

Physiological changes in pregnancy:

Clinical examination

  • Jugular venous distension and venous hum
  • Mammary soufflé: Continuous murmur at 2nd to 4th intercostal space
  • Occasional S3at Mitral area
  • Aortic or pulmonary flow murmurs at aortic/pulmonary areas
  • S2 P increased; S2 split
  • S1 M increased and widely split

Electrocardiography

  • T wave inversion, biatrial enlargement
  • Dysrhythmias
  • As the diaphragm is elevated in advancing pregnancy, there is an average 15-degree left-axis deviation in the electrocardiogram (ECG), and mild ST changes may be seen in the inferior leads.
  • Atrial and ventricular premature contractions are relatively frequent
  • Pregnancy does not alter voltage
  • Tricuspid regurgitation
  • Increased left atrial end-diastolic dimension and
  • Increased left ventricular mass

Other options:

Option A: There is an average 15-degree left-axis deviation in the electrocardiogram (ECG) as the diaphragm is elevated in advancing pregnancy.

Option B: Mild ST changes may be seen in the inferior leads.

Option C: Atrial and ventricular premature contractions are relatively frequent

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy was brought to the OPD with fever and swelling of hands after playing football. He gives a history of previous episodes of swelling of hands. On imaging, his spleen was found to be shrunken. Which of the following is a likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The finding of dactylitis along with the shrunken spleen is suggestive of sickle cell disease.

In sickle cell disease, repeated splenic micro-infarcts cause loss of splenic function and shrinkage. Vaso-occlusion causes hand-foot syndrome with painful infarction of the digits and dactylitis.

Sickle cell anemia is an autosomal recessive disorder that occurs due to the point mutation in the β-globin gene, which results in the replacement of glutamate residue with valine. This causes the production of sickle-shaped red blood cells due to the polymerization of deoxygenated hemoglobin (HbS).

Factors that predispose to sickling are infection, dehydration, and acidosis.

The clinical features of sickle cell disease are due to the tendency of HbS molecules to stack into polymers when deoxygenated.

Clinical features:

  • Moderately severe hemolytic anemia with jaundice
  • Painful bone crisis - hand-foot syndrome or dactylitis of the bones of hands and feet.
  • Acute chest syndrome - Typically presents with fever, cough, chest pain, and pulmonary infiltrates.
  • Hyposthenuria- inability to concentrate urine.
  • The aplastic crisis stems from the infection of red cell progenitors by parvovirus B19, which causes a transient cessation of erythropoiesis and a sudden worsening of the anemia.
  • Spleen
    • In children- splenic sequestration crises occur which results in splenomegaly due to red pulp congestion.
    •         Adolescence or early adulthood- autosplenectomy occurs due to splenic infarction, fibrosis, and progressive shrinkage.
    • Increased susceptibility to infection with encapsulated organisms like pneumococcal, meningococcal, and Haemophilus influenzae septicemia, but can be reduced by vaccination and prophylactic antibiotics.
  • Other clinical features- priapism, leg ulcers, stroke, retinopathy, pigment gallstones, and growth retardation.

The diagnosis is suggested by the clinical findings, the presence of irreversibly sickled red cells on the peripheral smear, and hemoglobin electrophoresis showing increased HbA2 and HbF and S spike. The changes in the skull resemble a crewcut in radiographic studies as a result of compensatory erythroid hyperplasia.

Other manifestations include:

  • Acute splenic sequestration due to venous obstruction, needing emergency transfusion/splenectomy
  • Painful ischemic crises due to vaso-occlusion in connective and musculoskeletal tissue
  • Renal papillary necrosis leading to isosthenuria
  • Cerebrovascular strokes
  • Chronic lower leg ulcers
  • Priapism in males

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presented with blurred vision. A urine examination showed proteinuria. Fundus examination showed dot and blot hemorrhages, microaneurysms, and cotton wool spots. The histopathology of the kidney is shown below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and histopathology image showing acellular periodic acid Schiff (PAS)-positive nodules are suggestive of Kimmelstiel–Wilson disease. It occurs in patients with diabetic nephropathy.

The following renal lesions are encountered in diabetic nephropathy:

  • Glomerular lesions -
    • Capillary basement membrane thickening
    • Diffuse mesangial sclerosis
    • Nodular glomerulosclerosis/ Kimmelstiel–Wilson disease
    • Intercapillary glomerulosclerosis
  • Renal vascular lesions - hyaline arteriolosclerosis
  • Pyelonephritis - necrotizing papillitis

Other options:

Option A: In Renal amyloidosis, glomerular deposits appear as thickenings of the mesangial matrix, forming interlacing broad ribbons of amyloid

Option B: In focal segmental glomerulosclerosis, there is focal and segmental hyalinosis and sclerosis of the capillary wall with lipid droplets in the sclerosed area.

Option D: In lupus nephritis, immune complex deposits are seen in the mesangium or along the entire basement membrane (wire loop lesions), with mesangial cell proliferation.

questions.text:
The image below illustrates a therapeutic modality for vitiligo. Which of the following are contraindications to this therapeutic modality?
  1. Dysplastic naevus syndrome
  2. Atopic eczema
  3. Systemic lupus erythematosus
  4. Dermatomyositis
  5. Psoriasis
questions.solution:
The given image shows Phototherapy being used as a treatment modality.

Phototherapy (light therapy) refers to the administration of non‐ionizing radiation (most commonly UV radiation) in a controlled manner to the skin for the treatment of certain skin conditions.

The UVB part of the spectrum is defined as that between 280 and 320 nm and the UVA spectrum is between 320 and 400 nm. UVA is used in combination with an oral or topical psoralen photosensitizer and is known as photochemotherapy (PUVA). UVB phototherapy is preferred to PUVA due to a lower risk of skin cancer.

Absolute contraindications to phototherapy include:

  • Dysplastic naevus syndrome
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus
  • Dermatomyositis
  • Genetic skin cancer syndromes (xeroderma pigmentosum, Gorlin syndrome)
  • Severe cardiovascular or respiratory disease

Indications of PUVA therapy

  • Psoriasis
  • Atopic eczema
  • Vitiligo
  • Polymorphic light eruption(for desensitisation)
  • Cutaneous T cell lymphoma

questions.text: A farmer presents with a warty cutaneous growth on his foot. Histopathology is as shown below. Which of the following is a likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient is likely a case of chromoblastomycosis with sclerotic bodies seen on histopathology examination

It is a subcutaneous infection caused by fungi belonging to the genera fonsecaea. It enters the skin by traumatic inoculation. Hence, seen in woodcutter and farmers. It appears as sclerotic bodies on histopathology examination and copper penny bodies on KOH mount. Treatment with antifungals are given.

Other options:

Mycetoma:

  • It is caused by various types of Fungi (Eumycetoma) or filamentous bacteria (actinomycetes).
  • It presents with a painless nodule but with time, papules and pustules may form which breaks down to form draining sinuses, with the discharge of granules.

Image: Mycetoma of Foot.

Sporotrichosis: Nodules generally develop along the draining lymphatics.

Phaeohyphomycosis : it is a chronic fungal infection involving the skin and subcutaneous tissue. The lesions maybe plaques which are verrucous, hypertkeratotis or ulcerated. The fungi implicated are usually of the class Phialophora or Cladophora or other demetacious fungi.

questions.text: Condition favourable for adipocere formation is _________

choices.text: Hot weather and dry air currents

questions.solution:
Warm and humid weather is a favourable condition for adipocere formation.

Adipocere formation, also called corpse wax, grave wax, or mortuary wax, is a late sign of death. A wax-like organic substance is formed by the anaerobic hydrolysis or hydrogenation of fat in tissues. It has a greyish-white appearance with a distinctive offensive or sweetish smell. The usual time for adipocere formation is between 3 to 6 months, but in countries like India, it is accelerated by the warm and humid weather, resulting in the beginning of adipocere formation as early as 3 to 15 days after death. 

Prerequisites for adipocere formation:

  • Abundant fat
  • Moisture
  • Still air
  • Warm temperature
  • Bacteria producing fat splitting enzyme like Clostridium welchii

Postmortem changes are classified on the basis of time:

  • Immediate signs of death (at the time of somatic or clinical death):
    1. Insensibility and loss of voluntary power
    2. Cessation of respiration
    3. Cessation of circulation
  • Early signs of death (cellular death that is observed in the first 12 to 24 hours of death):
    1. Pallor and loss of elasticity of the skin
    2. Eye changes
    3. Primary flaccidity of muscles
    4. Algor mortis/Postmortem cooling
    5. Postmortem lividity/Suggillation
    6. Rigor mortis
  • Late signs of death:
    1. Putrefaction
    2. Adipocere
    3. Mummification

questions.text: A 35-year-old lady who had tested positive for HPV  is undergoing an investigation where the following device is used. Which of the following statements is false about this investigation?

choices.text: It is used in lithotomy position
Green filter is used to study vascular pattern
External os is visualised at a distance of 50 cm

questions.solution:
The device shown in the image is a colposcope. It is used to perform colposcopy where the cervix is visualized at a distance of around 20 cm with the patient in the lithotomy position.

This instrument provides binocular vision with a magnification of 6x-15x. A green filter is used to study vascular pattern as the vessels appear black. Abnormal areas can be identified by their peculiar vascular pattern such as mosaic, reticular, and punctate.

questions.text: A person who met with an accident, and suffered from a skull fracture presents with the following finding. Identify this clinical finding.
questions.solution:
The image shows Battle's sign.

It is retroauricular or mastoid ecchymosis that typically results from fracture of middle cranial fossa following head trauma. Battle sign is prominent when there is a fracture of the petrous temporal bone. 

Signs in basilar skull fractures:

  • Hemotympanum: Pooling of blood behind the tympanic membrane, associated with fracture of the temporal bone. It is one of the earliest signs of basilar fracture.
  • Periorbital ecchymosis (raccoon eyes): Pooling of blood surrounding the eyes, associated with fractures of the anterior cranial fossa. 
  • Retroauricular or mastoid ecchymosis (Battle sign): Pooled blood behind the ears in the mastoid region is associated with fractures to the middle cranial fossa. 
  • CSF rhinorrhea or otorrhea: Double target sign, a double-ring pattern described with CSF-containing bloody fluid from the ear or nose, when dripped onto paper or linen.

Battle sign and raccoon eyes are both typically not present during the initial evaluation and are delayed by 6 hrs up to 3 days after head injury.

CSF leaks may be delayed hours to days after the initial trauma. Fluid suspicious for CSF is confirmed by testing for β2 transferrin. Most CSF leaks are conservatively managed. Persistent leaks >7 days have a heightened risk of meningitis and are often surgically repaired.

Nasopharyngeal airways and nasogastric tube insertion are relatively contraindicated in basilar skull fractures due to the risk of intracranial placement. Noninvasive Positive Pressure Ventilation (NIPPV) is avoided due to the risk of pneumocephalus. 

Other options:

Option B: Bezold abscess is a complication of acute otomastoiditis where the infection extends into the infratemporal fossa.

Option C: Acute mastoiditis is used to refer to an acute infection that spreads from the mucosa lining the mastoid air cells to involve the bony walls of the mastoid air cell system. Mastoiditis presents as retro-auricular redness and swelling which is painful. 

The image below shows a smooth ironed-out mastoid with erythema seen in acute mastoiditis.

Option D: The Griesinger's sign refers to edema of the postauricular soft tissues overlying the mastoid process as a result of thrombosis of the mastoid emissary vein. It is a complication of acute otomastoiditis.

questions.text: All of the following diseases are transmitted by the vector shown in the image except:
questions.solution:
Scrub typhus is not caused by the vector shown in the image (tick).

The vector shown is a hard tick and transmits tick typhus, viral encephalitis (e.g., Russian spring-summer encephalitis), viral fevers (e.g., Colorado tick fever), viral hemorrhagic fevers (e.g. KFD in India), tularemia, tick paralysis, and babesiosis.

The following image shows a soft tick.

Scrub typhus is transmitted by trombiculid mite which is as shown below.

Related Pearl: Ticks

  • The two types of ticks are the hard ticks and soft ticks.
  • General morphology of ticks includes an oval shaped body, four pairs of legs and no antennae.
  Hard tick Soft tick
Scutum A chitinous shield that covers the entire back in males. Females have a small portion in front. Absent.
Head Situated at anterior end. Lies on the underside of the body, ventrally. Not visible from above.
Spiracles Situated behind coxa IV. Situated between III and IV coxa.
Eggs Several hundred/thousands laid at once Laid in batches of 20 – 100 over a long period
Nymphal stages One Five
Habits Can’t stand starvation; feed night and day. Can stand starvation for more than a year.
Vectors for Tick typhus, viral encephalitis, viral fevers, tularemia, Kyasanur forest disease, babesiosis, tick paralysis. Ixodes type transmits Lyme disease. Q fever(reservoir), relapsing fever.
Life span Short Longer
Habits Always found on their hosts. They hide in cracks and crevices during the day and come out to feed during the night.
  • Insecticidal control of ticks includes DDT, chlordane, dieldrin, lindane, malathion and toxaphone. Environmental control and protection of workers must also be done to prevent disease transmission from ticks.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with AV block?
questions.solution:
Hypothyroidism is associated with AV block.

Causes of AV block:

Autonomic:

  • Carotid sinus hypersensitivity

Metabolic:

  • Hyperkalemia
  • Hypermagnesemia
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Adrenal insufficiency

Drug related:

  • Beta blockers
  • Calcium channel blockers
  • Adenosine
  • Digitalis
  • Lithium
  • Class 1 and class 3 anti arrhythmics

Infections:

  • Endocarditis
  • Lyme disease
  • Chaga's disease
  • Syphilis
  • Tuberculosis
  • Diphtheria
  • Toxoplasmosis

Inflammatory:

  • SLE
  • RA
  • Scleroderma

Infiltrative:

  • Amyloidosis
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Hemachromatosis

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl presented to OPD  with multiple pigmented papular lesions on her face, neck, and forearm and corneal injection following exposure to the sun. Which DNA repair mechanism is defective in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture and the history is suggestive of Xeroderma pigmentosum. The DNA repair mechanism that is defective in this condition is  Nucleotide Excision Repair (NER).

Xeroderma Pigmentosum (XP) is a rare autosomal recessive genetic disorder characterized by defective DNA repair which leads to clinical and cellular hypersensitivity to ultraviolet radiation and other carcinogenic agents.

The given image shows hyperkeratotic lesions with some induration suspicious of actinic keratosis and early squamous cell carcinoma. Also numerous hyper-pigmented lentigos and xerosis on the entire front of the face.

questions.text: In order to reach the demographic goal of NRR=1, the couple protection rate should exceed?
questions.solution:
In order to reach the demographic goal of NRR=1, the couple protection rate (CPR) should exceed 60%. This coincides with every couple having 2 children.

Net reproduction rate (NRR) is defined as the number of daughters a newborn girl will bear during her lifetime assuming fixed age-specific fertility and mortality rate. India is aiming for an NRR of 1 as it is equivalent to the two-child norm. 

CPR measures the prevalence of contraceptive use in eligible couples, who are currently married and the wife is in the reproductive age group of 15 to 45 years.  It is defined as the percentage of eligible couples effectively protected against childbirth by one or the other approved methods of family planning like sterilization, IUD, oral pills or condoms. Sterilization is considered the most effective form of contraception. It accounts for over 60% of effectively protected couples.

Related Pearl: Pearl index and couple protection rate:

Pearl Index is defined as the number of contraceptive failures per 100 woman-years of exposure (HWY).

  • In this formula, the total accidental pregnancies that are used as the numerator must include every known conception, irrespective of its outcome.
  • In the denominator, total months of exposure is obtained by deducting, 10 months for full-term deliveries and 4 months for abortion, from the total period under review.

Couple Protection Rate:

  • It is an indicator of couple protection practice in the community.
  • It is defined as the percentage of eligible couples effectively protected against childbirth by one or the other approved methods of family planning.
  • Attaining a 60% CPR would mean restricting all third or higher-order births.

Related Pearl: Fertility Indicators

Crude birth rate

  • It is the simplest measure of fertility although its usage is unsatisfactory
  • India, as per SRS bulletin 2018, had a birth rate of 20.0 per 1000 population

General Fertility Rate

  • It is a better indicator of fertility than crude birth rate
  • The demerit of this indicator is that not all women in the denominator are exposed to childbirth

Age-specific fertility rates is a more precise measure of fertility and is also a sensitive indicator of family planning achievement.

Total Fertility Rate

  • It is the sum of all age-specific fertility rates multiplied by 5
  • This measure gives the approximate magnitude of completed family size

Gross Reproductive Rate is the average number of girls that would be born to a woman if she experiences the current fertility pattern throughout her reproductive span, assuming no mortality.

Net Reproduction Rate

  • It is a demographic indicator
  • NRR of 1 is equivalent to approximately the 2 child norm
  • If the NRR is less than 1, then the reproductive performance of the population is said to be inadequate

questions.text: The remnants of Wolffian ducts in females are located in________.
questions.solution:
The Gartner's duct is a remnant of the Wolffian ducts in women. These are located in the broad ligament and the vagina.

The remnants of Wolffian ducts (Gartner's duct) in females are located in the broad ligament and vagina. It is an imperfect duct that runs below and parallel to the fallopian tube in the mesosalpinx. The duct passes downwards by the side of the uterus until the internal os, after which it passes into the cervix. It then runs forwards, reaching the anterolateral part of the vaginal wall.

Gartner's duct cysts are located in the vagina or broad ligament. They are usually asymptomatic and found within the lateral vaginal wall during a routine examination. Symptoms if present, might include dyspareunia, pain, and difficulty inserting tampons. Examination reveals a tense cyst, seen bulging from beneath the vaginal wall.

Differentials include epidermoid cysts, Bartholin's gland cyst, uterine prolapse, cystocele, rectocele, urethral diverticula.

Treatment is observation in most cases. Marsupialization or excision may be done if large and symptomatic.

Related Pearl: Homologous structures in male and female genitalia

questions.text: You are counseling a diabetic patient to consume foods with low glycemic index. Which of the following would you advise him to eat?
questions.solution:
The patient should be advised to eat whole grains since it has low glycemic index (GI).

GI is a number representing the relative ability of a carbohydrate food to increase the level of glucose in the blood. It is calculated by comparing the test carbohydrate to the standard (glucose or white bread). This measure has practical use in the management of diabetes and obesity.

  • Low GI foods – most fruits and vegetables, whole grains, pasta foods, beans, and lentils
  • Moderate GI foods – sucrose, basmati rice, and brown rice
  • High GI foods – corn flakes, baked potatoes, white bread, potatoes, watermelon and sweet corn, candies and syrupy foods

questions.text: Which type of aphasia is seen in the lesions of the posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus?
questions.solution:
Fluent aphasia is seen in the lesions of the posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus due to the involvement of the Wernicke's area. The speech is full of jargon and neologisms that make little sense.

Lesions in the categorical hemisphere lead to

  1. Broca's aphasia is caused due to an injury in the inferior frontal gyrus. It causes nonfluent aphasia. Affected individuals have slow speech and difficulty in generating verbal or written words.
  2. Wernicke's aphasia is caused due to a lesion in the posterior end of the superior temporal gyrus. It produces a type of fluent aphasia in which speech itself is normal but it is full of jargon and neologisms that make little sense. The patient also fails to comprehend the meaning of spoken or written words, so other aspects of the use of language are compromised.
  3. Anomic aphasia- When a lesion damages the angular gyrus in the categorical hemisphere without affecting Wernicke or Broca areas, there is no difficulty with speech or the understanding of auditory information. But there is trouble understanding written language or pictures because visual information is not processed and transmitted to the Wernicke area.
  4. Global aphasia- In this, both understanding and speaking is impaired. It is also non-fluent aphasia.
  5. Acalculia- Impairment of mathematical ability. Occurs due to an impairment to the left frontal lobe.

Option B: Broca's or motor/non-fluent aphasia is seen in lesions of the inferior frontal gyrus which contains the motor speech area. Speech is non-fluent and interrupted, with a paucity of functional words.

Option C: Comprehension of written language and the ability to name objects are compromised in anomic aphasia. This aphasia is caused by damage to the angular gyrus that disrupts visual information processing and transmission to the Wernicke area.

Option D: Conduction aphasia is seen in lesions of the arcuate fasciculus, the bundle of nerve fibers connecting the Wernicke and Broca's areas. Repetition of words is impaired and paraphasias are observed, though not as much as in Wernicke aphasia.

Related Pearl: Aphasias and Related Conditions

  Comprehension Repetition of Spoken language Naming Fluency
Wernicke's Impaired Impaired Impaired Preserved
Broca's Preserved Impaired Impaired Decreased
Global Impaired Impaired Impaired Decreased
Conduction Preserved Impaired Impaired Preserved
Anterior (nonfluent) transcortical Preserved Preserved Impaired Impaired
Posterior (fluent) transcortical Impaired Preserved Impaired Preserved
Isolation Impaired Echolalia Impaired No purposeful speech
Anomic Preserved Preserved Impaired Preserved except for word finding pauses
Pure Word Deafness Impaired only for spoken language Impaired Preserved Preserved
Pure Alexia Impaired only for reading Preserved Preserved  Preserved

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl presented with cyclical abdominal pain and a midline hypogastric lump. She has not achieved menarche yet. On examination, a bluish bulge is noted on parting the labia. What is the likely cause of her condition?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of an imperforate hymen, which has led to cryptomenorrhoea. This is a condition where menstruation occurs but is not visible due to an obstruction of the outflow tract.

The menstrual fluid gets collected in the reproductive tract. When this collection occurs in the vagina, it is known as hematocolpos. If the collection extends to the uterus, it is known as hematometra. The collection of blood in the fallopian tubes is called hematosalpinx.

The most common causes of cryptomenorrhea are:

  • Intact/imperforate hymen - a bluish convex bulge is seen.
  • Transverse vaginal septum - a pinkish concave covering is seen

Ultrasound pelvis confirms the diagnosis.

Management:

Imperforate hymen - A simple cruciate incision of the hymen allows the free drainage of the collected menstrual blood, and leads to normal reproductive function.

Transverse vaginal septum - Extensive dissection and vaginoplasty is required.

Option A: Bartholin's cyst appears as a swelling on the inner side of the labia majora. Larger cysts can bulge across the introitus. Small cysts can remain asymptomatic.

Option D: Endometriomas are endometriotic lesions seen on the ovary. They present as adnexal masses. Endometriosis is a complication in cryptomenorrhea, due to retrograde menstruation.

questions.text: Graft from identical twin is called:
questions.solution:
A graft from an identical twin is called an isograft.

Isograft is defined as an organ or tissue that is taken from a donor and is transplanted to a recipient who has the same genetic constitution as the donor. For example, graft between identical twins.

Related Pearl: Types of transplants

Type  Definition
Orthotopic

 

Organ implanted in the same anatomic location in the recipient as it was in the donor. 

Diseased organ removed
Heterotopic

Organ implanted in a different anatomic location. 

Diseased organ kept in place.
Autotransplant  Transfer of cells/tissues/organs within the same person. 
Allotransplant Transfer of cells/tissues/organs within the same species. 
Xenotransplant Transfer of cells/tissues/organs in a different species.
Isograft Transfer of organ or tissue within genetically identical individuals. Eg: Identical twins

questions.text: The type of laryngoscope blade shown in the given image is:
questions.solution:
The given image shows Miller laryngoscopic blade.

Miller is a straight blade laryngoscope, used in:

  • Neonates, infants and young children
  • Adults with short thyromental distance and long floppy epiglottis.

Laryngoscopic blades can be

  • Straight blade, Miller
  • Curved blade, Macintosh

Advantage of curved blade:

  • Greater room available for the passage for an endotracheal tube
  • Less damage to the teeth

questions.text: A male patient was brought by his mother concerned about his appearence. The image of the hands of a patient is given below.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image has the characteristic wrist sign i.e. the distal phalange of the first and fifth fingers of the hand overlaps when wrapped around the opposite wrist. This is seen in Marfan's syndrome. This happens as their fingers and hands are long and slender and have a spider-like appearance (arachnodactyly).

The given image has the characteristic wrist sign i.e. the distal phalange of the first and fifth fingers of the hand overlaps when wrapped around the opposite wrist. This is seen in Marfan's syndrome. This happens as their fingers and hands are long and slender and have a spider-like appearance (arachnodactyly). 

Marfan's syndrome is an inherited connective tissue disorder that is caused by a mutation in a gene that codes for an extracellular matrix protein-fibrillin-1 (FBN1). The FBN1 locus is on the long arm of chromosome 15. It is a clinical diagnosis based on skeletal, cardiovascular, and ocular manifestations. 

Features of Marfan's syndrome (Mnemonic: MARFAN’S)

  • Mitral valve prolapse
  • Myopia due to upward dislocation of lens (bilateral ectopic lentis)
  • Aortic root dilatation, Aortic regurgitation
  • Retinal detachment
  • Fibrillin 1 gene defect: Reduced fibrillin 1 production causing joint laxity
  • Fifteen (Chromosome 15 is involved)
  • Flat feet
  • Arachnodactyly, Astigmatism, Air in lungs (Pneumothorax)
  • Nearsightedness
  • Subluxation of lens, Scoliosis, Speech disorders, Sleep apnea

Skeletal manifestations: 

  • Overgrowth of long bones (dolichostenomelia) with an arm span to height ratio of more than 1.05
  • Pectus carinatum or pectus excavatum
  • Long and slender fingers (arachnodactyly), contracture of fingers (camptodactyly)
  • Malar hypoplasia
  • Joint laxity 

Cardiovascular manifestations:

  • Thickened atrioventricular valves, valvular prolapse (mitral regurgitation) 
  • Aortic valve dysfunction due to aortic root aneurysm
  • Aortic dissection and rupture due to cystic medial necrosis of the aorta

Ocular manifestations:

  • ectopia lentis
  • myopia
  • flat cornea
  • retinal detachments
  • early cataracts and glaucoma

Other systemic manifestations: 

  • thoracic scoliosis
  • spontaneous pneumothorax
  • striae atrophicae in the skin

Other options:

  • Ehler Danlos syndrome is characterized by hyperextensible skin and hypermobile joints. However, wrist sign is not a characteristic of EDS.
  • Osteogenesis imperfecta is characterized by a decrease in bone mineral density. Hence, the bones are very fragile limiting the physical activity of the patient.

questions.text: Which of the following is deficient in a patient with features as shown below:
questions.solution:
The image provided is characteristic of Casal's necklace, seen in pellagra, and indicates a deficiency of Tryptophan.

Pellagra can occur due to:

  • Vitamin B3 (niacin)
    • Niacin is derived from tryptophan and needs B2 and B6 for its synthesis.
  • Hartnup's disease (tryptophan malabsorption)
  • Malignant carcinoid syndrome (↑ tryptophan metabolism)
  • Isoniazid (↓ vitamin B6)

In Hartnup's disease, defective membrane transport of tryptophan across PCT and enterocytes leads to malabsorption of tryptophan. This causes a deficiency of tryptophan.

As a result, the production of niacin from tryptophan is reduced and this manifests as pellagra with dermatitis, diarrhea and dementia (3D's) and glossitis. A characteristic skin rash called the Casal’s necklace may also be seen.

Related Pearl: Conditions Associated with Pellagra-like Symptoms

Condition/Disease

Reason for niacin deficiency

Hartnup disease

Intestinal & renal malabsorption of tryptophan

Carcinoid syndrome

Overproduction of serotonin that causes diversion of  tryptophan from NAD+ Pathway

Vitamin B6 deficiency

Defective kynureninase pathway

Maize rich diet

Niacin is in unavailable niacytin form

Jowar diet (Sorghum)

Increase leucine content inhibit QPRTase enzyme

questions.text: An entomologist was studying a vector and the pathogen it transmits. He found that the pathogen underwent changes in number and morphology in the vector. What is this type of biological transmission called?
questions.solution:
This type of biological transmission where a pathogen undergoes a change in number and morphology in a vector is called cyclo-propagative transmission.

Malaria is a disease whose causative organism (Plasmodium sp.) undergoes cyclo-propagative transmission. In malaria, the parasite undergoes both developmental changes and multiplication in the Anopheles mosquito (vector).

Related Pearl: Biological Transmission in Vector-Borne Diseases

1. Propagative

  • The disease agent only multiplies in the vector and there is no change in form.
  • E.g., Plague bacilli in rat fleas.

2. Cyclo-propagative

  • The agent changes in form and in number.
  • E.g., Malarial parasites in mosquitoes.

3. Cyclo-developmental

  • The agent undergoes only developmental changes and not multiplication.
  • E.g., Microfilaria in mosquitoes.

4. Transovarial

  • Infectious agent is transmitted vertically in the vector, from parent to progeny.
  • E.g., Rickettsia rickettsii in ticks.

5. Transstadial

  • The infectious agent stays with the vector from one stage of its life cycle to the next.
  • E.g., Borrelia burgdorferi in ticks.

questions.text: Which of the following dural venous sinuses receives the great cerebral vein of Galen as its tributary?
questions.solution:
The venous sinus marked with 'B' in the given image is the straight sinus. The great cerebral vein of Galen drains into the straight sinus.

The straight sinus is a continuation of the inferior sagittal sinus. It lies in the junction of the falx cerebri with tentorium cerebelli. The straight sinus further drains into one of the transverse sinuses (mostly the left).

Other options

A - Superior sagittal sinus

C - Superior petrosal sinus

D - Sigmoid sinus

Related Pearl: Dural Venous Sinuses

Dural venous sinus Drains into
Unpaired sinuses
Superior sagittal sinus Confluence of sinuses or continues as right transverse sinus
Inferior sagittal sinus joins the great cerebral vein to form the straight sinus
Straight sinus forms the left transverse sinus
Paired sinuses
Occipital sinus Confluence of sinuses
Superior petrosal sinus transverse sinus
Inferior petrosal sinus Internal jugular vein
Transverse sinus continue as sigmoid sinus
Sigmoid sinus continuous with the internal jugular vein
Cavernous sinus Superior and inferior petrosal sinuses

questions.text: The muscle given below passes through the sciatic foramen. Identify the muscle:
questions.solution:
The muscle shown in the image is piriformis.

Origin:

  • The anterior surface of the sacrum
  • The posterior inferior iliac spine
  • The capsule of the sacroiliac joint
  • Sacrotuberous ligament

Insertion: Greater trochanter of the femur.

Action:

  1. Lateral rotation of the thigh in extension
  2. Abduction of the thigh in the flexed position

Clinical note: Piriformis syndrome is a clinical condition characterised by the compression of the sciatic nerve by the piriformis muscle

The following image shows different muscles and of the pelvis and their attachments

Related Pearl: Structures Passing Through the Sciatic Foramen

Structures passing through the Greater Sciatic Foramen

The piriformis, emerging from the pelvis, it fills the foramen almost completely and is the key muscle of the region.

Structures passing above the piriformis

  • Superior gluteal nerve
  • Superior gluteal vessels

Structures passing below the piriformis

  • Inferior gluteal nerve         
  • Inferior gluteal vessels
  • Sciatic nerve                                              
  • Posterior cutaneous nerve of thigh
  • Nerve to quadratus femoris                  
  • Pudendal nerve
  • Internal pudendal vessels                                  
  • Nerve to obturator internus

Note: The last three structures, after a short course in the gluteal region, enter the lesser sciatic foramen, where the pudendal nerve and internal pudendal vessels run in the pudendal canal.

Structures passing through the Lesser Sciatic Foramen

  • Tendon of obturator internus
  • Pudendal nerve
  • Internal pudendal vessels
  • Nerve to obturator internus

questions.text: A child aged 10 years presented with perianal pruritus which is worse in night. Routine stool examination didn't reveal parasite cysts or eggs. The scotch tape method is done to recover eggs which are non-bile stained. Identify the organism causing the infection.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the scotch tape method to collect perianal egg deposition by (Enterobius vermicularis) is  suggestive of infestation with Pinworm 

Characteristics of Pinworm egg:

  • It is colorless, non-bile stained.
  • It floats in the saturated salt solution.
  • The egg is planoconvex. Eggshell is double layered and relatively thick, though transparent.

Since pinworms are not released in feces, the diagnosis cannot be made by conventional fecal ova and parasite tests. NIH swab method and Scotch tape method are used for the collection of specimens.

Scotch tape method involves:

  1. Take a clear cellophane tape almost 4 cm long
  2. Hold it in such a way(or make a loop) so that sticky surface faces upwards or towards the perianal skin.
  3. Place the sticky surface of tap in the perianal area momentarily
  4. Place the sticky surface down on the glass slide. Examine under microscope.

 

Other eggs that can be collected by scotch tape method are Taenia solium, Taenia saginata and Schistosoma mansoni. Which are none of the options in question

Other eggs which are non-bile stained can be remembered as NEHA - Necator americanus, Enterobius vermicularis, Hymenolepsis nana, Ancylostoma duodenale.

questions.text: The following image shows the sequence of propulsion of a bolus in the gut by means of peristalsis. Which of the following substances is responsible for the configuration of the segment of the gut marked as 'B'?
questions.solution:
The part of the gut marked by 'B' is the anterograde segment, which is in a state of relaxation. The vasoactive intestinal peptide is responsible for bringing relaxation in this part of the gut.

The above image shows peristalsis. It is a reflex response that is initiated when the gut wall is stretched by the contents of the lumen. It moves in oral to caudal direction.

Stretching of the gut wall releases serotonin and activates the cholinergic neurons present in the myenteric plexus. Cholinergic neurons passing in anterograde direction produce NO and VIP which cause relaxation of a segment of the intestine in front of the bolus. Cholinergic neurons passing in retrograde direction produce substance P and acetylcholine which cause contraction of a segment of the intestine behind the bolus.

NOTE:

In achalasia cardia, there is decreased release of NO and VIP in the distal part of esophagus.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of peristalsis

questions.text: A 20-year-old female came to OPD with a tingling sensation in her legs and hands. The oral examination shows the following features. Which of the following investigations will be useful in diagnosing the vitamin deficiency seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
RBC glutathione reductase activity will be useful in diagnosing the riboflavin deficiency that this patient has. The image shows cheilosis and angular stomatitis which point towards riboflavin deficiency. The nutritional status of riboflavin can be assessed by measuring the activity of the RBC glutathione reductase.

Deficiency state of riboflavin is characterized by the following signs and symptoms:

  • Cheilosis: pallor in the angle of mouth and fissuring of lips, which extends radially to skin.
  • Glossitis: tongue becomes smooth, loss of papilla (magenta-colored tongue).
  • Eyes: keratitis, conjunctivitis, corneal vascularisation.
  • Other features: Seborrheic dermatitis, anemia.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man was diagnosed with STEMI. He was admitted and given thrombolytic therapy. The next day he complained of palpitations and an ECG was taken. Which of the following drugs can be used to treat his condition?
questions.solution:
The above ECG shows narrow QRS complex, irregular RR intervals, and absent P waves which are suggestive of atrial fibrillation. Among the given options, amiodarone can be administered in patients having atrial fibrillation with coronary or structural heart disease.

Drugs for rhythm control in atrial fibrillation:

In patients without structural heart disease, class I agents are used. Class I agents act by blocking the Na+ channels leading to slower depolarization:

  • Flecainide 
  • Propafenone
  • Disopyramide

In patients with coronary or structural heart disease, class III agents are used. Class III agents act by blocking the K+ channels leading to slower repolarization causing increased refractory period:

  • Amiodarone
  • Dofetilide
  • Sotalol
  • Ibutilide

Other options:

  • Flecainide and Propafenone are a Class IC Anti-arrhythmic drug
  • Drugs used to treat PSVT include oral beta blockers, verapamil, or diltiazem. They are given at the beginning of the episode. If prophylactic therapy is needed, chronic treatment with the same drugs or flecainide can be given.   
  • Adenosine is the preferred agent in the acute termination of an episode of supraventricular tachyarrhythmias since it is fast acting and has a short half life.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is used for the treatment of motion sickness?
questions.solution:
Promethazine is used for motion sickness. It is an antihistaminic agent that acts as an antagonist of H1 receptors. It also has central anticholinergic activity that is responsible for its antiemetic action.

Drugs used in the treatment of motion sickness are:

  • Anticholinergic agents (muscarinic receptor antagonists) such as scopolamine (hyoscine) and dicyclomine.
  • Antihistamines (H1 antagonists) are primarily used for treating motion sickness and postoperative emesis.  

Scopolamine transdermal patches should be given prophylactically as it is less effective once symptoms start. It is applied behind the ear at least 4-12 hours before an anticipated exposure to motion. Dry mouth and sedation are common side effects.

First-generation antihistamines such as promethazine, dimenhydrinate, chlorpheniramine, diphenhydramine, cyclizine, and meclizine are effective in controlling nausea and vomiting in motion sickness. Sedation is a common side effect of these drugs. Second-generation antihistamines like cetirizine and fexofenadine are ineffective in the treatment of motion sickness.

questions.text: Which nerve is involved in Frey’s syndrome?
questions.solution:
The auriculotemporal nerve (V3 nerve) is involved in Frey's syndrome.

Frey’s syndrome is also known as Dupuy syndrome or auriculotemporal syndrome. It commonly develops post parotid surgery or other surgeries that cause an opening of the parotid capsule. It is caused by an aberrant regeneration of post-ganglionic parasympathetic nerve fibres, along the sympathetic pathways to the sweat glands near the parotid region. 

Clinical features as a result of salivary stimulation by the smell or taste of food include:

  • Sweating
  • Warmth
  • Redness of the face 

Diagnosed using a starch-iodine test. Denervation by a tympanic neurectomy or auriculotemporal nerve avulsion has been advocated in management but is often not curative. The symptoms can be managed by the subcutaneous infiltration of purified botulinum toxin into the affected area and the use of antiperspirant.

Related Pearl: Parasympathetic/ secretomotor (general visceral efferent) innervation of glands

  • Nervus intermedius, also called the nerve of Wrisberg, is the sensory & secretomotor component of the facial nerve.
  • The main trunk of the facial nerve, as it exits the brainstem, only carries motor fibers.

questions.text: In which part of the fallopian tube does fertilization occur?
questions.solution:
Fertilization usually occurs in the ampulla of the fallopian tube.

During ovulation, the ovum is released and it enters the fallopian tube. It is propelled towards the uterine cavity by the peristaltic action of the fallopian tubes. It can only be fertilized within 24 hours of ovulation.  If coitus takes place during this period, the spermatozoa swimming up into the tubes meet the ovum in the ampulla.

Related Pearl: Fallopian tube

Gross anatomy:

The fallopian tube is divided into the following parts:

  • Intramural/Interstitial portion:  
    • Intrauterine
    • The narrowest and shortest part
  • Isthmus:
    • The most common site for tubectomy
  • Ampulla:
    • The longest part
    • The most common site for - fertilization and ectopic pregnancy
  • Infundibulum:
    • The widest part

Histology:

The ampulla, isthmus and infundibulum are extrauterine. They're covered by three layers: 

  • Mesosalpinx - It is the peritoneal layer. Also called serosa.
  • Myosalpinx - It contains smooth muscle and has 2 layers:
    • Inner circular 
    • Outer longitudinal
  • Endosalpinx - It is the mucosal layer. It has the following features:
    • Numerous branching folds, filling the entire lumen
    • Basement membrane
    • Ciliated, columnar epithelium 
    • Peg cells - non-ciliated epithelium. They help in the capacitation of sperms.

questions.text: A pregnant woman presents to your OPD with severe constipation. After ruling out pathological causes, which of the following is the safest to prescribe?
questions.solution:
Lactulose is safe to use in pregnant women with constipation.

Constipation in pregnancy:

Constipation is a common occurrence in pregnancy because of dietary alterations, anatomic impingement of a large uterus on the rectosigmoid, fluid shifts, decreased exercise levels, and reduced mobility. Pregnancy and pregnancy-related constipation increases the risk for developing haemorrhoids.

Treatment options include

  • Dietary changes - increased water intake, increased fibre in diet
  • Gentle exercises
  • Laxatives - Lactulose, an osmotic purgative, and Ispaghula, a bulk forming agent, are safe to use in pregnancy. 

Senna, bisacodyl, docusates and saline laxatives’ safety is unknown and hence it is better to avoid them.

Note:

Laxatives are drugs that promote bowel evacuation.

Classification of Laxatives:

  • Bulk-forming agents 
    • Dietary fibre: Bran
    • Psyllium, Ispaghula, Methylcellulose
  • Stool softener: Docusates (DOSS), Liquid paraffin
  • Stimulant purgatives
    • Diphenylmethanes: Phenolphthalein, Bisacodyl, Sodium picosulphate
    • Anthraquinones: Senna, Cascara sagrada
    • 5-HT4 agonist: Prucalopride
    • PG analogue: Lubiprostone
  • Osmotic purgatives
    • Magnesium salts: sulphate, hydroxide
    • Sodium salts: sulphate, phosphate
    • Sodium potassium tartrate
    • Lactulose
    • Lactitol

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presented with sudden, progressive, painless loss of vision in the right eye. There was no history of associated photopsia. On examination, shifting fluid sign is present. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the presence of shifting fluid is suggestive of exudative retinal detachment. 

Exudative RD is characterized by the accumulation of fluid beneath the retina in the absence of a retinal break or traction. Fluid leaks outside the vessels and accumulates under the retina. RD does not occur as long as the retinal pigment epithelium is pumping the leaking fluid into the choroidal circulation. Causes:

  • Inflammatory conditions like choroiditis, posterior scleritis.
  • Choroidal tumours like melanoma.
  • Toxaemia of pregnancy
  • Central serous retinopathy
  • Coats disease

Patients may present with painless progressive visual field defects without photopsia. Floaters may be present if there is an associated vitritis. Clinical signs include:

  • Convex configuration of the retinal detachment, with a smooth surface
  • A detached retina is very mobile
  • Shifting fluid sign- Subretinal fluid detaches the area of the retina under which it accumulates. In the upright position, it collects under the inferior retina. But in the supine position, the inferior retina flattens, the fluid shifts posteriorly which detach the superior retina.
  • The cause of the RD may be apparent. 
  • Leopard spots- Scattered areas of clumped subretinal pigment may be seen after the detachment has flattened

Retinal detachment (RD) is the result of the accumulation of fluid between the retina and the retinal pigment epithelium. It is classified into the following:

  • Rhegmatogenous RD- due to a tear or break in the retina
  • Secondary RD - due to some other preceding event
    • Exudative RD
    • Tractional RD

The image shows the shifting fluid sign and late-phase fluorescein angiogram showing hyperfluorescent spots with a leopard spot pattern in the posterior fundus and staining of the arteries and an avascular area in the nasal region respectively.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with end-stage renal disease presents with back pain. He gives a history of frequent pathological fractures. Identify the characteristic finding seen in his lumbosacral radiograph given below.
questions.solution:
The radiograph given above shows a Rugger jersey spine which is a characteristic feature of renal osteodystrophy. The given clinical scenario is suggestive of renal osteodystrophy which is caused by hyperparathyroidism secondary to chronic renal disease. 

Rugger jersey appearance is seen due to osteosclerosis of the superior and inferior vertebral endplates. This occurs due to excess osteoid formation by the osteoblasts to counteract increased bone resorption. The term 'rugger jersey’ appearance is used because there are alternating bands of increased and decreased bone density, similar to the jersey of a rugby player.

questions.text: Which of the following fractures results most commonly due to falling from a height onto the feet?
questions.solution:
Ring fracture - These occur in the posterior fossa around the foramen magnum and are most often caused by a fall from height. If the kinetic energy of the fall is not absorbed by fractures of the legs, pelvis or spine, the impact is transmitted up the cervical spine. This may be rammed into the skull, carrying a circle of occipital bone with it.

Related Pearl: Types of skull vault fracture

Diastatic fracture - Separation of sutures due to blow with blunt weapon or from cerebral edema. It is also called sutural fracture.

Fissured fracture/Linear fracture:

  • Linear skull fractures are breaks in the bone that traverse the full thickness of the skull from the outer to inner table.
  • They are usually fairly straight with no bone displacement.
  • The common cause of injury is blunt force trauma where the impact energy transferred over a wide area of the skull.

Pond fracture - Occurs in children due to elasticity of bones. It is also known as indented fracture.

Depressed fracture - Caused by a heavy weapon with a small striking surface. Its shape indicates the type of weapon which is produced. So it is also called 'signature fracture'.

Comminuted fracture - It is also called spider web fracture and has a stellate appearance where there is no displacement of fracture.

questions.text: On performing a pulmonary function test, reduction in FEV1/FVC is characteristic of:
questions.solution:
Reduction in FEV1/FVC is characteristic of obstructive lung disease.

Common pulmonary function tests (PFTs) include

  • Spirometry
  • Measurement of lung volumes
  • Quantitation of diffusing capacity for carbon monoxide(DLCO)

Based on PFTs, lung disorders are broadly classified into:

  1. Obstructive disease
  2. Restrictive disease
  3. Pulmonary vascular disease

At a given lung volume, when a person inhales to the total lung capacity and exhales as hard and as completely as possible, the volume of expired air is recorded as forced vital capacity (FVC), and the volume of air expired in the first second is called the forced expiratory volume (FEV1).

FVC is reduced both in obstructive and restrictive lung diseases. In obstructive diseases, the slope of FVC is steady, therefore the FEV1 value is low. Therefore, the FEV1/FVC ratio decreases. In restrictive diseases, the airflow is fast in the beginning, leading to a higher value of FEV1. Therefore, the FEV1/FVC ratio increases. 

Related Pearl: PFT for obstructive vs restrictive diseases

  • Decreased in emphysema

questions.text: A 23-year-old male patient presents to the OPD with nausea, vomiting, and four episodes of loose stools. On history taking, he reveals to have consumed food from a restaurant 3 hours back. Which of the following is wrong about the toxin involved?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is highly suggestive of an acute episode of food poisoning caused by Staphylococcus aureus. The toxin involved, enterotoxins, are heat stable.

Staphylococcus causes nausea, vomiting, and diarrhoea 2-6 hours after consuming contaminated food (other organisms causing food poisoning within the same time period of 2-6 hours is Bacillus cereus-Emetic strains).

Enterotoxin produced by Staphylococcus:

  • There are 15 enterotoxins, they are superantigens
  • It is a preformed toxin that is heat stable (Most of the other exotoxins are heat-labile).
  • Site of action: This toxin stimulates the vagus nerve and vomiting centre of the brain and also stimulates the intestinal peristaltic activity.

Related Pearl: Food Poisoning

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl was brought by her mother with complaints of enlarged clitoris. Karyotype revealed 46XX. What is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
The likely cause in the given clinical scenario is congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH), in which 21-hydroxylase deficiency causes ambiguous genitalia in females due to increased serum androgens. 

Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH)/adrenogenital syndrome is a family of autosomal-recessive disorders caused by the deficiency of enzymes involved in the synthesis of steroid hormones in the adrenal cortex. It causes pseudohermaphroditism, that is, genotypically normal female (46, XX), whose external genitalia looks like that of a male.

Note:

  • Virilization is usually apparent at birth in females and within 2 to 3 years of life in males.
  • The most common cause of ambiguous genitalia in a newborn is a classic 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
  • Pseudohermaphroditism of the female child is most commonly due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.

Related Pearl: Variants of Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH)

21-Hydroxylase 17-Hydroxylase 11β-Hydroxylase 3β-HSD

Deficiency of cortisol and aldosterone;

↑ in testosterone

 Deficiency of cortisol and sex hormones; ↑ in aldosterone Deficiency of cortisol; ↑ in deoxycorticosterone (mineralocorticoid) and testosterone Deficiency of cortisol, aldosterone and testosterone; ↑ in DHEA

Salt retention and  hypertension
