virilized (DHEA is a weak androgen)
Precocious puberty in males Males are incompletely virilized (ambiguous genitalia 46XY) Precocious puberty in males Males are incompletely virilized (ambiguous genitalia 46XY)

Note: In 11β-Hydroxylase deficiency, Aldosterone synthetic capacity is normal and some corticosterone is synthesized from progesterone by intact aldosterone synthase enzyme. Thus, it is unusual for patients to manifest signs of adrenal insufficiency.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs cause carcinoma bladder?
questions.solution:
Cyclophosphamide causes bladder cancer. 

The risk of bladder cancer is related to the duration and intensity of cyclophosphamide treatment. Phosphoramide mustard is the primary mutagenic metabolite that causes bladder cancer in patients exposed to cyclophosphamide.

Carcinoma of the bladder & associated risk factors: 

Histological subtype Risk factors
Transitional cell carcinoma (urothelial)
  • Smoking
  • Exposure to aniline dyes
  • Cyclophosphamide
  • Pelvic irradiation

Squamous cell carcinoma
  • Schistosomiasis
  • Chronic irritation caused by stone disease
  • Bladder diverticula
  • Chronic UTI
  • Smoking
Adenocarcinoma
  • Persistent urachus or trigone of the bladder

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman with a lump in her right breast was advised to undergo mammography which was reported as BIRADS 3. What will be the appropriate next step of management in this patient?
questions.solution:
A BIRADS score of 3 means that it is probably a benign lesion. The next appropriate step is to follow up with this patient every 6 months for the next 2 years.

During this period, the score can either downgrade to BIRADS 2 or upgrade to BIRADS 4 or 5.

Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System (BI-RADS) standardizes the reporting for mammography and ultrasonography and helps guide decision making:

Category Definition Follow-up
0 Incomplete assessment Additional imaging evaluation
1 Negative Annual screening
2 Benign finding Annual screening
3 Probably benign finding 6 monthly mammogram for next 2 years
4 Suspicious abnormality (2%-95% malignant) Biopsy
5 Highly suggestive of malignancy (>95% malignant) Appropriate action should be taken 
6 Known biopsy—proven malignancy Appropriate treatment

questions.text: The following barium swallow is suggestive of
questions.solution:
Image shows markedly dilated esophagus and characteristic bird's beak appearance suggestive of achalasia cardia (dilated esophagus with distal narrowing).

In achalasia cardia, the lower esophagral spinchter (LES) is hypertensive and fails to relax appropriately in response to swallowing. Sphincter spasm and delayed emptying through LES are also seen. Esophageal manometry is the gold standard for establishing the diagnosis of esophageal achalasia.

Related Pearl: Achalasia Cardia

Achalasia is a rare disease caused by the loss of ganglion cells within the esophageal myenteric plexus.

Their absence leads to increased tone of the lower esophageal sphincter, impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES), and absent peristalsis.

Achalasia is the only true motility disorder of the esophagus.

Primary achalasia is due to ganglion cell degeneration and is thought to be due to an autoimmune process attributable to latent infection with human herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV1) combined with genetic susceptibility.

Secondary achalasia may arise in Chaga's disease

Clinical features:

  • dysphagia (solid and liquid food)
  • regurgitation
  • chest pain
  • weight loss
  • bronchitis, pneumonia, or lung abscess from aspiration

Differential diagnosis: Diffuse esophageal spasm, Chagas’ disease, and pseudoachalasia

On barium swallow: Bird beak-appearance

Investigation of choice: Manometry (most sensitive)

Treatment: Pneumatic dilatation and Heller myotomy

Related Pearl: Manometric findings in oesophageal disorders

Manometric Findings in Nutcracker Esophagus

  • Peristaltic esophageal contractions 2 standard deviations above normal
  • Amplitude > 180 mmHg and duration > 7seconds.
  • Normal peristaltic sequence

Manometric Findings in Diffuse Esophageal Spasm

  • Simultaneous, multipeaked contractions of high amplitude (>120 mm Hg) or long duration (>2.5 sec)
  • These erratic contractions occur after more than 20% of wet swallows.
  • Intermittent normal peristalsis

Manometric Findings in Hypertensive Lower Esophageal Sphincter-

  • Elevated LES pressure > 26mmHg and normal relaxation of LES
  • The esophageal body may be hyper-peristaltic or normal.

Manometric findings in Achalasia Cardia

  • Incomplete LES relaxation
  • Aperistalsis in the esophageal body
  • Elevated LES pressure ≥26 mmHg
  • Increased intraesophageal baseline pressures relative to gastric baseline

Manometric findings in ineffective esophageal motility disorders

  • Decreased or absent amplitude of esophageal peristalsis (<30 mmHg)
  • Increased number of non-transmitted contractions

questions.text: Zika virus is transmitted by:
questions.solution:
Zika virus may be transmitted by the bite of infected Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus.

The symptoms of Zika virus disease include fever, rash, conjunctivitis, muscle and joint pain, malaise, or headache. These symptoms are mild and usually last for 2-7 days.

Zika virus infection during pregnancy may cause lead to microcephaly or congenital Zika syndrome. 

The complications of Zika virus infection include Guillain-Barré syndrome, neuropathy, and myelitis.

Related Pearl: The Mosquito

The mosquito as a vector:

  • Mosquitoes are global in distribution.
  • The main species of mosquitoes include the Anopheles, Culex, Aedes and Mansonia.
  • Flight range varies up to 11 kms, except Aedes for which it is 100 metres.
  • Life span of mosquitoes is around 8 to 34 days.
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a proboscis, a pair of palpi and a pair of antennae; a thorax and an abdomen.

questions.text: What is the finding in the given EEG of an infant?
questions.solution:
Hypsarrhythmia is an abnormal interictal pattern which consists of diffuse, giant slow waves with a chaotic background of irregular, multifocal spikes and sharp waves. During the clinical spasm, there is a marked suppression of the EEG background (the electrodecremental response).

Hypsarrhythmias are usually seen in epileptic spasms. These are characterized by a briefly sustained flexion or extension of predominantly proximal muscles, including truncal muscles.

The table given below shows the EEG features seen in various seizure disorders.

Disease Typical EEG feature
Lennox-Gastaut syndrome 1.5-2.5 Hz spike and polyspike bursts in sleep
Absence seizures 3 Hz spike and slow-wave (spike and dome pattern)
Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy 4-5 Hz spike
West syndrome Hypsarrhythmia (high-voltage waves with chaotic background)

Related Pearl: EEG Waves

EEG Waves

questions.text: Identify the finding in the image below:
questions.solution:
The image shows velamentous cord insertion, where the umbilical cord is attached to the foetal membranes. The cord vessels traverse between the membranes for some distance before reaching the placenta.

If this part of the membrane with the vessels lies in front of the presenting part and above the internal os, the condition is called vasa previa. In this condition, rupture of the membranes leads to vaginal bleeding and foetal exsanguination.

Other options:

  • Battledore placenta – The cord is attached to the margin of the placenta.
  • Circumvallate placenta - The foetal surface of placenta is covered by a white ring at the periphery made up of a double fold of amnion and chorion.
  • Succenturiate placenta - One or small lobes of placenta lies separate from the main part and is connected to the main part by a leash of blood vessels passing through the membrane.

questions.text: You are writing a paper about the growth and development of children. You are doubtful about a few points. Which of the following statements given below is not true?

choices.text: Head circumference should be measured within 24 hours after birth
Head circumference equals chest circumference at 1 year of age
A boys height at 2 and half years is half of his adult height
A girls height at 2 years is half of her adult height

questions.solution:
Head circumference should not be measured within 24 hours because the head is subjected to molding during delivery, which makes the measurements unreliable.

The maximum circumference of the head from the occipital protuberance to the supraorbital ridges on the forehead is recorded using the cross-tape method.

Age Head circumference
At birth 33 to 35cm
3 m 40 cm
6 m 43 cm
1 year 46 cm
2 years 48 cm
3 years 49 cm
4 years 50 cm
12 years 52 cm (adult size)
  • Head circumference increases by the following:
    • 2 cm/month in first 3 months
    • 1 cm/month in next 3 months
    • 0.5 cm/month in next 6 months

Head circumference is more than chest circumference by 2.5 cm at birth.

  • At birth: Head circumference > Chest circumference
  • At 9-12 months: Head circumference = Chest circumference
  • After 1 year: Head circumference < Chest circumference

Interesting fact!

A boy's height at 2 and half years is half of his adult height and a girl's height at 2 years is half of her adult height.

To roughly predict adult height, use the formula:

  • Adult height = height at 2.5 years for boys (or 2 years for girls) X 2

According to WHO growth charts, the height-for-age for most of the children lies between 70-90 cm during these periods. The double of it, i.e. 140-180 cm is the average height that most of us achieve as adults.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the marked incision shown below?

choices.text: The rectus abdominis muscles are transected
Follows Langer lines of skin tension
Reentry during repeat C-section is difficult due to scarring

questions.solution:
The incision marked is the Pfannenstiel incision where the rectus muscles are not transected.

Pfannenstiel incision is the most common incision made in caesarean delivery.It follows Langer lines of skin tension. A transverse and slightly curvilinear incision is made in the skin and subcutaneous tissue 3 cm above the superior border of the pubic symphysis. This is stretched laterally for 12-15 cm to accommodate the delivery of the fetus. Following this, the rectus sheath is incised transversely and rectus muscles are separated in the middle to gain entry to the peritoneum.

The Maylard incision (the unmarked incision in the image) differs mainly from the Pfannenstiel in that the bellies of the rectus abdominis muscles are transected horizontally to widen the operating space.

Related Pearl: Transverse and vertical incisions in Cesarean section

Transverse Incisions Vertical incisions

Advantages

  • Follows Langer lines of skin tension, so superior cosmetic results
  • Less Postoperative pain
  • Less fascial wound dehiscence
  • Low incidence of incisional hernias

Advantages

  • Quick entry
  • Minimal blood loss
  • Superior access to the upper
    abdomen
  • Wide operating space
  • Flexibility for easy wound extension if necessary

Disadvantages

  • High infection risks
  • Narrow operating space
  • Injury to neurovascular bundles
  • Reentry during repeat C-section is difficult due to scarring 

Disadvantages

  • Poor cosmetic results
  • Higher fascial dehiscence 
  • Higher incisional hernia rates
  • Greater postoperative pain

questions.text: Which of the following accurately describes the shape of trapezius muscle?
questions.solution:
The trapezius muscle individually is a flat, triangular muscle that extends over the back of the neck and upper thorax. When paired together, they resemble a trapezium and hence the name.

Muscles with oblique fibers are further subclassified as follows:

  1. Triangular - They are triangular in shape.
  2. Pennate - They are feather-shaped. Based on their complexity, they can have the following subtypes:
    • Unipennate - fascicles on one side of the tendon.
    • Bipennate - fascicles on two sides of the tendon.
    • Multipennate - central tendon branches into two or more branches within the muscle.
    • Circumpennate (radial) - muscle fibers converge to a central tendon in a radial fashion.

Related Pearl: Classification of muscles according to their shape/direction of muscle fibers

Muscles with parallel fasciculi

Muscles with oblique fasciculi

Muscles with spiral or twisted fasciculi

 

Quadrilateral: Thyrohyoid

Triangular: Temporalis, Adductor longus, Trapezius

Spiral: Pectoralis major, Latissimus dorsi, Supinator

Strap like: Sartorius, Sternohyoid

Unipennate: Extensor digitorum longus, Flexor pollicis longus, Peroneus tertius, Palmar interossei

Partially cruciate and partially spiral: Masseter, Adductor magnus, Sternoclediomastoid 

Strap like with tendinous intersections: Rectus abdominis

Bipennate: Rectus femoris, Flexor hallucis longus, Peroneus longus, Dorsal interossei

 

Fusiform: Biceps brachii, digastric

Multipennate: Deltoid, Subscapularis

  

 

Circumpennate: Tibialis anterior

questions.text: Nitric oxide is synthesized from:
questions.solution:
Nitric oxide is synthesized from arginine by a calcium-dependent reaction catalyzed by NO synthase. 

The co-enzymes of NO synthase include FMN, FAD, Heme, and Tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4).

questions.text: ECG of a patient who presented with palpitations to the ER is shown below. Which of the following is a likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above ECG shows increased heart rate with wide QRS complexes (> 0.12s). This is suggestive of ventricular tachycardia (VT). 

Types of ventricular tachycardia based on QRS morphology:

  • Monomorphic- a stable QRS morphology from beat to beat
  • Polymorphic- changing or multiform QRS variance from beat to beat. Torsades de pointes is an example of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia.
  • Bidirectional- has a beat-to-beat alternation in the QRS frontal plane axis. It is associated with digitalis toxicity or catecholaminergic polymorphic VT.

The most common cause of VT is ischemic heart disease.

Ventricular tachyarrhythmias occur due to impulses that originate within the ventricles. These impulses are conducted through the normal ventricular myocardial cells instead of the fast conducting Purkinje system. Hence, they present with wide QRS complexes ( >0.12 sec) on the ECG.

Supraventricular tachyarrhythmias occur due to impulses originating above the ventricles. These impulses reach the ventricles through the proper fast conduction pathway resulting in a narrow QRS complex. SVTs are associated with wide QRS in few exceptional conditions like:

  • Conduction block in the left or right bundle branch
  • Activation of ventricles from an accessory pathway- antidromic AVRT

The given ECG shows wide stable QRS complexes in monomorphic ventricular tachycardia:

Other options:

Narrow QRS with irregular RR interval

     Tachycardia        ECG features
Atrial fibrillation No distinct p waves seen
Multifocal atrial tachycardia More than 3 different abnormal p wave morphologies are seen
Atrial flutter/tachycardia with variable block ECG features of heart block are seen.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient who is a known case of interstitial lung disease has recently been diagnosed with an arrhythmia. Which of the following antiarrhythmic drugs is contraindicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
Amiodarone is contraindicated in a patient with interstitial lung disease.

The most serious adverse effect during chronic amiodarone therapy is pulmonary fibrosis, which can be rapidly progressive and fatal. Underlying lung disease, doses of 400 mg/day or more, and recent pulmonary insults such as pneumonia appear to be risk factors for this condition.

Amiodarone is a class III antiarrhythmic drug.

The side effects of amiodarone include:

  • Pulmonary fibrosis
  • Hypotension, depressed ventricular function
  • Torsades de pointes
  • Corneal microdeposits
  • Hepatotoxicity
  • Neuropathies
  • Photosensitivity
  • Thyroid dysfunction

questions.text: The graph shows the drug-receptor interaction. Identify the line that depicts action of the antagonist.
questions.solution:
Line C depicts the action of an antagonist.

The receptor is postulated to exist in two forms: the inactive form (Ri) and the activated form (Ra). An antagonist binds to Ri and Ra in relative same amounts as in the absence of any drug (Ri~Ra). Thus, in this situation, no change in activity is observed (Line C).

The presence of the antagonist at the receptor site will block access of agonists to the receptor and prevent the agonist effect. Such blocking action is termed as neutral antagonism, for example, flumazenil on GABA receptors.

Other options:

  • Line A depicts full agonist, where the drug shifts maximum receptors to Ra pool. (Ra>>Ri)
  • Line B depicts partial agonists, which bind to the same receptors and activate them but not as much as full agonists, even at their maximum concentrations.
  • Line D depicts inverse agonists, where the majority of the receptors are shifted to inactivated state than activated state (Ri>Ra). Here, the effects are opposite to those produced by conventional agonists at that receptor.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy comes with complaints of right ear pain, difficulty in opening the mouth, painful swallowing, and fever. The oral cavity examination reveals the following. The external facial examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is likely?
questions.solution:
The image shows quinsy also known as a peritonsillar abscess.

Peritonsillar abscess or quinsy is a collection of pus in the peritonsillar space which lies between the capsule of the tonsil and the superior constrictor muscle. It usually follows an episode of acute tonsillitis when the crypta magna gets infected and gets sealed off. An intratonsillar abscess then forms which then bursts through the capsule to reach the peritonsillar space.

Usually, it is unilateral though occasionally bilateral abscesses are recorded.

It presents with marked odynophagia such that the patient cannot even swallow his saliva which dribbles from the angle of his mouth. The patient is usually dehydrated. Other features include a muffled and thick speech, often called a hot potato voice, sore throat, ipsilateral otalgia, torticollis, and fever.

On examination, the tonsil, pillars, and soft palate are congested and enlarged. The uvula is congested and oedematous and pushed to the opposite side. Mucopus covering the tonsil is seen. Jugulodigastric lymph nodes are enlarged and tender.

CECT, submandibular ultrasonography, and MRI are better suited for visualizing the abscess and its extent. Submandibular ultrasonography is also helpful for incision and drainage.

 Management of peritonsillar abscess:

  • Hospitalization
  • Intravenous fluids to address dehydration
  • High-dose intravenous antibiotics to cover aerobes and anaerobes
  • Analgesics for pain relief
  • Drainage by needle aspiration or incision and drainage
  • Tonsillectomy when there is airway obstruction or recurrence.

Incision and drainage of the abscess at the point of the maximum bulge above the upper pole of the tonsil or just lateral to the point of junction of the anterior pillar with a line drawn through the base of the uvula.

 Complications of peritonsillar abscess are:

  • Retropharyngeal abscess
  • Laryngeal edema
  • Parapharyngeal abscess
  • Septicemia
  • Pneumonitis/ lung abscess
  • Jugular vein thrombosis
  • Spontaneous hemorrhage from carotid artery/ jugular vein.

questions.text: Name the procedure depicted in the picture below.
questions.solution:
The picture depicts the nothern blotting technique.


Northern blotting is used for detection of RNA.

Other blotting techniques :

  • Southern blotting is used for detection of DNA.
  • Western blotting is used for detection of protein.

questions.text: After successful delivery of the baby, the obstetrician witnesses that the episiotomy performed has extended backwards beyond the perineal body. Which among the following structures is likely to be injured in this case?
questions.solution:
External anal sphincter is the structure injured in an episiotomy extended posteriorly beyond the perineal body. 

Perineal tear have been divided into four degrees:

  • First degree- laceration is restricted to the skin of the fourchette
  • Second degree- muscles of the perineal body are torn through
  • Third degree- the tear extends partially backward through the external sphincter of the anus
  • Fourth degree- the external anal sphincter is torn and anal mucosa is also involved

A central tear of the perineum is when the head penetrates first through the posterior vaginal wall, then through the perineal body and appears through the skin of the perineum. It usually occurs in patients with a contracted outlet.

Related Pearl: Degrees of perineal laceration

Degree
Description
First-degree
Injury to the skin and subcutaneous tissue of the perineum and vaginal epithelium only. The perineal muscles remain intact.
Second-degree
Extends into the fascia and musculature of the perineal body. The anal sphincter muscles remain intact.
Third-degree 
3a
<50% of EAS thickness is torn
3b
>50% of EAS thickness is torn
3c
Both EAS and IAS are torn
Fourth-degree
Involves the perineal structures, EAS, IAS and rectal mucosa.

questions.text: A patient with chronic history of severe COPD comes to the emergency room with shortness of breath. Rales and wheeze are heard on auscultation and elevated JVP is noted.  Shortness of breath wasn't relieved with bronchodilators, IV steroids, and antibiotics. Chest X-ray is given below. What is the pathology behind the patient's current condition?
questions.solution:
This patient with COPD has shortness of breath despite appropriate treatment for acute COPD exacerbation, showing peripheral pruning in chest X-ray, due to pulmonary artery hypertension

Pulmonary artery hypertension is associated with peripheral pruning which means that the blood vessels appear cut off before they reach the outer 1/3 of the lung. The edge of the lung fields are, therefore, often darker than usual and the central area often whiter.

Plain radiograph findings in pulmonary artery hypertension :

  • Elevated cardiac apex due to right ventricular hypertrophy
  • Enlarged right atrium
  • Prominent pulmonary outflow tract
  • Enlarged pulmonary arteries
  • Pruning of peripheral pulmonary vessels

Left hear failure would have showed pulmonary edema on chest X-ray (Option B)

Laryngitis would not cause pruning on chest X-ray and shortness of breath would be associated with stridor (Option D)

Patient with severe COPD without (A) and with (B) signs of pulmonary fluid overload and cardiac decompensation. Note the only discrete increase of vascular markings in (B) while the pleural effusion and the enlarged heart indicate the severity of the disease.

questions.text: A 41-year-old female patient presented with a tortuous swelling over the left side of the scalp and face as shown in the image given below. On local examination, the swelling was pulsatile. On auscultation, a bruit was heard. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image showing tortuous swelling over the scalp and the clinical findings are suggestive of a cirsoid aneurysm.

Cirsoid aneurysm is a slow-growing, tortuous swelling that develops due to abnormal arteriovenous connections among the subcutaneous blood vessels. They are usually congenital. However, in some cases, they may be traumatic. The superficial temporal artery is most commonly involved.

Patients present with a tortuous, pulsatile swelling over the scalp or face. They are usually asymptomatic and present to the clinic due to cosmetic deformity. However, some patients may have headache, tinnitus, and/or bleeding. A loud bruit is heard on auscultation.

Angiography is the investigation of choice.

Treatment includes surgical resection, endovascular occlusion or injection of percutaneous sclerosing agents.

questions.text: Which of the following vaccine vials can be used based on the vaccine vial monitor (VVM) color changes shown?
questions.solution:
From the above image, only vials 1 and 2 can be used as the inner squares of the VVMs are lighter than the outer circles.

Vial 3 has crossed the discard point as the inner square and outer circle are the same color and thus cannot be used. Vial 4 cannot be used as the VVM shows a darker inner square compared to the outer circle.

Related Pearl: Vaccine Vial Monitors

  • Vaccine vial monitors are used to monitor heat exposure of vaccines.
  • It is a chemical indicator that records the cumulative heat exposure through a gradual change in color.
  • If the color of the inner square is the same color or darker than the outer circle, it indicates that the vaccine has been exposed to too much heat and it must be discarded.
  • Currently, there are four types of VVMs (VVM2, VVM7, VVM14, and VVM30). They are chosen to match the heat sensitivity of the vaccine.
  • The VVM can be located on the label of the vaccine or on the neck or cap of the ampule/vial.
  • VVMs also help in reduction of vaccine wastage by indicating which batch of vaccines can be used first.

questions.text: All of the following conditions are related to the same pathology except?
questions.solution:
Alzheimer's disease, unlike the rest, is not an alpha-synucleinopathy. It is a β-amyloidopathy characterized by the accumulation of Aβ amyloid protein.

Alpha-synucleinopathies: These are a group of neurodegenerative disorders, that are characterized by aggregation of α-Synuclein in neurons, nerve fibers, or glial cells to form inclusion bodies. 

Related Pearl: Alzheimer’s disease

Alzheimer’s disease:

  • Age of onset > 60 years
  • Mini-mental state examination (MMSE) < 24
  • Diagnosis: Clinical
    • 2 or more areas of cognitive deficits
    • Progressive worsening of memory and other cognitive function
    • No disturbance in consciousness
    • Other systemic causes must be ruled out 

Risk Factors:

  • Most important risk factor: Old age
  • Other risk factors – Family history, presenilin-1, presenilin-2, Apolipoprotein E4 (ApoE ε4 allele), Ubiquitin, Down syndrome and smoking.

Protective factors: NSAIDs and Apolipoprotein E2

Causes: Decrease in acetylcholine causing depletion of the cholinergic neurons in the nucleus basalis of Meynert resulting in short-term memory defects. 

Early findings:

  • Anterograde memory loss (immediate recall affected, distant memories preserved)
  • Visuospatial deficits (lost in own neighborhood)
  • Language difficulties (difficulty finding words)
  • Cognitive impairment with a progressive decline
  • Anosognosia 
  • Visual processing dysfunction (posterior cortical atrophy syndrome)
  • Difficulties with naming and repetition (logopenic aphasia)

Late findings:

  • Psychotic symptoms: delusions
  • Apraxia: Difficulty to perform learned motor tasks
  • Lack of insight regarding deficits
  • Non-cognitive neurologic deficits: Pyramidal and extrapyramidal, myoclonus and seizures
  • disrupted sleep - wake pattern.
  • Urinary incontinence.
  • Loss of procedural memory

Histopathology:

  • Senile plaques (amyloid deposits), neurofibrillary tangles (composed of tau proteins), neuronal loss, synaptic loss, and granulovacuolar degeneration of neurons.

The image below shows neurofibrillary tangles in Alzheimer's disease.

CT/MRI:

  • Later stages: Cortical and subcortical atrophy prominent in parietal and temporal lobes, particularly hippocampus. 

Treatment:

  • NMDA antagonist: memantine
  • Cholinesterase inhibitors: donepezil, galantamine, rivastigmine.
  • Monoclonal antibody against the N-terminus of the Aβ peptide - aducanumab

questions.text: Which of the following features would you not expect to see in a patient with MEN2B syndrome?
questions.solution:
Meningioma is not commonly seen in MEN2B Syndrome. MEN1 syndrome is associated with meningiomas.

Related Pearl: MEN 2 Syndrome Features

MEN 2A

  • Known as Sipple’s syndrome
  • Chromosome 10 / RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Parathyroid adenoma (10–25%)

MEN 2B

  • Known commonly as MEN 3
  • Chromosome 10/ RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (>90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Other associated abnormalities include: (40–50%)
      • Mucosal neuromas
      • Marfanoid habitus
      • Medullated corneal nerve fibers
      • Megacolon

questions.text: Identify the condition seen in this X-ray.
questions.solution:
This X ray shows a typical finding of multiple gas-filled cysts of the gastrointestinal tract which is indicative of Pneumatosis intestinalis.

It is an uncommon condition where cysts may be located in the subserosa, submucosa, and, rarely, muscularis layer and vary in size from microscopic to several centimeters in diameter.

Pneumatosis not associated with other lesions is referred to as primary pneumatosis.

Pneumoperitoneum is an emergency where early surgical intervention/laparotomy may be needed to stop further contamination of the peritoneal cavity.

Except in a few cases like silent perforations with a sealed leak, perforated cyst in pneumatosis intestinalis, post-operative pneumoperitoneum, etc can be managed conservatively. 

Pneumatosis cystoides intestinalis presents as multiple gas-filled cysts. Intermittent rupture of these cysts leads to pneumoperitoneum without the evidence of peritonitis. The management here lies in treating the underlying cause. Asymptomatic patients do not require any additional therapy.

questions.text: Which of the following is the likely explanation for symmetrical uptake in bilateral supraclavicular areas with no uptake on paratracheal nodes on PET-CT in a patient with ca esophagus?

choices.text: Recent viral upper respiratory tract infection

questions.solution:
• 18F-FDG PET-CT is the current modality of choice to evaluate for metastases and demonstrates brown fat as areas of high uptake. It is a potential source of false-positive FDG PET interpretations in oncologic imaging.

 Areas of Normal physiological uptake in PET CT:

  • Brain tissue
  • Skeletal muscle, especially after strenuous activity and laryngeal muscles following speech
  • Myocardium
  • Gastrointestinal tract, e.g. intestinal wall
  • Genitourinary tract: FDG is excreted via the renal system and passes into the collecting systems
  • Brown fat
  • Thymus
  • Bone marrow

questions.text: A patient in the emergency ward rolls around on the bed in a futile attempt to find a position free from pain. This attitude of the patient is most likely to be because of
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is most likely to be due to renal colic. A patient of renal colic would have a restless attitude, often rolling around because of pain and tries to find a pain free position.

Option B: On the contrary, a patient with peritonitis lies supine without movement and also has shallow breathing as any movement exacerbates the pain in peritonitis.

Option C: Patients with meningitis present with neck stiffness.

Option D: In acute pancreatitis, the patient usually bends forward and assumes a knee-chest position because of abdominal pain.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presented with low-grade fever, headache, and mild upper respiratory tract infection. He also developed an erythematous rash on the cheek which progressed to the extremities the following day as shown below. The agent responsible for this condition has ________
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario, along with the image displaying the distinctive 'slapped cheek appearance,' is characteristic of erythema infectiosum (fifth disease), which is caused by parvovirus B19. This virus is a single-stranded DNA virus.

It evolves in three phases:

First phase - sudden onset diffuse and macular, asymptomatic erythema of the cheeks, (slapped cheek). Prodromal symptoms may occur.
Second phase -  begins after 1–4 days, with discrete erythematous macules and papules on the proximal extremities and later the trunk.
Third phase - Recurring stage, the eruption is greatly reduced or invisible, only to recur after the patient is exposed to heat or sunlight, or in response to crying or exercise.

Note:

  • Viruses contain either RNA or DNA but never both.
  • Only single-stranded DNA virus – Parvoviridae
  • Only double-stranded RNA virus – Reoviridae

Related Pearl: Enveloped and non-enveloped viruses

  Non-enveloped viruses Enveloped viruses
DNA viruses

Parvovirus

Adenovirus

Herpes virus

Hepatitis B virus

Poxvirus
RNA viruses

Picornavirus

Astrovirus

Reovirus

Calicivirus

Hepatitis A and E virus

Hepatitis c virus

Rubella virus

Chikungunya virus

Dengue virus

Japanese encephalitis virus

Kyasanur Forest disease virus

Zika virus

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department with complaints of breathing difficulty, facial swelling, and palpitations following a bee sting. He was immediately given an injection of a drug. What dose, and in what route should this drug be given to this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient's complaints of breathing difficulty, facial swelling, and palpitations following a bee sting are suggestive of anaphylactic shock. The drug of choice for anaphylaxis is intramuscular adrenaline (0.5ml in 1:1000 dilution).  Epinephrine (1:1000 solution) 0.5 ml via intramuscular route is preferred in the treatment of anaphylactic shock.

For intravenous use, 1:1000 adrenaline must be further diluted to 1:10,000 and should be used very cautiously as slow bolus.

There is a much greater risk of causing harmful side effects by either inappropriate dosage or misdiagnosis of anaphylaxis when using IV adrenaline. Hence, IM injection is preferred over intravenous (IV) bolus because it is faster in many situations and safer (lower risk of cardiovascular complications, such as severe hypertension and ventricular arrhythmias).

For intramuscular, subcutaneous, and inhalational (nebulization) routes of administration, 1:1000 dilution can be used. 

In cardiac arrest, the 1:1000 adrenaline must be diluted to 1:10,000 for IV use. The recommended dose of epinephrine is 1mg = 10 mL of 1:10,000 solution IV administered every 3 to 5 minutes during resuscitation as per the CPR guidelines.

Epinephrine is also used in the treatment of hypotension, to induce local vasoconstriction to reduce the diffusion of local anaesthetics and to induce bronchodilation in asthma and COPD.

questions.text: Where is the electrode placed in cochlear implant procedures?
questions.solution:
The electrode of a cochlear implant is placed in the scala tympani.

A cochlear implant is a medical device that uses electricity to stimulate the spiral ganglion cells of the auditory nerve to restore sensorineural hearing loss. It converts sound to an electrical signal (transduction) and delivers this to the hearing nerve, which bypasses the damaged hearing apparatus. It cannot be used in patients with cochlear aplasia or without the VIIIth cranial nerve.

Cochlear implant:

  • An electronic device for severe to profound SNHL and who cannot benefit from a hearing aid.
  • Principle- surgery to place the electrode array within the scala tympani of the cochlea.
  • Indication- bilateral severe to profound deafness
  • Prerequisites- intact 8th nerve and higher auditory pathway
  • Surgical approach- facial recess (posterior tympanotomy) approach
  • The electrode of a cochlear implant is placed in the scala tympani. (Note: In the auditory brainstem implant, the site of the implant is the lateral recess of the 4th ventricle.)

The receiver-stimulator implanted during surgery (under the skin) and the electrode array (implanted in the scala tympani of the cochlea) are part of the internal component of the cochlear implant. Microphone, speech processor, and transmitter are part of the external component of the cochlear implant, which remains outside the body.

Cochlear implants replace the non-functional transducer system of hair cells of the cochlea and convert the sound signal to electrical impulses, which directly stimulate the fibers of cranial nerve VIII.

questions.text: A baby assessed 5 minutes after birth is found to be pink, with blue extremities, and irregular respiration. Heart rate is 80 beats per minute. There is grimace and some flexion. What is the Apgar score for this baby?
questions.solution:
The Apgar score for this baby will be 5.

  • Color; body pink, extremities blue: score-1
  • Heart rate; 80 beats per minute: score 1
  • Grimace: Score-1
  • Some flexion: Score-1
  • Irregular respiration: Score-1

Related Pearl: APGAR score

questions.text: A medical student is presenting a paper on retrosternal goitre. Which of the following statements is true about this condition?

choices.text: Operated in all patients regardless of symptoms
Sternal incision is always required to operate
It receives blood supply from the thoracodorsal artery
Most of the retrosternal goitres can be removed by a neck incision

questions.solution:
Most of the retrosternal goitres can be removed by neck incision (transcervical). 

Option A: Surgical removal of the retrosternal goitre is indicated in patients with significant airway compression, in young patients who have symptoms such as dyspnoea or dysphagia. 

Option B: Median sternotomy approach is indicated in:

  • Primary mediastinal goitre
  • Malignant retrosternal goitre
  • Very large retrosternal goitre
  • Recurrence in the mediastinum

For a primary mediastinal goitre whose boundaries are completely within the chest, resection is often achieved through median sternotomy or thoracotomy to ensure that the vessels supplying the tumour are properly ligated. Removing the tumour through a cervical approach can result in uncontrolled bleeding and is generally avoided. 

Option C: Blood supply to retrosternal goitre is from the thyroid vessels (secondary).

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of the image given below?

choices.text: It is also known as thiersch graft
Only dressing is enough at donor site
Donor site can be reused before healing

questions.solution:
The image given depicts the harvesting of a split skin graft. The donor site can not be reused before healing.

The most preferable donor site is buttock in cosmetically sensitive individuals and children. The most commonly used donor site is the thigh.

  • The graft is taken from the donor site with a handheld Humby knife or electric dermatome.
  • Grafts are perforated to allow exudates to escape and improve ‘take’. It can further be meshed to allow expansion.
  • Grafts will take up only on the beds which are vascularized, hence preparation of wound bed is an essential step.
  • Skin grafts are completely dependent on nutrition on the tissue over which they are placed and can heal well over muscle, perichondrium, and periosteum. They do not take well over bone or cartilage or on tissue that has been irradiated or infected or is hypovascular.
  • A clean healthy wound bed with a meshed graft tied in place to stop movement will encourage take.
  • Presence of group A beta-hemolytic streptococci is contraindicated in grafting as it can destroy split grafts completely and also convert donor to full thickness defect.

Skin grafts can be broadly divided into two categories:

Split-thickness skin graft (Thiersch graft): Partial-thickness skin grafts consisting of the epidermis and a portion of the dermis are called split-thickness skin grafts. Less dermis in the split-thickness skin graft translates into less primary contraction (the degree to which a graft shrinks in surface area after harvesting and before grafting) and more secondary contraction (the degree to which a graft shrinks during healing).

Full-thickness skin grafts (Wolfe graft) include the epidermis and entire dermis, with portions of the sweat glands, sebaceous glands, and hair follicles. More dermis in the full-thickness skin graft translates into more primary contraction and less secondary contraction.

Advantages of split skin graft over full-thickness skin graft:

  • Large grafts can be harvested.
  • In the case of thinner split-thickness grafts, the donor site heals more rapidly and can be reused in severe cases such as burns.
  • Uptake is good. Meshing can be done i.e. small splits are made in graft and any exudates collected can come out through this and this improves graft takeup. 
  • Meshing also allows the graft to expand.

Advantages of full-thickness skin graft over split skin graft:

  • It has a lesser degree of post-graft contraction.
  • Best cosmetic appearance as they include the highest number of skin appendage elements.

Related Pearl: Skin graft : phases of uptake of the graft

The take of skin graft occurs in three phases:

  1. Imbibition (Plasmatic circulation): during the first 48 hours, the graft is nourished with plasma exudate from host bed capillaries.
  2. Inosculation, in which cut vessels from the host bed line up with the cut ends of the vessels of the graft to form anastomoses
  3. Neovascularization, in which blood vessels grow from the recipient bed into the graft

Sensibility returns to the graft over time, with reinnervation beginning at approximately 4 to 5 weeks and being completed by 12 to 24 months. Pain returns first, with light touch and temperature returning later.

Note: some books give that the 3 phases are imbibition,revascularisation (inosculation+neovascularisation) and organisation (fibrin layer holds the graft in place and this is replaced by postgraft day 7 with fibroblasts)

questions.text: The following is the histopathological image of the patient with acute viral hepatitis. Identify the cause of the marked structure?
questions.solution:
The above histopathological image shows Councilman bodies.

These are acidophil bodies, which represent hepatocytes undergoing apoptosis.

Councilman bodies are seen mainly in acute viral hepatitis.

questions.text: What type of joint is an incudostapedial joint?
questions.solution:
The incudostapedial joint is a ball and socket type of joint.

In ball and socket-type of joints, the articular surfaces include a globular head (male surface) fitting into a cup-shaped socket (female surface). These joints are multi-axial and movements occur around a number of axes. Flexion, extension, abduction, adduction, medial rotation, lateral rotation, and circumduction, all occur quite freely. E.g., shoulder joint, hip joint, talocalcaneonavicular joint, and incudostapedial joint.

Note: The other joint between the incus and malleus (incudomalleolar joint) is a saddle joint. 

Related Pearl: Types of Synovial Joints

Classification of Synovial Joints
Type Articular surfaces Movement Examples
1. Plane Almost flat Minimal sliding movements Intercarpal, intermetacarpal, carpometacarpal (except first), intertarsal, intermetatarsal, tarsometatarsal, joints between articular processes of vertebrae, cricothyroid joint, cricoarytenoid joint, superior tibiofibular, interchondral joint (5-9 ribs), costovertebral, costotransverse, acromioclavicular, chondrosternal (except first) joints
2. Hinge Pulley shaped Uniaxial - flexion & extension Elbow, ankle, interphalangeal joints
3. Pivot Central pivot (peg) surrounded by osteoligamentous ring Uniaxial - rotation (supination and pronation) Superior and inferior radioulnar joints, median atlantoaxial joint
4. Condylar (bicondylar) 2 convex condyles articulate with concave or flat surfaces on the other side Biaxial - but predominantly one axis movement (flexion & extension) with limited rotation Knee joint, temporomandibular joint
5. Ellipsoid Oval convex surface fitting into an elliptical concavity Biaxial - flexion & extension, abduction & adduction, circumduction Radiocarpal (wrist), metacarpophalangeal joints
6. Saddle Each articular surface has a concave and convex region fitting the convex and concave regions of the other surface Biaxial - mainly 2 axis, flexion & extension,  abduction & adduction; very limited coupled axial rotation (conjunct rotation)  First carpometacarpal joint (of thumb), calcaneocuboid joints, incudomalleolar joint, sternoclavicular joint
7. Ball & Socket Globular head fitting into a cup-shaped socket Multiaxial - flexion & extension, abduction & adduction, circumduction, and rotation Shoulder, hip, talocalcaneonavicular, incudostapedial joint

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman has been diagnosed with lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS) which is estrogen dependent, on an excisional biopsy.  What is the drug used for her condition?
questions.solution:
Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) that is used for hormone receptor-positive breast cancers in pre-menopausal women.

It exhibits selective agonistic and antagonistic activity for ER receptors:

  • Agonist activity at uterus, bone, liver, and pituitary
  • Antagonist activity at breast and blood vessels

Uses:

  • Primary prophylaxis of breast cancer in high-risk women
  • Reducing the risk of carcinoma in the contralateral breast
  • Reducing the risk of recurrence of carcinoma in ipsilateral and contralateral breasts

Dose: 20 mg once daily for 10 years (Earlier 5 years was the duration, but latest guidelines recommend 10 years).

Adverse effects:

  • Hot flushes (most common)
  • Endometrial carcinoma
  • Thromboembolic events
  • Reduced visual acuity, cataract, and retinal deposits.

questions.text: 24-year-old presents with an intensely itchy lesion for three days. The rash is shown below. What could be the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image is a ring lesion with a central clearing suggestive of tinea corporis.

Tinea corporis/ ringworm infection is caused by the dermatophyte Trichophyton rubrum. It results from invasion and proliferation of the causal fungi in the stratum corneum with lesions on the trunk and limbs. 

Characteristic lesions are circular, usually sharply marginated with a raised edge with central resolution. Scaling is a common but not a constant finding. 

Other options:

Option B: Granuloma annulare is a circular lesion with central clearing found most commonly in children and in adult females <30 years. They usually manifest as groups of 1- to 2-mm papules that range in color from skin-colored to violaceous, often in an annular arrangement over distal extremities.

Option C: Ichthyosis Vulgaris presents with dry scaly lesions in infants. Fine scales usually develop on the back and over skin near the knee/elbow joints. Ichthyosis is usually most common and severe over the lower legs.

Option D: Pyoderma gangrenosum, chronic, recurrent, very painful neutrophilic dermatosis presents as painful ulcerative erythematous plaques or papules with undermined violaceous borders usually found on the lower limbs. It is usually associated with Inflammatory Bowel disease.

questions.text: A 3-month-old child presented with umbilical discharge. Abdomen examination was normal except for the below finding. The next step of management is?
questions.solution:
The given image is that of a congenital umbilical anomaly. The given clinical scenario is suggestive of embryonal umbilical anomalies such as patent urachus, urachal cyst, and vitelline cyst (resulting from the persistence of omphalomesenteric duct). The next best step in the management of this case is the USG abdomen to diagnose if the anomaly is cystic, fibrous, or of fistula.

Omphalomesenteric duct abnormalities:

  • Vitello intestinal duct or omphalomesenteric duct is the connection between yolk sac and the midgut during embryonic life, which gets obliterated eventually.
  • The persistence of the vitellointestinal duct can lead to various abnormality depending on the part of a duct that is persistent.
    • Persistence of the proximal intestinal end of the duct leads to Meckel’s diverticula.
    • Persistence of the distal end near umbilicus leads to umbilical polyp or sinus.
    • Persistence of distal end with mucus retention leads to cyst, which may be associated with the intestine or the umbilicus by means of a fibrous band.
    • Fully patent vitellointestinal duct can lead to enterocutaneous fistula.

questions.text: Insulin inhibits which of the following lipase enzymes?
questions.solution:
Insulin has an inhibitory effect on lipolytic hormones like hormone sensitive lipase (HSL). In adipose tissues, the stored triglycerides are broken down (lipolysis) by hormone sensitive lipase (HSL) into free fatty acids (FFAs). Insulin inhibits HSL and thus reduces the release of FFAs and also glycerol.

In diabetic patients, low insulin level corresponds to an increase in HSL activity, promoting the breakdown of lipids and release of FFAs from adipose tissue. Hormone-sensitive lipase activity is accelerated by hormones like epinephrine, norepinephrine, glucagon, ACTH, TSH, GH, ADH, and Melanocyte stimulating hormones (MSH).

Insulin induces the activity of lipoprotein lipase (LPL) which is present on the walls of capillaries. LPL promotes hydrolysis of TGs and degradation of VLDL and chylomicrons. In diabetes, low insulin leads to decreased LPL activity resulting in increased VLDL and TGs levels.

Well-fed state (Insulin) During fasting (Glucagon)
Lipogenesis increased Lipogenesis inhibited
Lipolysis inhibited Lipolysis increased
Insulin inhibits HS-lipase Glucagon activates HS-lipase
Lipoprotein lipase active Lipoprotein lipase inactive

Increased fatty acid synthesis

Increased triglycerides deposition
Activation of lipoprotein lipase
Increased K+ uptake		 Inhibition of hormone-sensitive lipase

Increased protein synthesis in ribosome

Increase K+ uptake

Decrease  release of glucogenic amino acids

questions.text: Which of the following is the most potent local anaesthetic agent?
questions.solution:
The most potent local anaesthetic among the following is bupivacaine.

Potency depends on hydrophobicity. Hydrophobicity can be increased by the addition of alkyl groups to the molecule.

Note: Dibucaine is the most potent, most toxic and longest acting local anaesthetic agent.

questions.text: A 10-year-old male child presents with a history of easy bruisiability and hemarthrosis. Investigations revealed normal platelet count and bleeding time, normal PT, and prolonged PTT. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of hemarthrosis and the investigations showing prolonged PTT  and normal platelet count, bleeding time, and PT, are suggestive of a coagulation disorder. Among the given options, hemophilia A is a coagulation disorder, while all the other conditions are platelet disorders.

Bleeding into joints (hemarthrosis) and deep tissues is a feature of coagulation disorders, whereas platelet disorders usually present with mucocutaneous bleeding such as petechiae, purpura, epistaxis, or GI bleeding. Prolonged PT/aPTT is a feature of coagulation disorders, while prolonged bleeding time is a feature of platelet disorders.

In the given scenario, normal platelet count and bleeding time exclude platelet disorders. Normal PT indicates normal functioning of the extrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade, and prolonged PTT indicates a defect in the intrinsic pathway.

Hemophilia is an X-linked (recessive) coagulation disorder associated with mutations in factor VIII, affecting the intrinsic pathway. The patients present with easy bruising, significant hemorrhage following trauma and operative procedures, and hemarthroses, but no petechiae. The diagnosis is confirmed by carrying out factor VIII-specific assays. Infusions of recombinant factor VIII are used for treatment. 

Other options:

Option 1- Von Willebrand disease is an autosomal dominant disorder that is associated with qualitative/quantitative defects in the von Willebrand factor (vWF). vWF is a protein necessary for platelet adhesion, platelet aggregation, and stabilization of factor VIII.

Option 3- Bernard-Soulier disease is an autosomal recessive condition that is characterized by the absence of the GpIb receptor necessary for platelet adhesion to the subendothelial collagen. 

Option 4- Glanzmann's thrombasthenia is an autosomal recessive condition that is characterized by the absence of the GpIIb/IIIa receptor necessary for platelet aggregation.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with thyroid swelling. Blood tests show elevated TSH levels and the presence of thyroid peroxidase antibodies. Histopathological examination revealed the presence of Hurthle ​cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Hurthle cells are seen in Hashimoto thyroiditis.

Hashimoto thyroiditis is an autoimmune disease, characterized by the gradual destruction of the thyroid gland leading to thyroid failure. It is commonly seen in females between 45 to 65 years of age. It is caused by the presence of circulating autoantibodies against thyroglobulin and thyroid peroxidase in the vast majority of Hashimoto patients.

Morphologically, there is a diffuse enlargement of the thyroid gland, with an intact capsule. It is well demarcated from the adjacent structures.

Microscopic features include:

  • Intense lymphocytic infiltrate containing small lymphocytes, plasma cells, and well developed germinal centers.
  • Atrophied thyroid follicles, lined by epithelial cells, which contain eosinophilic granular cytoplasm. These epithelial cells are referred to as Hurthle cells.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with major depressive disorder was prescribed escitalopram. Which of the following adverse effects is least likely to occur?
questions.solution:
Sialorrhea is not a side effect of escitalopram.

Escitalopram is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI). SSRIs are associated with dry mouth, and not sialorrhea.

Sexual Anorgasmia, Decreased libido
Gastrointestinal ( 5-HT3 receptor) Nausea, Diarrhea, Anorexia, Vomiting, Flatulence, and Dyspepsia
Nervous system Extremely vivid dreams or nightmares, Anxiety, Insomnia/sedation, Seizures, Emotional blunting
Anticholinergic Dry mouth, Constipation, Sedation
Cardiovascular Drug induced long QT syndrome
Hematological Easy bruising
Endocrine Mammoplasia, Galactorrhea

questions.text: The most important source of reducing equivalents for fatty acid synthesis in the liver is
questions.solution:
The most important source of reducing equivalents (NADPH) for fatty acid synthesis in the liver is the hexose monophosphate shunt pathway (HMP) pathway.

Since HMP shunt pathway and fatty acid synthesis both occur in the cytosol of the cell, there are no membranes or permeability barriers against the transfer of NADPH. This NADPH is involved as a donor of reducing equivalents in both the reduction of the 3-ketoacyl and of the 2,3-unsaturated acyl derivatives. 

Other sources are:

  • Extramitochondrial isocitrate dehydrogenase (minor source)
  • Malic enzyme

questions.text: Breast milk is superior to cow’s milk because ________

choices.text: Casein is 60% of the protein content
Whey is 70% of the protein content

questions.solution:
Whey constitutes 70-80% of breast milk's protein content. The Whey: Casein ratio in human milk fluctuates between 70:30 and 80:20. This ratio is 20:80 in cow's milk. The high fraction of soluble whey protein in breast milk makes it easily digestible.

The predominant whey protein is α-lactalbumin in human milk and β-globulin in cow milk. Human milk contains amino acids like taurine and cysteine (lacking in cow’s milk), which are necessary for neurotransmission and neuromodulation.

Breast milk is rich in polyunsaturated fat (not saturated fat), which is necessary for myelination. Human breast milk is generally rich in oleic acid and linoleic acid.

Sodium concentration is not high in breast milk. It has a low osmolality, and hence, the solute load on the kidneys is low.

Differences between human milk and cow's milk are shown below:

Nutrient Human milk (per 100 mL) Cow's milk (per 100 mL)
Protein 1.1 g 3.5 g
Calories 67 kcal 73 kcal
Casein 30–40% (rich in whey protein) 80%
Lactose 7.4 g 4.5 g
Fat  3.5 g 4g

K+ (mEq/L) 14 35
Osmolality (mOsm/L) 290 350
calcium/phosphate >2 <2
Vitamin K 1.5 µg 6 µg
Iron 0.29–0.45 mg 0.01-0.38 mg
Vitamin D 0.5-10 IU 0.5-4.5 IU

questions.text: A 65-year-old female with type 2 diabetes mellitus ingested an unknown quantity of metformin. On biochemical examination, her lactate levels are raised. What is the type of lactic acidosis encountered here?
questions.solution:
Metformin (biguanide) toxicity encountered here is a Type B lactic acidosis.

Lactic acidosis is defined as an increase in plasma lactate levels. The various types of L-lactic acidosis are:

  • Type A - This occurs secondary to poor tissue perfusion. The conditions include shock, cardiac failure, severe anemia, carbon monoxide, or cyanide toxicity.
  • Type B - This type of lactic acidosis occurs in aerobic disorders. It can occur secondary to malignancies, renal failure, hepatic failure, drugs like metformin, ethanol, ethylene glycol, and methanol, diabetes mellitus, seizures, Severe malaria/ cholera etc .

Note: A D-lactic acidosis is an unusual form of metabolic acidosis that occurs in patients with short bowel syndrome, post-jejunoileal bypass, or intestinal obstruction. This is due to the formation of D-lactate by gut bacteria.

Related Pearl: Causes of Metabolic Acidosis

questions.text: The given image depicts:
questions.solution:
The given image depicts a frequency polygon. It is used mainly for ratio and interval scale data. In a frequency polygon, the mid-points of each class interval are joined together by straight lines.

Other options: 

Option A: Line graph is also called a line diagram or line chart. Its best use is to show the trend of events or change over passage of time.

The image below represents a line graph.

Option B: Ogive is a frequency polygon which is drawn to represent cumulative frequency distributions form a typical S-shaped curve. It referred to as a cumulative frequency diagram.
The image given below is of Ogive.

Option D: Histogram is a graphical representation of frequency distribution that contains rectangles and shows the underlying frequency of a set of continuous, quantitative data.
The X or horizontal axis is called the abscissa which usually has the group scores or class intervals of the variables/data and the Y or vertical axis is called the ordinate which usually shows the frequencies at which these variables appear.

The following image shows a histogram.

Related Pearl: Graphical Representation of Data

1. Histogram

  • A histogram, by definition, is a graphical representation of frequency distribution that contains rectangles and shows the underlying frequency of a set of continuous, quantitative data.
  • The X or horizontal axis is called the abscissa which usually has the group scores or class intervals of the variables/data and the Y or vertical axis is called the ordinate which usually shows the frequencies at which these variables appear.
  • The following image shows a histogram.

2. Bar Chart

  • It is also called a bar graph.
  • It is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data as they are not quantitative and usually qualitative.
  • The difference between a bar graph and a histogram is that the rectangles are separated by spaces representing data that forms discrete categories instead of continuous groups.
  • Bar graphs can be simple, multiple or component bar graphs.

3. Pie Charts

  • Pie charts are also used for nominal or ordinal data.
  • The categorical data are represented as segments of a circle.

4. Frequency polygons

  • Frequency polygons are used for mainly ratio and interval scale data.
  • In a frequency polygon, the mid-points of each class interval are joined together by straight lines.

5. Ogive

  • A frequency polygon which is drawn to represent cumulative frequency distributions form a typical S-shaped curve which is called an ogive. It referred to as a cumulative frequency diagram.

6. Line chart

  • It is also called a line diagram or line graph.
  • Its best use is to show the trend of events or change over passage of time.

questions.text: A silver-stained section of the cerebral cortex shows numerous cells of the type shown below. Which of the following cells could they most likely be?
questions.solution:
Since the silver-stained section of the cerebral cortex shows a triangular cell with a broad base, it is likely to be a pyramidal cell.

Pyramidal cells have a triangular shape, with a broad base from which a single axon and many basilar dendrites emerge. A single apical trunk usually projects from the apex. The apices of these cells orient towards the pial surface of the cortex.

Pyramidal cells of Betz are larger pyramidal cells seen in the precentral gyrus. They measure up to 120 μm.

Pyramidal cells are the most abundant type of cortical neurons. Their fibers give rise to the corticospinal tract. 

Nerve cells present in the cerebral cortex include:

  • Pyramidal cells
  • Stellate cells or granule cells
  • Fusiform cells
  • Horizontal cells of Cajal
  • Cells of Martinotti

Other options:

Options A and B: Purkinje cells and Golgi cells are found in the cerebellum. Purkinje cells have flask-shaped cell bodies with axons containing efferent fibers of the cerebellar cortex. Golgi cells are large, stellate cells lying in the granular layer of the cerebellum with dendrites that branch extensively and are located deep in the Purkinje cells. 

Option D: Glomus cells are neuroendocrine cells found in the carotid body. Like neurons, they too have dendritic processes and cytoplasm containing numerous membrane-bound granules.

Related Pearl: Cerebellar Circuitary

Cerebellar circuitry includes:

Afferents- Climbing and mossy fibers

  • Climbing fibers -
    • Origin - contralateral inferior olivary nucleus in the medulla oblongata
    • Terminates on - Purkinje cell
  • Mossy fibers -
    • Origin - multiple sources in the spinal cord and brainstem
    • Terminates on - Granule cell

Intrinsic components

  • Granule cell backward inhibition - done by Golgi cells- prevent transmission from mossy fibers to the granule cells
  • Purkinje cells forward inhibition- done by stellate and basket cells

Efferents -

  • The output from the cerebellar cortex - from Purkinje cells inhibitory output to the deep cerebellar nuclei
  • The output from the cerebellum - from deep cerebellar nuclei
    • Globose, emboliform, and dentate - via superior cerebellar peduncle
    • Fastigial - via inferior cerebellar peduncle

questions.text: An elderly diabetic female patient presented with a black, foul-smelling discharge from the nose. On examination, a blackish necrotic mass is seen filling the nasal cavity and eroding the septum and hard palate. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Mucormycosis.

Diabetic patients with local tissue destruction with blackish nasal discharge typically resembles the presentation of invasive mucormycosis. The blackish discolouration is due to direct fungal invasion causing arterial and venous thrombosis leading to gangrene. Mucormycosis is an opportunistic infection caused principally by species of Rhizopus, Mucor, and Lichtheimia. The most prevalent species is Rhizopus Oryza. 

Risk factors:

  • Diabetes (Diabetic ketoacidosis).
  • Immunocompromised individuals

Treatment:

  • Intravenous administration of amphotericin B is the treatment of choice for invasive mucormycosis.
  • Surgical debridement
  • Control of underlying predisposing causes.

Other options:

Option A: Invasive aspergillosis leads to the formation of black or greyish membrane in the nasal mucosa. The maxillary sinus may contain a fungus ball containing semisolid cheesy-white or blackish material.

Option C: Foreign body nose presents with foul-smelling unilateral discharge.

Option D: Rhinosporidiosis is a granulomatous condition caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi and presents with nasal discharge, epistaxis, and nasal obstruction by a polypoidal mass.

questions.text: Which of the following should be the treatment of choice for renal cell carcinoma with tumor less than 4 cm in size?
questions.solution:
Partial nephrectomy (also known as nephron-sparing surgery) is performed for tumors less than 4 cm in size. It is also performed for:

  • Bilateral RCC
  • Carcinoma affecting a solitary functioning kidney
  • RCC in one kidney and hydronephrosis or calculi in the contralateral kidney

Recently, partial nephrectomy is also increasingly being performed for stage T1b tumors. 

Radical nephrectomy is indicated in:

  • Large tumors
  • When partial nephrectomy is not feasible 

RCC is a radio and chemoresistant tumor.

Cryoablation is indicated in the T1a stage of RCC if surgery cannot be performed. It is also indicated in advanced/ metastatic tumors. 

Debulking surgery has a role in patients with distant metastasis. mTOR inhibitors such as Everolimus, IL-2 agents, sunitinib, and sorafenib have also been found to be useful as adjuvant therapy in RCC.

Note: Sunitinib and sorafenib are also used in GIST and hepatocellular carcinoma.

questions.text: A 12-month-old child was brought to the hospital with complaints of fever and difficulty in breathing. On examination, the child had biphasic stridor. The lesion in which of the following level will produce this type of stridor?
questions.solution:
Obstructive lesions at the level of glottis, subglottis (B), and cervical trachea will cause Biphasic stridor.

Stridor is a noisy respiration produced by turbulent airflow through the narrowed air passages. It may be heard during inspiration, expiration or both.

  • Inspiratory stridor is often produced in obstructive lesions of supraglottis or pharynx, e.g. laryngomalacia or retropharyngeal abscess.
  • Biphasic stridor is seen in lesions of glottis, subglottis, and cervical trachea, e.g. laryngeal papillomas, vocal cord paralysis, and subglottic stenosis.
  • Expiratory stridor is produced in lesions of thoracic trachea, primary and secondary bronchi, e.g. bronchial foreign body, and tracheal stenosis.

Related Pearl: Acute stridor/ Noisy breathing

Stridor indicates an upper airway problem. Look for a history of foreign body aspiration and signs of toxicity.

Important differentials:

Condition  Findings
Croup

Non-toxic, viral prodrome, barking cough

X-ray neck shows steeple sign
Epiglottitis

Toxic child, drooling saliva

Lateral X-ray neck shows thumb sign
Diphtheria Cervical lymph nodes (bull neck), dirty grey/ white membrane, and un-immunized
Foreign body aspiration Choking, decreased air entry, unilateral hyperinflation

questions.text: An intern placed an intercostal drainage tube in a patient. Which of the following steps is incorrect?

choices.text: Identified 5th intercostal space anterior to mid axillary line to place the tube
Inserted tube along the lower border of upper rib
Directed tube posteriorly to prevent injury

questions.solution:
Intercostal tube is placed along the upper border of the lower rib, in order to prevent damage to the neurovascular bundle.

An intercostal tube connected to an underwater seal is central to the management of chest disease.

The safest site for insertion of a drain is in the triangle (Triangle of safety) that lies:

  • Anterior to the mid-axillary line
  • Above the level of the nipple
  • Below and lateral to the pectoralis major muscle.

This will ideally find the fifth space.

The technique includes the following:

  • Meticulous attention to sterility throughout.
  • Adequate local anesthesia to include the pleura.
  • Sharp dissection to cut only the skin.
  • Blunt dissection with artery forceps down through the muscle layers, these should only be the serratus anterior and the intercostals.
  • An oblique tract, so that the skin incision and the hole in the parietal pleura do not overlie each other.
  • Drain is placed in a short tunnel to reduce the chance of entraining air.
  • A drain for pneumothorax and haemothorax should aim towards the apex of the lung. A drain for pleural effusion or empyema should be nearer the base. The drain should pass over the upper border of the rib to avoid the neurovascular bundle that lies beneath the rib. The retaining stitch should be secure but should not obliterate the drain.
  • A vertical mattress suture is inserted for later wound closure. This is vital for pneumothorax management but should be omitted if the drain is for empyema (provided there is adherence of the pleura) because that tract should lie open.
  • Connect the drain to an underwater seal device which functions as a one-way valve.
  • After completion, check that the drain has achieved its objective by taking a chest radiograph.

questions.text: Which of the following viruses has been depicted in the image?
questions.solution:
The image shows a filamentous virus, hence, it is most likely to be the Ebola virus. 

Option A: Corona virus has petal/club-shaped peplomers radiating like sunrays.

 

Option B: Adenovirus is space-vehicle shaped.

 

Option D: Rabies virus is bullet shaped.

Related Pearl: Important Shapes of Some Viruses

VIRUS

SHAPE
