questions.text: You notice the following appearance in the X-Ray of a patient.  Which of the following conditions is the least likely cause for this?
questions.solution:
The X-ray is characteristic of Pneumoperitoneum which is not seen in Acute intestinal obstruction.

  • The erect X-ray shows gas under both the diaphragms, and the most important cause for this is a hollow viscus perforation.
  • An intestinal obstruction would show multiple dilated loops on X-ray with possible air-fluid levels. Only when the obstruction becomes severe and there is perforation, pneumoperitoneum occurs.
  • Causes other than perforation are:
    • Chilaiditi syndrome (where the intestine is seen between the liver and diaphragm giving a false impression of free air)
    • Sub-phrenic abscess
    • Postoperatively air may be present in the abdomen up to 7 days

Other signs in pneumoperitoneum:

  • Rigler’s sign: The outer and inner walls of the bowel loop are delineated by gas
  • Football sign/ Air dome sign: A central round air collection seen on a supine x-ray
  • Inverted V sign: Gas is seen on either side of the umbilical ligament

Note:

In an emergency setting, where a patient presents with peritonitis and Xray abdomen confirming pneumoperitoneum, an emergency laparotomy is undertaken to manage the bowel perforation.

questions.text: You are a medical practitioner in a remote rural area, you remove a worm from a patient as shown below by rolling it over a stick. The worm that you are removing by this procedure is ____.
questions.solution:
The given image shows the way Guinea worm(Dracunculiasis) is removed by rolling them out over a small stick.

Dracunculiasis/Guinea worm disease is a vector-borne parasitic disease caused by Dracunculus medinenesis. Transmission occurs by consumption of water containing cyclops harbouring infective stages of the parasite. This disease is totally a water-based disease and has no alternate way of transmission.

The life cycle of Guinea worm:

Guinea-worm disease is amenable to eradication. 

  • Worms are removed by sequentially rolling them out over a small stick.
  • Wet compresses may relieve discomfort. Occlusive dressings improve hygiene and limit shedding of infectious larvae.
  • No drug cures the infection but metronidazole and mebendazole are sometimes used to limit inflammation and facilitate worm removal.
    • Provision of safe drinking water (e.g., piped water, installation of hand pumps).
    • Control of cyclops
  • Health education of the public in matters relating to boiling or sieving drinking water through a double thickness cotton cloth for personal protection, and prevention of water contamination by infected persons.
  • Surveillance: Active search for new cases.

questions.text: A patient presented to the OPD with complaints of abdominal pain and diarrhea.  On further evaluation, the patient was found to have cutaneous flushing, extensive wheeze, and tricuspid insufficiency. Contrast enhanced-MRI revealed the presence of endocardial fibrosis. Which of the following substances will be excreted excessively in this patient?
questions.solution:
5-hydroxy indole acetic acid (5-HIAA) will be excreted excessively in the above given clinical scenario, as this is a case of carcinoid syndrome.

Carcinoid syndrome is due to excessive production of serotonin, a specialized product of tryptophan metabolism. It is then metabolized and excreted in urine as 5-HIAA. It is characterized by cutaneous flushing, abdominal cramps, and diarrhoea. 

Note:

5-HIAA testing is a 24-hour urine test that is specific to carcinoid tumours. This test is the most common biochemical test for carcinoid tumours associated with carcinoid syndrome.

Related Pearl: Carcinoid syndrome

questions.text: A factory worker with tuberculosis was started on DOTS (directly observed treatment short course) and is advised to rest. He earns Rs 20,000/- as a monthly income and is eligible for the extended sickness benefit under the Employees State Insurance Act scheme.  This patient will get the benefit for:
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the patient is diagnosed to have tuberculosis, and thus he is eligible for the extended sickness benefit of the ESI scheme. 

Extended sickness benefit is the leave given up to a maximum period of two years. The diseases for which extended sickness benefits are applied are TB, leprosy, empyema, HIV, malignancies, plegias, etc. During this period, 80 per cent of the wages are paid.

ESI act was amended to provide cash and medical benefits to employees during sickness, maternity, and employment injury. People with monthly earnings up to 21,000 are covered under this scheme. Cash benefits are made through branches and cash offices. The medical benefits are made available through ESI dispensaries, clinics, hospitals, etc. The benefits provided to the insured persons are:

  • Medical benefits - Complete medical care is provided to the insured person and his/ her family members.
  • Sickness benefits - include a periodic cash payment for 91 days to the insured sick person. 70% of the average daily wages is given as the daily rate if the person is under medical treatment. 
  • Enhanced sickness benefit - includes 14 days of leave given for tubectomy and 7 days of leave for vasectomy. The amount payable is equal to the full wages.
  • Maternity benefits - cash payments equal to full wages are paid to the insured person for up to 26 weeks in cases of pregnancy.
  • Disablement benefit - cash payment and free medical treatment are given for temporary or permanent disablements and occupational diseases.
  • Dependant's benefit - if an employment injury causes the death of the insured person, the dependants are eligible for periodic payments.
  • Funeral expenses of Rs 15000 are payable to the dependants.
  • Rehabilitation allowance - the insured person and the family members continue to get medical treatment after permanent disablement and retirement.

Note: Directly observed treatment short course (DOTS) is an effective treatment strategy used for tuberculosis. In the intensive phase of the treatment, the patient swallows the drug in the presence of a healthcare worker. During the continuation phase, medicine is issued for a week and only the first dose is swallowed in the presence of a health worker.

questions.text: A man continues to call women, and achieves sexual gratification by talking obscenity and sharing obscene pictures. This condition is termed as ________.
questions.solution:
Telephone and computer scatology- it involves obscene phone calling or sending of inappropriate videos/images to an unsuspecting person.

Paraphilias or perversions are sexual stimuli or acts that are deviations from normal sexual behaviors but are necessary for some people to experience arousal and orgasm.

Important paraphilic disorders are:

  • Exhibitionism- Urge to expose genitals to a stranger or unsuspecting person.
  • Fetishism- It is the use of objects for sexual gratification. Eg. shoes, gloves, pantyhose, and stockings. The objects can be used to attain gratification directly or the person may ask the partner to wear them during sexual intercourse.
  • Frotteurism- is usually characterized by a man's rubbing his penis against the buttocks or other body parts of a fully clothed woman to achieve orgasm.
  • Pedophilia- involves recurrent intense sexual urges or arousal by children less than 13 years of age over a period of at least 6 months.
  • Masochism- takes its name from the activities of Leopold von Sacher-Masoch, a novelist whose characters derived sexual pleasure from being abused and dominated by women.
  • Sexual sadism- The person attains sexual arousal from the physical and psychosocial suffering of another person.
  • Voyeurism- It is also called scoptophilia. The person has an urge to watch an unsuspecting person naked or in sexual activity.
  • Transvestism- Fantasies and sexual urge to dress in opposite gender clothing.
  • Telephone and computer scatology- it involves obscene phone calling or sending of video images to an unsuspecting partner. 
  • Necrophilia- it is an obsession with obtaining sexual gratification from dead bodies
  • Zoophilia- having an urge to involve in sexual activity like intercourse, masturbation, or oral-genital contact with an animal.
  • Coprophilia- Sexual pleasure associated with a desire to defecate on the partner or to be defected on.
  • Urophilia- the sexual pleasure associated with the desire to urinate on a partner or to be urinated on.
  • Hypoxyphilia- is the desire to achieve an altered state of consciousness secondary to hypoxia while experiencing orgasm. They may use volatile nitrite or nitrous oxide to produce hypoxia.

questions.text: A 14 year old girl presents to the emergency room with fracture forearm and says she has tripped and fell. On examination you notice multiple cigarette burns on her forearm. What will you do next?
questions.solution:
A child who has been physically abused should undergo a thorough physical examination at first.

This should be followed by a psychiatric interview.

When the child is brought to the emergency room, a detailed and spontaneous account of the injury should be obtained promptly from parents or other caregivers before secondary details and rationalizations cloud the information provided.

questions.text: Effacement of podocyte foot processes is seen in which of the following diseases?
questions.solution:
Effacement of the podocyte foot processes is characteristically seen in minimal change disease (MCD), which is also called lipoid nephrosis.

 

Minimal change disease is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children. It is more common in males and appears between 2 to 6 years of age.

The causes of MCD are mostly idiopathic. It is usually associated with Hodgkin's lymphoma (due to the increased production of cytokines), respiratory infections, prophylactic immunizations, eczema, and rhinitis.

Clinically, they mostly present with proteinuria. The child presents with a history of edema that is initially noted around the eyes and gradually progresses into generalized edema. Hypertension and hematuria are uncommon.

Levels of the following proteins are increased in nephrotic syndrome:

  • Fibrinogen - leads to hypercoagulability.
  • Lipoproteins - due to increased synthesis.

Levels of the following proteins are decreased in nephrotic syndrome as a consequence of selective proteinuria:

  • Albumin—the protein with the largest proportion of loss in nephrotic syndrome
  • Transferrin
  • Cholecalciferol-binding protein
  • Thyroxine-binding globulin (TBG)
  • Ferritin
  • Coagulation factors 
  • Antithrombin III

Diagnosis can be made by urinalysis showing proteinuria, ranging from 3+ to 4+ protein on urine dipstick and a spot urine protein/creatinine ratio (PCR) >2. The proteinuria principally contains albumin, hence known as selective proteinuria. Serum albumin levels are <2.5 g/dL and there is an increase in serum cholesterol and triglyceride levels. 

Biopsy findings include the following: 

  • Light microscopy- glomeruli appear normal (hence called "minimal change")
  • Immunofluorescence studies- no Ig or complement deposits
  • Electron microscopy- diffuse effacement of foot processes of visceral epithelial cells/podocytes

The majority of children will respond to corticosteroid (prednisone/prednisolone) treatment and will achieve complete remission (urine PCR<0.2 or <1+ protein on urine dipstick).

Related Pearl: Glomerular Pathology in Renal Diseases

Disease

 Light microscopy Fluorescence microscopy

Electron microscopy

Nephritic syndrome:

Postinfectious glomerulo-nephritis

Diffuse endocapillary proliferation; leukocytic infiltration

Granular IgG and C3 in glomerular basement membrane and mesangium, 

Granular IgA in some cases

 

Subepithelial humps (between the basement membrane and overlying epithelial cells) Subendothelial deposits in early disease stages

Goodpasture syndrome

 Extracapillary proliferation with crescents; necrosis  Linear IgG and C3; fibrin in crescents

Linear deposits of immunoglobulins along the basement membrane. 

Disruptions in GBM

IgA nephropathy (Berger disease)

 Focal mesangial proliferative glomerulo-nephritis; mesangial widening  IgA ± IgG, IgM, and C3 in mesangium Mesangial and paramesangial dense deposits 

Alport syndrome

 Normal Negative Basket-weave appearance of GBM

Nephrotic syndrome:

Membranous  nephropathy

Diffuse capillary wall thickening

Granular IgG and C3; diffuse

 

Subepithelial deposits (epimembranous spikes), effacement of podocyte foot processes.

Minimal change disease

Normal; lipid in tubules

 Negative 

No deposits.

Effacement of podocyte foot processes.

Focal segmental glomerulo-sclerosis  (FSGS)

Glomerular hyalinosis and sclerosis

 Occasional C3 and IgM deposits in the sclerotic areas and the mesangium.

No deposits.

Effacement of podocyte foot processes.

Epithelial denudation.

Nephrito-nephrotic syndrome:   

Membrano-proliferative glomerulo-nephritis

(MPGN) type I

Mesangial proliferative or membrano-proliferative patterns of proliferation; GBM thickening; splitting

IgG ++ C3; C1q ++ C4

 

Subendothelial deposits

Dense-deposit disease (MPGN type II)

Mesangial proliferative or membrano-proliferative patterns of proliferation; GBM thickening; splitting

C3; no C1q or C4

 

Intramembranous Dense deposits

Fibrillary glomerulo-nephritis

  

Membrano-proliferative or mesangio-proliferative patterns

 IgG4 and C3  Fibrillar deposits in the mesangium and glomerular capillary walls

 

Note:

  • Anionic antigens form subendothelial deposits.
  • Cationic antigens form subepithelial deposits.
  • Neutral antigens form mesangial deposits.

 

Image – Linear, smooth diffuse pattern of staining for IgG in Goodpasture syndrome:

questions.text: A newborn presents to the outpatient department with a history of noisy breathing. Upon performing direct laryngoscopy, specific findings are observed. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the stridor in this infant?

choices.text: Increases in prone position and subsides on crying
Subsides on prone position and increases with crying
Subsides both on crying and prone position
Increases with both prone position and crying

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the laryngoscopy image showing omega-shaped epiglottis is suggestive of laryngomalacia. Inspiratory stridor is seen in laryngomalacia.

Laryngomalacia is the most common congenital cause of stridor. It is characterized by excessive flaccidity of the supraglottic larynx which is sucked in during inspiration. This results in inspiratory stridor, a feature typical of laryngomalacia.

It presents just after birth and subsides by 2 years of age. Stridor is increased on crying but improves (decreases) in the prone position, and worsens during feeding or crying. The cry is normal.

Direct laryngoscopy shows an elongated epiglottis that is curled upon itself, making it appear omega (Ω)-shaped. Other features include floppy aryepiglottic folds and prominent arytenoids.

Stridor is noisy respiration produced by turbulent airflow through narrowed air passages. Stridor may be heard during inspiration, expiration or both

  • Inspiratory stridor- e.g., laryngomalacia or retropharyngeal abscess.
  • Expiratory stridor- e.g. bronchial foreign body, and tracheal stenosis.
  • Biphasic stridor- e.g. laryngeal papillomas, vocal cord paralysis, and subglottic stenosis.

Treatment of Laryngomalacia:

  • Mostly, it self corrects by 2 years of age.
  • Tracheostomy may be required for some cases of severe respiratory obstruction.
  • Supraglottoplasty is required in cases of severe laryngomalacia.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with obesity, metabolic syndrome, and renal failure presents with excruciating joint pain associated with localized hyperemia and warmth involving ankles, heels, and knees.  Aspirate from the joint shows dense neutrophilic infiltrate and crystals seen under polarised light are as  shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is gout. Aspirate from the joint shows dense neutrophilic infiltrate and crystals which are long, slender, needle-shaped, and negatively birefringent

Gout is marked by transient attacks of acute arthritis initiated by crystallization of monosodium urate within and around joints.

Gout can be classified into primary and secondary forms.

The inflammation in gout is triggered by precipitation of monosodium urate (MSU) crystals into the joints, which results in the production of cytokines that recruit leukocytes.

Macrophages phagocytose the MSU and the inflammasome activates caspase-1, which is involved in the production of some biologically active cytokines.

IL-1 is pro-inflammatory and promotes accumulation of neutrophils and macrophages in the joint

The distinctive morphologic changes in gout are (1) acute arthritis,(2) chronic tophaceous arthritis, (3) tophi in various sites, and (4) gouty nephropathy

Tophi are the pathognomonic hallmark of gout- large aggregations of urate crystals surrounded by an intense inflammatory reaction of foreign body giant cells which may appear in the articular cartilage, ligaments, tendons, and bursae, earlobes, fingertips, or kidneys.

Gouty nephropathy refers to the renal complications caused by MSU crystals or tophi in the renal medullary interstitium or tubules. Complications include uric acid nephrolithiasis and pyelonephritis.

Gout has been known since antiquity. Historically, it was referred to as "the disease of kings/rich man's disease" because of the lavish diet and alcohol consumption of the wealthy.

Related Pearl: Difference between Gout and Pseudo-gout

Finding

Gout

Pseudogout

Crystal composition

Uric acid

Calcium pyrophosphate

Shape

Needle like

Rhomboid

Birefringence pattern

Negative

Weak positive

Most commonly affected joint

1st MTP

Knee

X-ray findings

Periarticular erosions with overhanging margins

Chondrocalcinosis

questions.text: Which of the following drugs causes the below condition?
questions.solution:
The image shows blackening of tongue. Colloidal bismuth subsalicylate is known to cause blackening of tongue, dentures, and stools.

It combines with trace amounts of sulfur in saliva and colon to form bismuth sulfide. Bismuth sulfide is a highly insoluble black salt.The adverse effects are temporary and harmless.

Colloidal bismuth subsalicylate:

  • It is a foaming agent which protects gastric mucosa against H.Pylori.
  • Bismuth coats ulcers and erosions thereby creating a protective layer against acid and pepsin.

Uses:

  • Peptic ulcer disease
  • Traveler's diarrhea - It has antimicrobial properties and exerts a neutralizing effect on the enterotoxins.
  • Anti-secretory agent in diarrhea - It reduces stool frequency and helps form a bulk. 

Side-effects:

  • Blackening of tongue
  • Blackening of stools
  • Rarely toxicity manifesting as encephalopathy
  • Should be used in caution in patients with renal insufficiency. 
  • Should be avoided in patients and children with Chicken pox or fever, as it can cause or precipitate Reye's syndrome.
  • Tinnitus is a notable side-effect when co-administered with aspirin. 

Other causes of the black tongue:

1. Chronic cocaine poisoning (cocainism or cocainophagia) may present with

  • Black tongue and teeth
  • Ulceration and perforation of the nasal septum
  • Persecuting delusions
  • Magnan symptom

2. Red wine consumption

Important risk factors for the development of peptic ulcer disease are:

  • H. pylori infection
  • Use of NSAIDs
  • Cigarette smoking

questions.text: A 35-year-old male with chronic bacterial prostatitis was treated with cotrimoxazole.  He developed malaise, jaundice, abdominal pain, and dark urine. The blood picture is given below. The most likely diagnosis is  __________
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in the above case scenario is glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency.

The clinical features are suggestive of an acute hemolytic reaction following administration of cotrimoxazole. A hemolytic attack starts with abrupt onset of malaise, weakness, and abdominal or lumbar pain. After an interval of several hours to 2–3 days, the patient develops jaundice and often dark urine, due to hemoglobinuria. 

The peripheral smear shows characteristic "bite cells" or degmacytes or blister cells. In G6PD deficiency uncontrolled oxidative stress causes hemoglobin to denature and form Heinz bodies. Bite cells result from the removal of Heinz bodies by macrophages in the spleen.

Cotrimoxazole contains sulfamethoxazole which triggers a hemolytic reaction in persons with G6PD deficiency.

Other options:

  • The hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) is a triad of microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and acute kidney injury which commonly occurs following gastroenteritis with E.Coli O157: H7.
  • Autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA) and PNH are not precipitated by exposure to cotrimoxazole. AIHA maybe secondary to SLE, lymphomas, EBV, CMV or Mycoplasma infections. Stress and infections can precipitate PNH.

Drugs that carry risk of clinical hemolysis in persons with G6PD Deficiency:

Drugs

Antimalarials

Primaquine

Chloroquine

Dapsone/chlorproguanil

Sulphonamides/

sulphones

Sulfamethoxazole

Sulfasalazine

Sulfisoxazole

Antibacterial/

antibiotics

Cotrimoxazole

Ciprofloxacin

Chloramphenicol

Nalidixic acid

Norfloxacin

Nitrofurantoin

Others

Naphthalene

Methylene blue

Rasburicase

questions.text: Sin of Gomorrah is:
questions.solution:
Buccal coitus is also known as sin of Gomorrah / Coitus Per Os.

The male genital organ is introduced into mouth of another male or female.

Teeth marks / abrasions on the penis, semen in the respiratory tract / stomach could be the clues to diagnosis. Buccal swabs are useful only upto 9 hours. Buccal coitus can lead to death by aspiration of semen or impaction of the penis in the hypopharynx.

Other options:

Option A: Sodomy is anal intercourse between 2 males or between a male and a female. 

Option C: Incest is sexual intercourse between man and woman who are related by blood or a certain degree of blood relationship.

Option D: Bestiality is the sexual intercourse of a human being with a lower animal.

questions.text: The low pressure receptors are ______

choices.text: Stimulated by atrial systole and diastole

questions.solution:
The low-pressure receptors are stimulated by atrial systole and diastole

The low-pressure receptors are those in the great veins, right and left atria and pulmonary vessels.
Atrial stretch receptors are of two types:

  • Type A: discharge primarily during atrial systole
  • Type B: discharge primarily during late diastole

Distension of the atrial walls→stimulation of atrial receptors → Vasodilation, fall in BP and increased heart rate.

questions.text: A 35-year-old HIV positive​ patient presents with mucosal lesions in the mouth as shown in the image below. On microscopy, budding yeasts and pseudohyphae are seen. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an HIV-positive person with mucosal lesion in the mouth and microscopy showing budding yeasts and pseudohyphae is suggestive of oral candidiasis.

Oral candidiasis or thrush is a patchy, pseudomembranous lesion that develops over the tongue, lips, gum or palate. It is composed of epithelial cells, yeasts, and pseudohyphae. The causative agent is usually Candida albicans.

It occurs in almost all individuals with AIDS. Other risk factors include hyperglycemia, cellular immunodeficiency, corticosteroids or antibiotics.

It is treated with topical nystatin, oral ketoconazole, or fluconazole.

Option B: Hairy leukoplakia is a wart-like growth on the tongue, caused by the Epstein-Barr virus. It is commonly seen as a white lesion on the lateral side of the tongue.

Option C: Lichen planus is a pruritic disease characterized by papules commonly seen over the flexor surfaces and trunk. Oral and vulvovaginal lesions may also occur. Oral lesions appear as lacy, white, and raised lesions.

Option D: Diphtheria is characterized by the presence of a grey pseudomembrane covering the tonsils and pharynx. It is caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

questions.text: Which is a component of homeostatic control system?
questions.solution:
Stimulus, receptor and effector are all components of a homeostatic control system.

Components of homeostasis include:

  • Stimulus - It is a detectable change in the internal or external environment, such as change in temperature.
  • Receptor - It detects environmental changes.
  • Integrating centre
  • Effector - It is an organ or cell that acts in response to a stimulus.

questions.text: The amount of sodium present in ReSoMal is ________
questions.solution:
Rehydration solution for malnourished (ReSoMal) contains 45 mmol/L of sodium.

Severely malnourished children have excess intracellular sodium (leaky cell membranes and reduced activity of the sodium–potassium pump). So, sodium intake should be reduced and a low-sodium oral rehydration solution (ReSoMal) is advised. Because severely malnourished children are deficient in potassium, ReSoMal contains extra potassium, as well as extra glucose or sucrose and selected minerals (Mg, Cu, Zn).

ReSoMal stands for Rehydration Solution for Malnutrition

Composition of ReSoMal and ORS

Component (mmol/L) Standard ORS ReSoMal
Glucose 75 (anhydrous) 125
Sodium 75 45
Potassium 20 40
Chloride 65 70
Citrate  10 7
Magnesium - 3
Zinc - 0.3
Copper - 0.045
Osmolality 245 300

ReSoMal is oral rehydration salts or ORS for severely malnourished children. It is used in in-patient centers for the treatment of children with severe acute malnutrition. ReSoMal contains a higher amount of glucose (125mmol/L) and a lower amount of sodium (45mmol/L) than the standard WHO-ORS.

Earlier it was used for correcting hypokalemia, and in lowering the risks of excess sodium and/or overhydration, in severely malnourished children with diarrhea. However, according to the recent guidelines of WHO, ReSoMal should not be given to a child who is suspected of having cholera/profuse watery diarrhea. There is no additional significant benefit to using hypo-osmolar ORS /ReSoMal in comparison with standard WHO ORS.

Guidelines for children with SAM and suspected/confirmed cholera are identical to those with non-cholera diarrhea other than the ORS used. Cholera is secretory diarrhea with high stool volume output and the current restrictive guidelines may therefore result in undertreatment of children with dehydration.

Related Pearl: Comparison between low-osmolar oral rehydration solution and ReSoMal

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the management of endometriosis?

choices.text: Primary surgery is preferred in infertile women because hormones delay pregnancy
Asymptomatic patients are observed over 6–8 months without any need of the infertility workup
Estrogen is the drug of choice for endometriosis
Not all symptomatic women need treatment

questions.solution:
Primary surgery is preferred in infertile women because hormones delay pregnancy. This is the only true statement.

Endometriosis is estrogen-dependent. Hence estrogen is not used in treatment.

Minimal asymptomatic cases are to be observed over 6–8 months and infertility in such cases should be investigated and treated if necessary.

All symptomatic women do need treatment.

Treatment of endometriosis:

Medical management

Minimal disease Moderate/Severe disease
DOC = NSAIDS DOC=GnRH agonist
OCPs (Pain with menstrual complaints) Progesterone (First drug to start)

Mnemonic to remember drugs used: GOLD GAP

  • G: GnRH analog
  • O: Oral contraceptive pills
  • L: Letrozole
  • D: Danazol
  • G: Gestrinone
  • A: Antiprogesterone-Mifepristone
  • P: Progesterone

Surgical management

  • Conservative surgery: Endometrial deposits are destroyed by electrocautery/laser.
  • Laparoscopic uterosacral nerve ablation (LUNA)
  • Radical surgery: Total hysterectomy with bilateral oopherectomy.

 Note:

  • Endometrioma is treated by laparoscopic management.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best non-invasive tool for assessing fetal anaemia?

choices.text: Middle cerebral artery doppler peak systolic velocity (MCA PSV)

questions.solution:
Middle Cerebral Artery Doppler peak systolic velocity (MCA PSV) is the best non-invasive way of monitoring fetal anemia.

MCA PSV is used for the monitoring of fetuses of Rh-negative sensitized mothers, and if it exceeds 1.5 MoM and the gestational age less than 34 or 35 weeks, fetal blood sampling followed by transfu­sion is considered.

Serial mea­surements of the peak systolic velocity of the fetal MCA is reliable, noninvasive, and the recommended test to detect fetal anemia. Blood gets shunted to the brain to maintain adequate oxy­genation. A rise in cardiac out­put and a fall in blood viscosity enhance the peak systolic velocity in the MCA.

The threshold value to identify fetuses with anemia is 1.5 multiples of the median (MoM) for gestational age and is 100% sensitive. 

For an MCA PSV between 1.0 and 1.5 MoM, weekly Doppler monitoring to be done. If MCA PSV exceeds 1.5 MoM and the gestational age is lesser than 34 or 35 weeks, fetal blood sampling followed by fetal transfusion to be done if needed. 

Beyond 34 weeks, the false-positive rate of MCA peak systolic velocity increases due to the normal increase in cardiac output that develops at this gestational age.

Middle cerebral artery velocimetry is more accurate than and has replaced amnionic fluid spectral analysis and is not associated with the risks of increased alloimmunization and amniocentesis. It is also applied clinically to evaluate fetal growth restriction.

 

Other Options:

Option A: Biophysical profile, aka Modified Manning score, is a screening test for uteroplacental insufficiency. The fetal CNS is highly sensitive to diminished oxygenation and helps plan the next course of action.

Option B: If the MCA peak systolic velocity > 1.5 MoM and the gestational age is <34 or 35 weeks, fetal blood sampling should be considered and followed by fetal transfu­sion if needed. But it will fall under invasive method.

Option C: Amniocentesis is the most common prenatal diagnostic procedure. It is performed using an aseptic technique, under direct sonographic guidance, using a 20–22 gauge spinal needle.Approximately 20 to 30 mL of fluid is collected for fetal karyotyping or chromosomal microarray analysis.

questions.text: What is occipitomental view with open mouth also known as?
questions.solution:
Occipitomental view with open mouth is also called as Water’s view.

Water's view: The patient’s head is positioned such that the nose and the chin touch the film while the X-rays are projected from backward. The mouth is usually kept open, which allows visualising the sphenoid sinus.

Structures seen in Water’s view are:

  • Maxillary sinuses (seen best)
  • Frontal sinuses
  • Sphenoid sinus (if the film is taken with open mouth)
  • Zygoma
  • Zygomatic arch
  • Nasal bone
  • Frontal process of maxilla
  • Superior orbital fissure
  • Intratemporal fossa

Related Pearl: Radiographic views of paranasal sinuses and mastoid

questions.text: An infant is brought to the OPD by parents for a well-baby checkup when you notice the following lesion. They say the lesion has been present since birth and has been decreasing in size. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The above image shows Mongolian spots.

Mongolian spots are blue or slate-grey macular lesions, with clearly defined margins, that appear over the presacral region (most common), posterior thighs, legs, back, and forearms.

These spots occur due to the presence of melanin-containing melanocytes in the dermis, which is arrested during the migration from neural crest cells to the epidermis. Therefore, these spots are congenital, and are easily distinguished from the bruises of child abuse. They are non-tender and do not rapidly change in color or size.

They usually fade away during the first year of life, and the parents should be reassured about this.

 Other options:

  • Salmon patch or naevus simplex is small, pink-colored macules that are commonly seen over glabella, eyelids, upper lip, and nuchal area. They are an ill-defined lesion, which develops due to vascular ectasia. (Note: The subungual oil droplets seen in nail psoriasis are also known as salmon patches).
  • Neonatal pustular melanosis is a congenital benign lesion characterized by evanescent superficial pustules, ruptured pustules with fine scales, and hyperpigmented macules. The pustular lesions last for 2-3 days, while the hyperpigmented macules may last for about 3 months.
  • Harlequin color change is a congenital lesion, usually seen in low-birth-weight infants where half of the body in the dependent portion turns red in color, while the other half of the body is pale. This occurs due to an imbalance in the autonomic vascular regulatory mechanism. Changing the infant's position causes a reversal of the pattern.

Related Pearl: Benign findings in a newborn

1. Erythema toxicum – small, white papules on an erythematous base that usually present on the face, trunk, and extremities. They contain eosinophils and may persist for a week. 

 

2. Mongolian spots – Slate-blue, demarcated areas of pigmentation seen over the buttocks and back. This is also called dermal melanocytosis. 

 

3. Pustular melanosis – Benign lesions seen predominantly in black neonates, contains neutrophils, and is present at birth as vesiculopustular eruption around the chin, neck, back, extremities, palms and soles.

 

4. Sebaceous Hyperplasia - White-Yellow papules on nose of a newborn due to hyperplastic sebaceous glands

 

5. Milia - Pearly opalescent white, epidermal inclusion cysts usually over the face.

 

6. Epstein Pearls - nests of epithelial cells, that appear as whitish/yellowish spots on hard palate. Usually, resolve by 3 months.

 

7. Cutis Marmorata - Transient lacy reticular vascular pattern of skin caused due to exaggerated physiologic vasomotor response on exposure to low environmental temperature.

 

8. Sucking Blisters - Solitary or scattered superficial bullae present at birth on the upper limbs of infants, which are caused by vigorous sucking on the affected part in-utero.

 

9. Salmon patch or naevus simplex - Small, ill-defined, pink-coloured macules commonly seen over glabella, eyelids, upper lip, and nuchal area, which develop due to vascular ectasia.

 

10. Harlequin colour change - A transient, well-demarcated colour change, with one half of the body displaying erythema and the other half pallor, usually occurring between two and five days of age.

 

11. Vaginal bleeding in the newborn at 2–3 days of age and enlargement and secretion of the breasts in both sexes.

12. Hymenal tags

13. Physiological phimosis

14. Conjunctival hemorrhage

15. Peeling of skin (especially in post terms)

questions.text: Personal monitoring of radiation is done by:
questions.solution:
Personal monitoring of radiation is done by a TLD badge.

TLD badge (thermoluminescent dosimeter) is made up of thium fluoride or dysprosium.

The badge should be positioned according to local or national practices. In India, one TLD badge has to be worn at the chest level inside the lead apron, if the apron is used. An additional wrist badge has to be worn for procedures requiring hands close to the primary beam. 

The given image shows a TLD badge.

questions.text: A G2P1 lady is in the latent phase of labor for 8 hours. The latent phase would be said to be prolonged in her if it lasts for more than _______________
questions.solution:
The latent phase is said to be prolonged in a multigravida if it lasts for more than 14 hours.

Friedman defined prolonged latent phase by:

  • A nullipara who has not entered the active phase by 20 hours after the onset of the latent phase
  • A multipara who has not entered the active phase by 14 hours after the onset of the latent phase 

The first stage of labor consists of two phases :

1) Latent phase: It is considered to begin at the time the woman first perceives regular uterine contractions and is characterized by gradual cervical change(upto 5 cm of cervical dilatation)

2) Active phase: Follows the latent phase, is characterized by rapid cervical change (3-6 cm)

Related Pearl: Abnormalities of first stage of labor

Labor pattern Criteria- Nullipara Criteria-Multipara Treatment
Prolonged latent phase >20 hrs >14hrs

Bed rest

Oxytocin or cesarean delivery 
Protraction of dilatation <1.2cm/hr 1.5cm/hr

Expectant management and support

Cesarean delivery for CPD
Protraction of descent <1cm/hr <2cm/hr
Secondary arrest of dilatation >2hr >2hr

Check for CPD:

If no CPD- administer oxytocin

If CPD present- cesarean delivery

 
Arrest of descent >1hr >1hr
 CPD- Cephalopelvic disproportion

questions.text: The lining epithelium of the respiratory tract of a middle-aged man who is a chronic smoker shows a change from columnar to stratified squamous epithelium, as depicted in the image below. The change is called?
questions.solution:
The change described in the question is called metaplasia.

Metaplasia is defined as a reversible change in which one type of differentiated cell is replaced by another type.

Examples of metaplasia include:

  • Columnar to squamous epithelium (also called squamous metaplasia):
    • This is the most common type of metaplasia, and is usually seen in the respiratory tract in cases of chronic smoking or sometimes in vitamin A deficiency,
    • It may also be present in cases where there are stones in the excretory ducts of salivary glands, pancreas, or bile ducts, where, the normal secretory columnar epithelium is replaced by stratified squamous epithelium.
  • Squamous to columnar epithelium (also called columnar metaplasia): It is seen in Barrett's oesophagus.
  • Connective tissue metaplasia: It refers to the formation of bone, cartilage, or adipose tissue in the tissues where they are normally absent. One such example is myositis ossificans, a condition where there is the formation of bone within the muscle.

questions.text: A man presents with a slowly progressive swelling over the past 1 and 1/2 years. On examination, it has a variable consistency and appears as shown in the image. What is the probable cause?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and image showing the swelling lifting the ear lobe is suggestive of pleomorphic adenoma.

Pleomorphic adenoma is a painless, slowly growing, benign tumor that usually affects females more than males. It most commonly arises from the superficial lobe. It is unicentric in origin with a pseudo-capsule present. It is a radioresistant tumor.

Clinical features:

  • Lobulated, firm, elastic-to-hard in consistency
  • Well-defined margins
  • Free from deeper structures
  • With no facial nerve involvement

In case of deep lobe involvement, tonsils and faucial pillars will be pushed medially.

All tumors of the superficial lobe of the parotid gland should be managed by superficial parotidectomy.

Related Pearl: Important points regarding salivary gland tumors

  • Most common neoplasm of the salivary gland: Pleomorphic adenoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common benign tumor of the salivary gland in children: Hemangioma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland in children: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the minor salivary glands: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Most common gland affected by pleomorphic adenomas: Parotid gland
  • Tumor of the salivary gland with perineural invasion: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Tumor that shows a hot spot in 99mTc scan: Warthin’s tumor

questions.text: You are evaluating the patency and function of the Eustachian tube in a patient with a right earache and ear block. Which of the following test you will not do?
questions.solution:
Stenger test is not used for the assessment of patency or function of the eustachian tube. It is used to detect malingering of hearing loss.

Tests of Eustachian tube patency:

  • Pneumatic otoscopy
  • Nasopharyngoscopy
  • Valsalva manoeuvre
  • ET catheterization
  • Politzer test.

Tests of Eustachian tube function:

  • Toynbee’s test
  • Tympanometry
  • Saccharine/dye tests in perforated ears
  • Sonotubometry.

questions.text: Cough on scratching the external acoustic canal is due to?
questions.solution:
Cough on scratching the external acoustic canal is due to the auricular branch of the vagus nerve (also called Arnold's nerve).

Ear-cough reflex (Otorespiratory reflex): The Arnold's nerve innervates the skin over a small part of the ear and external auditory canal. In patients with chronic cough, scratching or mechanical stimulation of ear leads to activation of Arnold's nerve, which evokes reflex cough.

Nerve supply of External auditory canal:

  • Anterior wall and roof - the auriculotemporal branch of the mandibular division of trigeminal nerve (CN V3).
  • Posterior wall and floor - the auricular branch of Vagus (Arnold's nerve). Cough response while cleaning the ear canal is mediated by the vagus which also supplies the larynx.
  • Posterior wall also receives sensory supply by the facial nerve (CN VII).
Nerve Derivation Region supplied

Greater/Great auricular nerve

Medial surface and posterior part of the lateral surface
Lesser occipital nerve

Some supply medial surface (eminetia concha)
Auriculotemporal nerve

Mandibular (V3)

 Tragus, crus of helix and adjacent helix
Facial (VII)   Small region in the root of concha and retroauricular groove

questions.text: Which of the following proteins is present in skeletal muscles, but absent in a smooth muscle?
questions.solution:
Actin, myosin, and tropomyosin are present in both skeletal muscle and smooth muscle. But troponin is absent and calmodulin is present in smooth muscle.

questions.text: A gasless abdomen is seen in:
questions.solution:
A gasless abdomen is seen in acute pancreatitis. 

Usually in normal persons, there are numerous loops of gas-containing small bowel located centrally in the abdomen. But, in some conditions like small bowel obstruction, fluid replaces the air-filled lumen. This appears as a paucity of gas on abdominal radiography and is known as a gasless abdomen. 

Patients with acute pancreatitis can have significant vomiting and diarrhea that may produce a gasless abdomen.

Other causes include:

  • Bowel ischemia
  • Congenital atresia
  • Ascites
  • Gastroenteritis
  • Large abdominal mass - due to displacement
  • Post-surgery following total colectomy, oesophagogastrectomy, gastrectomy, and low anterior resection
  • A paucity of small bowel gas may be a normal finding in some adults

questions.text: Which of the following is false according to Caldwell and Moloy classification of pelvis:

choices.text: Platypelloid pelvis: has AP diameter > transverse diameter
Gynecoid pelvis:  sacral angle greater than 90 degree
Anthropoid pelvis: high incidence of face to pubis delivery

questions.solution:
Platypelloid pelvis has a transverse diameter much larger than the anteroposterior diameter.

questions.text: Which among the following statements about strangulation is true?

choices.text: Abrasions and contusions around the ligature mark are rare
Injuries to muscles of neck is rare

questions.solution:
Strangulations are mostly homicidal.

Strangulation is a type of asphyxia where there is neck constriction without suspension of the body. The pressure on the neck is applied either by bare hands, a ligature, or by any other instrument. There is sudden and violent compression of the windpipe which causes immediate insensibility and death. 

When strangulation is done by using a ligature, like a constricting band or rope, it is called ligature strangulation. The constricting band is tightened by a force other than the victim's body weight. It is characterized by the ligature mark which is transverse and completely encircling the neck below the thyroid cartilage. There is no dribbling of saliva. Bleeding may be present in the ears, nose, and mouth. Thyroid cartilage fracture is commonly seen in strangulation. But the hyoid bond fracture is uncommon. Ligature and manual strangulations are mostly homicidal. Marks of violence are usually seen on other parts of the body. 

Related Pearl: Difference between strangulation by Ligature and Hanging

Trait

Hanging

Strangulation by ligature

Nature of death

Mostly suicidal

Mostly homicidal

Face

Usually pale and petechiae rare

Congested, livid and marked with petechiae

Tongue

Swelling and protrusion is less marked

Swelling and protrusion is more marked

Bleeding

Bleeding from nose, mouth and ears not common

Bleeding from nose, mouth and ears may be found

Saliva

Often dribbles out of the mouth

Such dribbling is very rare

Ligature mark

Oblique, non-continuous, placed high up in the neck between the chin and the larynx. 

The subcutaneous tissue underneath the mark is usually hard, white and glistening

Horizontal or transverse, continuous around the neck, low down in the neck below or across the thyroid.   

Subcutaneous tissue underneath may be ecchymosed

Abrasions and

ecchymoses

Rare

Common

Injury to muscles of

neck

Rare

Common

Carotid arteries

Internal coats usually ruptured in violent cases of a long drops(Amussat's sign)

Damage to internal coat is rare

Hyoid bone

Fracture of the hyoid bone less common

Fracture of the hyoid bone is uncommon (common in manual strangulation)

Thyroid cartilage

Fracture is less common

Fracture is more common

Cervical vertebrae

Fracture and/or dislocation common in judicial hanging

Fracture and/or dislocation—rare

questions.text: Which of the following tests helps to distinguish inflammatory bowel disease from irritable bowel syndrome?
questions.solution:
Assessment of fecal calprotectin levels helps to distinguish inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) from irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).

The fecal calprotectin and lactoferrin are elevated in inflammatory conditions like inflammatory bowel disease, but not in irritable bowel syndrome. Hence, they are often assessed to distinguish the two conditions. These tests are also done to check if the disease is active and to detect postoperative recurrence. Other features of IBD include elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP), hypoalbuminemia, anemia, and leukocytosis.

Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) is a functional disorder characterized by abdominal pain or discomfort and altered bowel habits in the absence of structural abnormalities. There are no clear diagnostic markers for IBS. The presence of anemia, elevated ESR, leukocytosis, bloody stool, or stool volume of more than 200 - 300 ml/day argues against the diagnosis of IBS. The diagnosis is mainly based on clinical presentation.

Related Pearl: ROME IV Diagnostic criteria for IBS

According to the Rome IV criteria, IBS is defined as recurrent abdominal pain for at least 1 day per week in the last 3 months. It must be associated with 2 or more of the following criteria:

  • Related to defecation (improvement or worsening)
  • Associated with a change in stool frequency
  • Associated with a change in stool form (appearance)

The above criteria must be fulfilled for 3 months with symptom onset at least 6 months before diagnosis.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presented with bilateral proptosis, restriction of eye movements, and chemosis. Her thyroid profile showed she was euthyroid. What is the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of thyroid ophthalmopathy.

Thyroid eye disease (TED) is the most common cause of both bilateral and unilateral proptosis in an adult in the euthyroid state. The main features of TED include lid retraction, proptosis, periorbital edema, chemosis, and restrictive myopathy.

Other options-

Option A- Orbital pseudotumor presents with painful eye movements periorbital edema, erythema, proptosis, ptosis, diplopia

Option C- Orbital lymphoma usually presents in the 7th decade, most commonly observed as a painless palpable mass in the superolateral quadrant.

Option D- Orbital cellulitis is usually U/L condition with pain, proptosis, and chemosis

NOTE: Thyroid eye disease can also, though less commonly, occur in euthyroid patients.

Related Pearl: Signs in Grave’s ophthalmopathy

Sign Feature
Dalrymple's sign Retraction of the upper lids
von Graefe's sign Lid lag, i.e., when the globe is moved downward, the upper lid lags behind
Griffith Sign Lower lid lag on upward gaze
Enroth's sign Fullness of the eyelids
Stellwag's sign Infrequent blinking
Gifford's sign Difficulty in eversion of the upper lid
Mobius’ sign Convergence weakness
Joffroy’s sign Lack of wrinkling of the forehead on superior gaze
Jellinek's Sign Abnormal pigmentation of the upper lid

questions.text: The given image shows a normal His Bundle Electrogram (HBE). The deflection shown by the arrow indicates _______
questions.solution:
The arrow mark shows V deflection of HBE which indicates ventricular depolarization 

His bundle electrogram (HBE)

The record of the electrical activity obtained with the catheter passed through a vein to the right side of the heart and placed close to the tricuspid valve is HBE.

It shows 3 deflections as shown in the figure:

 

His bundle waves

Description

A

Denotes AV node activation

H

Denotes transmission through His bundle

V

Denotes ventricular depolarization 

 

With HBE and standard ECG leads, 3 intervals can be timed accurately

 

Interval

Recording

Corresponding event

Time from the first appearance of atrial depolarization to the A wave in HBE

Conduction time from SA node to AV node

AH interval

From A wave to start of H spike

AV nodal conduction time

HV interval

Time from start of H spike to start of QRS deflection in ECG

questions.text: A 32 year old traveller was lost in the desert. He was found after 2 days. He says that he has not consumed food or water for more than 24 hours. His vitals were normal. Which of the following part of the kidney must have been the site of maximum water reabsorption in this case?
questions.solution:
The proximal convoluted tubule is the site of maximum water reabsorption about 67% of the filtered water.

The driving force for water reabsorption is a transtubular osmotic gradient established by reabsorption of solutes.

Based on the ultrastructure proximal tubule is divided into three segments:

  • S1 segment: 1st half of PCT
  • S2 segment: 2nd half of PCT and 1st half of proximal straight tubule
  • S3 segment: 2nd half of proximal straight tubule

Related Pearl: Water transport along nephron

Segment

Mechanism of Water Reabsorption

Proximal tubule(67%)

Osmosis, AQ 1

Loop of Henle (15%)

Descending thin limb only; aquaporin 1 channels

Early distal convoluted tubule(0%)

No water reabsorption

Late distal tubule and collecting duct (8-17%)

Passive(aquaporin-2) under the influence of ADH

questions.text: A soldier posted in Siachen is brought to you in the ER. In order to rule out hypothermia, how do you best measure his temperature?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario rectal temperature would be the preferred site to measure the core body temperature.

During the low or high temperatures like in Siachen, the axillary and the oral temperatures are highly misleading and should not be used to measure the core body temperatures

Infrared tympanic thermometer measures the temperature of the eardrum which is the representative of core body temperature. However, more often the thermometer is not inserted adequately or for safety reason they are manufactured in such a way that they do not reach deep into ear canal or contains cerumen which can disturb the measurement. Hence the infrared thermometer more commonly delivers the temperature of ear canal, cerumen and hence not a reliable method of measuring the core body temperature.

questions.text: A 33-year-old female patient comes with complaints of menorrhagia for the past 3 months. The duration and regularity of her menstrual cycles are normal. Non-hormonal management has been tried without success. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Hormonal therapy is the next best step in the given scenario of menorrhagia that is unresponsive to non-hormonal therapy. 

Menorrhagia is defined as heavy but regular menstrual bleeding. It can be acute (<6 months) or chronic (>6 months).

It is managed as follows:

  • Medical - first line of treatment.  
    • NSAIDs
    • Tranexamic acid  
    • OCPs/progestogens - if non-hormonal management fails 
    • Mirena IUCD
    • Blood transfusion, if required 
  • Surgical - if medical management fails, depending on the diagnosis:
    • Endometrial ablation - hysteroscopic, TCRE, RITEA, microwave, NovaSure, etc
    • Uterine artery embolization
    • Uterine tamponade
    • Hysterectomy - if all minimally invasive methods fail

questions.text: A 25-year old man presents with the condition given in the image. Which of the following is not associated with the condition in the image?
questions.solution:
The image above depicts gynecomastia in a young male patient. Gynecomastia may be associated with functioning testicular tumors, but not in seminoma.

Gynecomastia occurs as a result of an imbalance between estrogens, which stimulate breast tissue, and androgens, which counteract these effects.

The most common causes are as follows:

  • Cirrhosis of the liver
  • Alcohol
  • Marijuana, heroin
  • Antiretroviral therapy
  • Anabolic steroids
  • Klinefelter syndrome (XXY karyotype)
  • Functioning testicular neoplasms, such as the Leydig cell or Sertoli cell tumors.

Microscopically, there is an increase in dense collagenous connective tissue associated with epithelial hyperplasia of the duct lining with characteristic tapering micro-papillae. Lobule formation is almost never observed.

questions.text: Which of the following is the main factor for the ductal closure postnatally?

choices.text: Increase in partial pressure of oxygen (paO2)

questions.solution:
Oxygen is the most important factor controlling ductal closure.

Note:

Gestational age also appears to play an important role; the ductus of a premature infant is less responsive to oxygen, even though its musculature is developed. Hence, patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) is more common in premature infants.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about gastroduodenal motor activity?

choices.text: Migrating motor complex (MMC) in the fasting state lasts for 50 minutes.
Duodenal slow waves are limited to the duodenum.
From the duodenum, the MMC moves distally at 5-10 cm/min.
The amplitude of contraction decreases to a minimum in phase III of MMC.

questions.solution:
From the duodenum, the migrating motor complex (MMC) moves distally at 5–10 cm/min, reaching the terminal ileum after 1.5 hours. 

In the fasting state,  there is a period of quiescence in the small bowel, lasting for approximately 40 minutes (phase I). This is followed by a series of waves, also lasting for about 40 minutes, propagating from the fundus of the stomach in a caudal direction at a rate of about 3 per minute (phase II). 

Duodenal slow waves are generated in the duodenum at a rate of about 10 per minute, which carry down the small bowel.

The amplitude of these contractions increases to a maximum in phase III, which lasts for about 10 minutes. This 90-minute cycle of activity is then repeated.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male smoker was diagnosed to have carcinoma of the right lung. Bronchogram showed the presence of a tumor, causing partial occlusion of the eparterial bronchus. Which of the following bronchopulmonary segments receive decreased airflow​?
questions.solution:
The eparterial bronchus supplies the right upper lobe, which includes the segments: apical, posterior and anterior.

questions.text: What is the most common tumor arising from undescended testis?
questions.solution:
The most common malignancy that occurs in an undescended testis is a seminoma (risk is 5–10 times).

An early orchidopexy is the management of choice because it helps in the early detection of these tumors in the testis as the testis is in the scrotum after the orchidopexy

The other complications that may develop as a result of the undescended testis can be remembered by the mnemonic TESTIS:

T- Torsion

E- Epididymorchitis

S- Sterility

T- Trauma (Increased risk)

I- Increased risk of inguinal hernia (Most commonly occurring complication)

S- Seminoma (Increased risk)

questions.text: A 50-year-old man comes to ophthalmology OPD with the complaints of diminished vision along with floaters and photopsia. The consultant on duty uses the following instrument to assess the retinal lesions. All of the following are the advantages of this instrument except  ______

choices.text: Visualization through hazy media is possible
Produces real image with 15 times higher magnification
Field of view is much larger
Depth perception of the lesion is possible

questions.solution:
The instrument shown in the above image is an indirect ophthalmoscope, and it produces an inverted real image of 2 to 5 times magnification.

Advantages of the binocular indirect ophthalmoscope are:

  • Visualization through hazy media is possible due to strong in built illumination system.
  • Field of view is much larger than direct ophthalmoscopy.
  • Examination of peripheral retina up to ora serrata is possible.
  • Depth perception of the lesion is possible due to stereopsis with binocular indirect ophthalmoscope.
  • Visualization of fundus in very high refractive error is also possible, where it may not be possible to focus the lesion with direct ophthalmoscope.

Related Pearl: Difference between direct and indirect ophthalmoscopy

FEATURE DIRECT OPHTHALMOSCOPE  INDIRECT OPHTHALMOSCOPE
Condensing lens Not required Required
Examination distance As close to the patient's eye as possible At an arm's length
Image Virtual, Erect Real, Inverted
Magnification 15 times 4-5 times
Illumination Not so bright, so not useful in hazy media Bright, so useful in hazy media
Area of the field in focus About 2 disc diameter About 8 disc diameter
Stereopsis Absent Present
Accessible fundus view Slightly beyond equator Up to ora serrata
Examination through hazy media Not possible Possible

questions.text: A radiation oncologist uses radiotherapy as part of the treatment protocol for various tumors. This treatment modality is found to be least effective in which among the following tumors?
questions.solution:
Radiotherapy is least effective in melanoma as it is a highly radioresistant tumor.

Apoptosis occurs in response to radiation in some but not all cells. No meaningful apoptosis occurs in very radioresistant tumors like melanoma and glioblastoma.

Seminoma is a highly radiosensitive tumor and hence radiotherapy is commonly used for treatment.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents with painless cervical lymphadenopathy. On examination, the right ear reveals conductive hearing loss with a dull tympanic membrane. Moreover, decreased mobility of the soft palate was also noted.  Treatment of choice for this patient's condition is?
questions.solution:
This patient most likely has nasopharyngeal carcinoma. Radiotherapy is the treatment of choice for nasopharyngeal cancer.

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma:

  • Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is also called Guangdong tumor.
  • Commonest site of origin of nasopharyngeal carcinoma is the fossa of Rosenmüller.
  • Epstein–Barr Virus (EBV) is closely associated with nasopharyngeal cancer.
  • Presenting symptoms and signs of nasopharyngeal cancer in order of frequency are:
    • Cervical lymphadenopathy (most common) (60–90%)
    • Hearing loss
    • Nasal obstruction
    • Epistaxis
    • Cranial nerve palsies -Cranial nerves V and VI are the most commonly involved among all the cranial nerves. (V more than VI)
    • Headache
    • Earache
    • Neck pain
    • Weight loss

 Nasopharyngeal cancer can cause:

  • Conductive deafness (eustachian tube block)
  • Ipsilateral temporoparietal/facial neuralgia (involvement of CN V) and
  • Palatal paralysis (CN X)

This is collectively called Trotter’s triad.

Radiotherapy is the treatment of choice for nasopharyngeal cancer.

  • Stage I and II are treated by radiotherapy alone.
  • Stage III and IV require concomitant radiation and chemotherapy or radiation followed by chemotherapy.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common sinusitis in children?
questions.solution:
The ethmoid sinus is the most common sinus involved in pediatric sinusitis.

It usually occurs when the infection spreads through the lamina papyracea.

Pain sensation from the ethmoid sinus is carried by the posterior ethmoidal branch of the nasociliary nerve.

Nasociliary nerve is a branch of the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve. 

The other branches of the nasociliary nerve are

  • Long ciliary nerves
  • Infratrochlear nerve
  • Communicating branch to the ciliary ganglion (long root of the ciliary ganglion)

Note: The most common site involved in adenocarcinoma in workers of the furniture industry is the ethmoidal sinus and upper nasal cavity.

Related Pearl: Symptoms of Sinusitis

Symptoms of maxillary sinusitis:

  • Pain over the upper jaw, aggravated by stooping, coughing & chewing
  • Constitutional symptoms like malaise and fever
  • Headache in the frontal region
  • Nasal and postnasal discharge
  • Redness and edema of cheeks
  • Tenderness on pressing over the anterior wall of the antrum

Symptoms of frontal sinusitis:

  • Frontal headache/ office headache with characteristic periodicity i.e. starts early morning and gradually increases and reaches its peak by about mid-day and then starts subsiding
  • Tenderness on pressing on the floor of the frontal sinus, just above the medial canthus
  • Nasal discharge
  • Edema of the upper eyelid

Symptoms of ethmoid sinusitis:

  • Pain over the bridge of the nose and deep to the eye that is aggravated by the movements of the eyeball
  • Edema of both eyelids,
  • Nasal discharge

Symptoms of sphenoid sinusitis:

  • Headache localized to occiput or vertex
  • Postnasal discharge

questions.text: Priya, a college student is fed up with wearing spectacles for her myopia. During her annual eye checkup, she asks the ophthalmologist for eye surgery to get rid of the glasses. Which of the following is not a surgical option to correct her refractive error?
questions.solution:
Conductive keratoplasty is a cornea-based surgical procedure used in the correction of hypermetropia.

Surgical procedures are undertaken after the stabilization of myopia, which usually occurs after 18 years of age.

The various surgeries done for myopia and hypermetropia are summed up in the pearls attached below. 

Related Pearl: Surgical correction of Myopia

  1. Refractive lens exchange
  2. Phakic intraocular lens
  3. Clear lens extraction

Refractive lenticule extraction (ReLEx) (or)

questions.text: Which of the following muscle is supplied by the structure marked as D in the following image?
questions.solution:
The structure marked as D is the recurrent laryngeal nerve, which supplies the posterior cricoarytenoid muscle, an intrinsic muscle of the larynx.

All the  intrinsic muscles of the larynx are supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve except for cricothyroid, which is supplied by the external laryngeal nerve.

In the given image, other structures marked are:

  • A – Vagus
  • B – Sympathetic trunk
  • C – Phrenic nerve

The cervical part of sympathetic trunk lies anterior to longus colli and longus capitis muscles (enclosed in prevertebral fascia) and posterior to the common carotid artery. Sympathetic trunk lies outside the carotid sheath.

Other options:

Option A: Trapezius is supplied by the spinal accessory nerve (CN XI).

Option C: Cricothyroid is supplied by the external laryngeal nerve.

Option D: Diaphragm is supplied by the phrenic nerve.

Related Pearl: Nerves of Larynx

questions.text: A 3 week old patient presenting with vomiting and failure to thrive is found to have pyloric stenosis. What should be the next step of management?

choices.text: Its emergency so do pyloromyotomy immediately

questions.solution:
Correction of electrolyte disturbances is the next step of management.

Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis is a medical emergency not a surgical emergency. Hypertrophy of the circular muscle of the pylorus results in constriction and obstruction of the gastric outlet, leading to nonbilious, projectile emesis, loss of hydrochloric acid with the onset of hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis, and dehydration. Immediate treatment requires correction of fluid loss and electrolytes imbalance.

  • An initial fluid bolus( 20mL/kg) of crystalloids should be infused immediately if infant is dehydrated.
  • Infants should receive 1.5 -2 times maintenance iv fluids: 150 - 180 ml/Kg/day of 0.9% saline with 0.15% Kcl in 5% glucose.
  • Definitive treatment  : Ramstedt's pyloromyotomy.

Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis:

It presents with non-bilious projectile vomiting. It is common between 2 and 8 weeks of age. Hypertrophy of the circular muscle of the pylorus results in constriction and obstruction of the gastric outlet. Male infants are at a higher risk.

Clinically, an olive-shaped mass is palpable in the right upper quadrant or epigastrium. When the infant is given a test feed, visible peristalsis is usually observed moving from left to right across the abdomen.

Infants with hypertrophic pyloric stenosis develop a characteristic metabolic abnormality- hypochloraemic hypokalaemic metabolic alkalosis. Persistent vomiting results in loss of hydrochloric acid leading to the development of metabolic alkalosis (due to loss of H+) and hypochloremia (due to loss of Cl-).

Diagnosis:

Ultrasound examination is the Investigation of choice for this condition. Ultrasound examination confirms the diagnosis of congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS) in the majority of cases. The diagnostic criteria for pyloric stenosis are a muscle thickness of ≥4 mm and a pyloric length of ≥16 mm. The cervix sign and nipple sign are signs seen on USG.

  • Nipple sign- Double-layered hypertrophic mucosa protrudes into the stomach
  • Cervix sign- The sonographic appearance of the hypertrophied pylorus resembles that of the uterine cervix 

Management:

  • The child should be rehydrated and the metabolic abnormality has to be corrected before proceeding to surgery.
  • The Ramstedt pyloromyotomy remains the standard surgical procedure for its treatment.

questions.text: Surgery where one nostril is partially or completely occluded is done for which condition?
questions.solution:
Complete closure of the nostrils (Young's operation) or partial closure of the nostrils (Modified Young's operation) is done for the treatment of atrophic rhinitis.

 

Atrophic rhinitis is a chronic inflammation of the nose characterized by atrophy of the nasal mucosa and turbinate bones. It is more common in females and starts around puberty. The patient presents with nasal obstruction in spite of roomy chambers. It is associated with foul odor from their nose but the patient is unable to smell it because of merciful anosmia. Anosmia due to degeneration of nerve elements. On examination nasal mucosa appears pale, greenish or greyish black dry crusts covering the turbinates and septum. 

Medical management is done using warm saline for nasal irrigation, removal of crusts and administering local antibiotics like kemicetine antiozaena solution(containing chloromycetin, oestradiol, and vitamin D2).

Surgical management involves:

  • In Young's operation, both the nostrils are closed completely by raising flaps within the nasal vestibule. They are opened after 6 months and during this time, the mucosa comes back to normal and the crusting is reduced.
  • Modified young operation is a modified version of Young's operation where the nostrils are only partially closed. The results are the same compared to Young's operation and it is done to avoid discomfort from complete closure of the nostrils.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient, during his routine annual checkup, is found to have an abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring 40 mm in diameter on USG. Which of the following is true about the management of this patient?

choices.text: Surgery is indicated if aneurysmal diameter is >55mm
Urgently wheel the patient to OT for surgery
Surgery is indicated only if aneurysm is >77mm

questions.solution:
Surgery is indicated in asymptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm only if its diameter is more than 55mm.

If the diameter is less than 55mm, regular ultrasound monitoring is required. This is because elective open surgery has a higher rate of mortality when compared to conservative management for aneurysms of size < 55mm.

Condition Criteria for surgical repair
Symptomatic aneurysm  Any size
Ascending thoracic aortic aneurysm - asymptomatic >5.5 cm
Descending thoracic aortic aneurysm - asymptomatic >6 cm
Abdominal aortic aneurysm - asymptomatic >5.5 cm
Popliteal artery aneurysm - asymptomatic >2-3 cm
Ascending thoracic aortic aneurysm in Marfan’s syndrome or bicuspid aortic valve >4-5 cm

Rapidly growing aneurysms 

>0.5 cm/year for ascending aortic aneurysms

> 1cm/year for descending aortic aneurysms

questions.text: The following appearance in IVP is caused by:
questions.solution:
The characteristic sign seen in the given intravenous urogram is the cobra head sign(spring onion sign) due to a ureterocele. 

Ureterocoele is a cystic enlargement of the intramural ureter and affects females more often than males. They are mostly detected on routine prenatal screening, or as an incidental finding on imaging studies in adults.

If they present clinically, they usually present with an infection in children, whereas in adults, they can present with stones in the lower ureter. Ureterocoeles can enlarge and obstruct the bladder neck or the contralateral ureteric orifice.

The classic sign of a ureterocele on intravenous urography is a ‘cobra head’ or ‘adder head’ sign or 'spring onion sign'. It refers to a dilated, contrast-filled distal ureter, surrounded by a thin rim of ureteric wall and bladder mucosa. On ultrasonography, it can be seen as a fluid-filled cystic mass in the bladder.

The treatment of simple ureteroceles is surgical excision with re-implantation of the ureter.

questions.text: The recommended temperature of water bath for a patient with frost bite is
questions.solution:
The temperature of the water bath for a patient with frostbite should be maintained between 40-44°C.

In frostbite, tissue damage results from severe environmental cold exposure or from direct contact with a very cold object. Tissue injury results from both freezing and vasoconstriction. It usually affects the distal aspects of the extremities or exposed parts of the face, such as the ears, nose, chin, and cheeks.

Initial treatment is rewarming, which is accomplished by immersion of the affected part in a water bath at temperatures of 40°–44°C (104°–111° F).

Massage, application of ice water, and extreme heat are contraindicated.

The injured area should be cleaned with soap or antiseptic, and sterile dressings should be applied. Analgesics are often required during rewarming. Antibiotics are used if there is evidence of infection.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man presents with burning pain on passing urine. He reluctantly admits that he had unprotected sexual intercourse 3 days ago. The following examination findings are seen. Which of the following is the likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The symptoms of this patient occurring 3 days after unprotected sex point to urethritis caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae, as its incubation period is 1-5 days.

The most common presentation of gonococcal infection in men is acute urethritis with dysuria and profuse purulent discharge. Pharyngeal and rectal infections can also occur depending on the type of sexual contact.

The primary site of infection in women is the cervix but the urethra, rectum, and pharynx may be involved. Symptoms include excessive vaginal discharge, dysuria, deep dyspareunia, postcoital and intermenstrual bleeding.

Other options:

Option A: The most common cause of non-gonococcal urethritis (NGU) is Chlamydia, which has an incubation period of 1-3 weeks. It usually presents with dysuria alone, but mucopurulent discharge can occur.

Option B: Syphilis is primarily a sexually transmitted disease caused by Treponema palladium but vertical transmission is also possible. It commonly presents as a hard, painless genital ulcer with induration, followed by the development of rubbery enlargement of inguinal lymph nodes.

Option C: Herpes genitalis is an infection of the genital skin or mucosa with herpes simplex virus HSV 1 and HSV 2. It presents as painful genital ulcers and dysuria. It is usually preceded by a prodrome of general malaise.

questions.text: Thrombocytopenia, eczema and recurrent infections are seen in:
questions.solution:
Wiskott Aldrich syndrome- The triad of thrombocytopenia, eczema, and recurrent infections are seen in Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome. It is an X- linked recessive disorder due to mutations in the WAS gene. In this syndrome, leukocytes and platelets are unable to reorganize cytoskeleton. It is associated with an increased risk of autoimmune diseases and malignancy such as leukemia and lymphoma. The characteristic triad includes:

  • Eczema- Eczematoid rash
  • Thrombocytopenia- Decreased platelet count, decreased platelet size, impaired platelet aggregation response, manifests with superficial bleeding
  • Immunodeficiency- There is a progressive loss of T cells in the peripheral blood and in the lymph nodes, with variable defects in cellular immunity and an impaired humoral immune response to polysaccharide antigens. The predominant immunoglobulin pattern is a low serum level of IgM, elevated IgA and IgE, and a normal or slightly low IgG concentration.

A definitive diagnosis can be made by gene sequencing to identify a mutation and by flow cytometry of blood cells to determine if the WASp protein is expressed at normal levels.

Option B: Chediak-Higashi syndrome (CHS) is an autosomal recessive disease due to mutations in CHS1/LYST gene (defective lysosomal transport). It leads to recurrent pyogenic infections, partial oculocutaneous albinism, neurologic abnormalities, and thrombocytopenia. Peripheral smear shows large azurophilic granules in neutrophils and eosinophils. It can lead to hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis.

Option C: Thrombocytopenia-absent radius syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder with severe thrombocytopenia (diagnosed at birth) and bilateral absent radii (thumbs are always present).

Option D: Hermansky-Pudlak syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder with oculocutaneous albinism, bleeding diathesis (deficient dense granules in platelets), pulmonary fibrosis, and granulomatous colitis.

Related Pearl: Primary immunodeficiency disorders

Affected component of the immune system

Disorder

Humoral immunity:

Problems with B cells (lymphocytes) and their antibody production

Common variable immunodeficiency

Selective immunoglobulin deficiency, such as IgA deficiency

Transient hypogammaglobulinemia of infancy

X-linked agammaglobulinemia

Cellular immunity: 

Problems with T cells (lymphocytes)

Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis

DiGeorge syndrome

X-linked lymphoproliferative syndrome

Combined humoral and cellular immunity:

Problems with B and T cells

Ataxia-telangiectasia

Hyperimmunoglobulinemia M syndrome

Severe combined immunodeficiency

Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome

Phagocytes: 

Problems with the movement or killing 

Chronic granulomatous disease

Chédiak-Higashi syndrome (rare)

Tuftsin deficiency

Cyclic neutropenia

Leukocyte adhesion defects

Complement proteins:

Complement component 1 (C1) inhibitor deficiency (hereditary angioedema)
