questions.text: Which of the following acts to increase the release of calcium ions from the endoplasmic reticulum of a smooth muscle?
questions.solution:
In response to a stimulus, the efflux of calcium from intracellular stores occurs through an Inositol triphosphate receptor (IP3R)- Ca+2 channel.

The source of Ca+2 in smooth muscle contraction can be different depending on the activating stimulus.

  • The influx from the extracellular site through voltage or ligand-gated Ca+2 channels in the plasma membrane
  • Efflux from intracellular stores (eg, sarcoplasmic reticulum) through the RyR and the inositol triosephosphate receptor (IP3R).

questions.text: Which serotype of HPV is responsible for carcinoma cervix?
questions.solution:
HPV serotypes 16, 18, 31, 33, 35, 39, 45, 52, 56, 58, 59, 68 are associated with carcinoma cervix.

Risk factors for carcinoma cervix include:

  • Human Papilloma virus (most important)
  • Sexual intercourse before 18 years
  • Multiple sexual partners
  • Multiparity
  • Poor personal hygiene
  • Smoking and drug abuse
  • Women with STD, HIV, HSV 
  • Immune suppression

Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) or southern blot or Hybrid capture technique is used for HPV DNA detection.

questions.text: You are an intern attending rounds and you see a 30-year-old male with the following picture as given below. Not true regarding the condition in the given condition?

choices.text: Incomplete cyst wall removal causes recurrence
A punctum may not always be visible

questions.solution:
The image shows an infected sebaceous cyst (epidermoid cyst) as evident by the inflammation of the swelling. Malignancies in epidermoid cysts are very rare. 

The most common site of a Sebaceous cyst is postauricular sulcus or below and behind the ear lobule. They are fixed to the skin and usually have a central punctum.

A sebaceous cyst is derived from hair follicle infundibulum or traumatic inclusion. The most common site of a sebaceous cyst is the postauricular sulcus or below and behind the ear lobule. Malignancy is rare. 

Clinical features of a sebaceous cyst include:

  • Benign swelling that is mobile, fluctuant, and fixed to the skin. It presents with a central punctum in about 70% of cases. 
  • It is generally an asymptomatic, non-tender swelling. It can be painful and red if inflamed.
  • It may ooze out a foul-smelling, cheese-like discharge.

Treatment depends on the clinical state of the cyst. When inflamed or infected, they should be incised and drained initially. After the inflammation subsides, total surgical excision of the cyst is performed. If the cyst wall is not removed, there is a risk of recurrence. Perilesional triamcinolone injection helps with inflammation resolution but not cyst eradication.

Tumor

Most common site

Sebaceous cyst

Post auricular sulcus

Dermoid cyst

Post auricular area

Keloid

Pinna around the piercing site

Cutaneous horn

Helix

Acoustic neuroma

Vestibular Nerve

Squamous cell Carcinoma

Helix

Basal cell Carcinoma

Helix & tragus

Malignant Melanoma

Anywhere

Other options: 

  • Incomplete removal of the cyst wall is indeed a frequent cause of recurrence
  • Punctum is not always clinically visible as it can be buried
  • Injection of triamcinolone Perilesionally aids faster resolution & clearing of infection. But this does not cause the eradication of cyst

questions.text: A 40-year-old diabetic patient presented with a ​squint. On examination, the secondary deviation was found to be more than the primary deviation. The forced duction test is negative. Which of the following squint types is most likely present in this patient?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of paralytic squint. It is characterized by the presence of secondary deviation more than the primary deviation, and a negative forced duction test.

The squint may be either comitant or incomitant.

  • Comitant squint: The angle of squint measured is same in all gazes. 
  • Incomitant squint: The angle of squint measured is different in different gazes. 

The differences between comitant and incomitant squint are shown in the table below:

Features Comitant squint Incomitant squint
Magnitude of squint Same in all gazes Varies with the gaze
Diplopia Absent Present
Ocular movements Full Restricted
False projection Absent Present
Abnormal head posture Absent Present
Secondary deviation Equal to primary deviation More than primary deviation

The incomitant squint is further divided into two main types: Paralytic and restrictive.

Paralytic squint occurs due to the paralysis of extraocular muscle while restrictive squint is due to the mechanical restriction caused by tight or fibrosed muscle.

Forced duction test(FDT) differentiates between these two types. In this test, the eye is moved mechanically with the help of a foreceps.

  • The test is negative if there is no resistance to the movement. It is seen in a paralytic squint.
  • The test is positive if there is resistance to the movement. It is seen in a restrictive squint.

questions.text: In the syndromic management of sexually transmitted infections, the grey kit consists of __________
questions.solution:
In the syndromic management of sexually transmitted infections, the grey kit consists of T.Azithromycin and T.Cefixime

The color coded packs are as follows:

  • Kit 1– Grey, for urethra discharge, anorectal discharge, and cervicitis.
  • Kit 2– Green, for vaginitis
  • Kit 3– White, for genital ulcers
  • Kit 4– Blue, for genital ulcers.
  • Kit 5– Red, for genital ulcers.
  • Kit 6– Yellow, for lower abdominal pain
  • Kit 7– Black, for inguinal bubo

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

Related Pearl: Partner management in sexually transmitted infections

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections. 

Syndrome Kit used for Treatment Partner Treatment
Urethral Discharge Grey kit Treat all recent partners
Cervical discharge Grey kit Treat partners when symptomatic
Painful scrotal swelling Grey kit Treat all recent partners
Vaginal Discharge Green kit Treat partners when symptomatic
Genital ulcer disease- Non-herpetic White kit/Blue kit Treat all sexual partners for past 3 months
Genital Ulcer disease -Herpetic Red kit No partner treatment
Lower Abdominal Pain Yellow kit Treat male partners with Grey kit (kit 1)
Inguinal Bubo Black kit Treat all sexual partners for past 3 weeks

NACO: http://naco.gov.in/sites/default/files/Syndromic%20Poster_REDUCED.pdf

questions.text: The difference between the incidence of disease among exposed and incidence among non exposed is given by which of the following variables?
questions.solution:
The difference between the incidence of disease among exposed and incidence among non-exposed is given by attributable risk.

Attributable risk is often expressed as a percentage.

Related Pearl: The Mosquito

The mosquito as a vector:

  • Mosquitoes are global in distribution.
  • The main species of mosquitoes include the Anopheles, Culex, Aedes and Mansonia.
  • Flight range varies up to 11 kms, except Aedes for which it is 100 metres.
  • Life span of mosquitoes is around 8 to 34 days.
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a proboscis, a pair of palpi and a pair of antennae; a thorax and an abdomen.

questions.text: A 3-day-old male neonate who has not yet passed meconium developed abdominal distension. On rectal examination, forceful expulsion of stool was observed.  A barium enema was done and showed dilated right colon with a transition zone in the mid-descending colon. Which of the following is true about the pathogenesis of this patient's condition?

choices.text: Failure of migration of neural crest cells

questions.solution:
Hirschsprung disease occurs due to the failure of migration of the neural crest cells to the bowel wall.

Pathogenesis of Hirschsprung disease:

During normal embryogenesis, the neural crest cells migrate from the caecum to rectum. The enteric neuronal plexuses develop from these migrated neural crest cells. In Hirschsprung disease, there is an arrest in the migration of these cells, which leads to the development of distal intestinal segment that is devoid of Meissner submucosal and the Auerbach myenteric plexus. Hence this segment is referred to as the aganglionic segment. As a result, there is a lack of co-ordination in the peristaltic contractions and functional obstruction, which further leads to the dilation of intestine proximal to the affected segment, leading to congenital megacolon.

Diagnosis is confirmed by demonstrating the absence of ganglion cells in biopsied sections.

Some conditions may cause acquired megacolon. These include:

  • Chagas disease, due to the loss of ganglion cells
  • Visceral myopathy
  • Obstruction by neoplasm or inflammatory stricture
  • Toxic megacolon complicating ulcerative colitis.
  • Functional psychosomatic disorders.

questions.text: An HIV-positive man presents with a high-grade fever. Examination reveals the following finding. CSF shows reduced glucose, increased protein, and increased leukocytes. What is the most common cause of this condition in such patients?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, along with a positive Kernig's sign, is suggestive of meningitis. Cryptococcus is the leading infectious cause of meningitis in patients with AIDS. It generally occurs in untreated patients, with CD4+ T cell counts <100/μL.            

Most patients present with a picture of subacute meningoencephalitis. The CSF profile may show modest elevations in WBC or protein levels and decrease in glucose. The CSF opening pressure is usually elevated (yeast colonies obstruct the free flow of CSF causing increased CSF pressure).

The diagnosis of cryptococcal meningitis is made by identification of Cryptococcus neoformans yeast cells in CSF with india ink stain or by the detection of cryptococcal antigen using latex agglutination (CrAg).

Prophylaxis: Oral fluconazole when CD4+ T cell count is <100/μL.

Treatment:

  • Induction - IV or liposomal amphotericin B with flucytosine for at least 2 weeks, continuing with amphotericin alone ideally until the CSF culture turns negative.
  • Maintenance -  Oral fluconazole until the CD4+ T cell count has increased to >200 cells/μL for 6 months in response to cART.

Related Pearl: CSF findings in meningitis

Bacterial <40 >100

>1000

Viral Normal 20-80

Predominantly lymphocytes

questions.text: The senior resident in the emergency medicine department decided to add the diuretic which acts on site "A"  marked in the image to the patient with pulmonary edema. The mechanism of action of this diuretic is __________
questions.solution:
Site " A" is the thick ascending limb of Loop of Henle. Loop diuretics act on the thick ascending limb of Loop of Henle and inhibit Na+- K+ -2Cl- symport.

Furosemide is a loop diuretic. It acts by inhibiting the Na+-K+-2Cl- symporter in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle resulting in increased excretion of sodium and chloride. It also has mild carbonic anhydrase inhibitory activity and also increases urinary excretion of bicarbonate and phosphate. Cirrhotic patients are often resistant to loop diuretics due to decreased secretion of the drug into tubular fluid and high aldosterone levels. Furosemide may be given along with eplerenone, but the best answer here is eplerenone since aldosterone antagonists are the main therapy for cirrhotic edema.

Related Pearl: Site and mechanism of action of diuretics

Diuretics  Site of action  

Enzyme/receptor/transporter inhibited 
Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors   Proximal tubule   Carbonic anhydrase  
Loop diuretics  Thick ascending loop of Henle  Na+- K+- 2Cl- symporter
Thiazides Distal convoluted tubule  Na+- Cl- symporter
Epithelial sodium channel inhibitors  Late distal tubule and collecting ducts   ENaC 
Aldosterone antagonists  Late distal tubule and collecting ducts  Mineralocorticoid receptors (indirectly ENaC)

questions.text: What is the diagnosis seen in the image below?
questions.solution:
The condition shown in the image is candidal intertrigo.

It is a candidal infection of opposing skin surfaces, which presents as erythema with a little moist exudation starting deep in a fold. When the web spaces of the toes or fingers are affected, marked maceration with a thick, white, horny layer is usually prominent.

As the condition progresses, it spreads beyond the area of contact, usually developing the typical features of candidosis with a fringed, irregular edge and subcorneal pustules rupturing to give tiny erosions, and then further peeling of the stratum corneum.

Sites of infection:

  • Between genital folds and groins
  • Armpits
  • Between the buttocks
  • Inframammary fold (large and pendulous breasts)
  • Under overhanging abdominal folds
  • Umbilicus.
  • Web spaces of toes, fingers

Marked maceration with a thick, white, horny layer is usually prominent. Soreness and itching are present.

The disease usually spreads beyond the area of contact, developing lesions with irregular edges and subcorneal pustules rupturing to give tiny erosions which lead to peeling of the stratum corneum. 

Psoriasis, tinea corporis, and pityriasis rotunda have scaly lesions.

Treatment:

Topical antifungal agents such as nystatin, ketoconazole, and clotrimazole are routinely used.

questions.text: A patient presents to you with a history of sharing needles during IV drug abuse with an HIV-positive partner. HIV-antibody spot test was negative, however, the p24 antigen assay was positive. You explain to him that he is currently in the window period for HIV. Which of the following statements would you use to explain the concept to him?

choices.text: It is the time period between infection and onset of first symptoms
It is the time period between infection and detection of antibodies
It is the time period between exposure and onset of viral multiplication
It is the time period between exposure and appearance of symptoms

questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the patient has experienced a high-risk exposure to HIV due to sharing needles during IV drug abuse with an HIV-positive partner. 

The period between infection and detection of antibodies against HIV is known as the window period.

The window period may last anywhere between 2–8 weeks to a few months. During this period, the individual may be highly infectious. HIV infection can be detected during this period by p24 antigen assay and PCR.

questions.text: What is the surveillance reporting system used by the WHO?
questions.solution:
The surveillance reporting system used by the WHO is the Weekly Epidemiological Record (WER).

The WHO collects and disseminates epidemiological information on diseases subject to International Health Regulations. It is done through an Automatic Telex Reply Service (ATRS) and the Weekly Epidemiological Record (WER).

questions.text:
You are studying the lung volumes of a patient with a spirometer. The patient is a known case of COPD. Which of the following will be increased in this patient?
  1. FRC
  2. TLC
  3. VC
  4. FEV1/FVC
questions.solution:
In COPD, the functional residual capacity increases. Total lung capacity may be increased or normal. Hence, both 1 and 2 are correct. In obstructive lung diseases:

  • Both FEV1 and FVC reduces, where the decrease in FEV1 is more than the reduction in FVC. As a result, the ratio of FEV1/FVC also decreases.
  • The total lung capacity is usually normal in chronic bronchitis, while increased in emphysema.
  • Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) is increased in COPD
     

Lung Capacities:

The total lung capacity can be broken down into alternative capacities that help to define functioning lungs.

  • The vital lung capacity refers to the maximum amount of air expired from the fully inflated lung or maximum inspiratory level.
  • The inspiratory capacity is the maximum amount of air inspired from the end-expiratory level.
  • The functional residual capacity represents the volume of the air remaining in the lungs after expiration of a normal breath. Functional Residual Capacity (FRC) is expiratory reserve volume + residual volume.

Related Pearl: Lung volumes and capacities

Measurement

Description

Normal Value

Tidal volume (TV)

The amount of air that moves into the lungs with each inspiration (or the amount that moves out with each expiration) during quiet breathing

500–750 mL.

Inspiratory reserve volume (IRV)

The air inspired with a maximal inspiratory effort in excess of the TV

∼3 L

Expiratory reserve volume (ERV)

The volume expelled by an active expiratory effort after passive expiration

∼1.1 L

Residual volume (RV)

The air left in the lungs after a maximal expiratory effort

∼1.2 L

Total lung capacity (TLC)

IRV+TV+ERV+RV

∼5.8 L

Vital capacity (VC)

IRV+TV+ERV

∼4.5 L

Inspiratory capacity (IC)

TV+IRV

∼3.5 L

Expiratory capacity (EC)

TV+ERV

∼1.5 L

Functional residual capacity (FRC)

ERV+RV

∼2.3 L

questions.text: Identify this sign in pregnancy.
questions.solution:
The image dipicts Hegar's sign.

Hegar's sign: the examiner performs a bimanual examination. Two fingers of one hand are placed in the anterior fornix of the vagina and the fingers of the other hand are placed, over the abdomen and behind the uterus. The abdominal fingers and the vaginal fingers appear to oppose each other below the body of the uterus. This can be elicited between 6-10 weeks.

This sign is based on the fact that the lower part of the body of the uterus is empty and extremely soft, and the upper part is enlarged by the growing fetus.

Other options :

Option A- Palmer's sign is regular rhythmic uterine contraction during the bimanual examination, which is seen as early as 4-8 weeks.

Option C- Osiander's sign is increased pulsation felt through lateral fornix by 8 weeks.

Option D- Goodell's sign is softening of the cervix by the 6th week.

Related Pearl: Clinical Signs in Obstetrics

  • Chadwick’s Sign: Bluish hue to the vestibule and anterior vaginal wall. Seen in the first trimester of pregnancy. The cause is increased blood flow to the pelvic organs. Also known as Jacquemier’s Sign. /
  • Cullen Sign: Bluish discoloration of the skin around the umbilicus. Occurs due to intraperitoneal hemorrhage. Seen in ruptured ectopic pregnancy
  • Goodell Sign: Marked softening of the cervix in contrast to a non-pregnant state. Also due to increased blood flow
  • Hegar Sign: An indication of Pregnancy. The softening of the lower parts of the uterus enables the approximation of vaginal and abdominal fingers on bimanual pelvic examination.
  • Kustner’s Sign: Sign of placental separation. On pushing the uterus upwards does not move the cord with it due to the separation.
  • Ladin’s Sign: Softening in the midline of the uterus anteriorly at the junction of the uterus and cervix. It occurs at about 6 weeks gestation
  • Osiander’s Sign: Pulsations in the lateral fornix due to the increased vascularity.
  • Palmer’s Sign: Regular rhythmic contractions of uterus felt as early as 6-8 weeks. It is a sign of pregnancy
  • Piskacek’s Sign: Asymmetric growth occurs to the uterus in the initial stages of pregnancy due to the lateral implantation of the blastocyst. The area of implantation feels soft compared to the other parts.
  • Schroeder’s Sign: A sign of placental separation. Uterus rises up when the separated placenta is passed downwards
  • Stallworthy’s Sign: Slowing of fetal heart rate on pressing the head down into the pelvis and prompt recovery on the release of pressure is termed Stallworthy’s sign. This sign is suggestive of posterior placenta praevia.
  • Turtle Sign: This is when the fetal head suddenly retracts back against the mother's perineum after it has emerged from the vagina. This retraction of the fetal head is caused by the baby's anterior shoulder being caught on the back of the maternal pubic bone, preventing delivery of the remainder of the baby.
  • Von Braun-Fernwald's Sign: Irregular softening and enlargement of the uterine fundus during early pregnancy. It occurs at 5-8 weeks gestation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old obese woman enquires about ways she can reduce her risk of coronary artery disease. Which of the following dietary modifications would you suggest?

choices.text: Reduction of salt intake to less than 10g per day
Consumption of saturated fats limited to less than 10% of the total energy intake
Reduction of total fat intake to less than 5% of total energy intake
Dietary cholesterol increased to above 100 mg/1000 kcal energy intake

questions.solution:
Limiting the consumption of saturated fats to less than 10% of total energy intake is recommended for the prevention of coronary artery disease.

The WHO'S Expert Committee suggested certain dietary modifications for the prevention of coronary artery disease. These include:

  • Reduction of the total fat intake to 20–30% of total energy intake
  • Consumption of saturated fats must be limited to less than 10% of total energy intake
  • A reduction of dietary cholesterol to below 100mg per 1000 kcal per day
  • Increase in the complex carbohydrate consumption (i.e vegetables, fruits, whole grains and legumes)
  • Avoidance of alcohol consumption and reduction of salt intake to 5g daily or less

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presented with fever, drooling of saliva and inspiratory stridor. X-ray is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is acute epiglottitis. The symptoms of drooling of saliva, inspiratory stridor and fever are suggestive of epiglottitis. The lateral X-ray of neck shows enlarged and edematous epiglottis or “thumb” sign.

Retropharyngeal and parapharyngeal abscess present with neck stiffness, trismus and muffled voice while barking cough and hoarseness are seen in tracheolaryngobronchitis (croup).

Retropharyngeal abscess would show widened pre-vertebral space on X-ray whereas croup is characterized by steeple sign. Parapharyngeal abscess is poorly defined on X ray and is best diagnosed on CT.

Acute epiglottitis

  • Microbiology: Streptococcus > Hemophilus influenzae b
  • Median age: 6-12 years
  • Cinical features: Distress (Inspiratory stidor, tripod positioning), Dysphagia and Drooling
  • X ray findings: Thumb sign (enlarged epiglottis), loss of vallecular space
  • Management: Antibiotics, emergency endotracheal intubation as required

Acute laryngotracheobronchitis (Croup)

  • Microbiology: viral infection
  • Median age: 6 months to 6 years
  • Clinical features: barking cough, inspiratory stridor, hoarseness, low grade fever
  • X-ray findings: “Steeple sign” due to subglottic narrowing
  • Management: Nebulized racemic epinephrine

Retropharyngeal abscess:

  • Microbiology: Polymicrobial (streptococcus pyogenes, staphylococcus aureus and anaerobes)
  • Median age: 6 months – 6 years
  • Clinical features: Fever, odonyphagia/dysphagia, drooling, neck stiffness, muffled voice and trismus.
  • X-ray findings: Widened pre-vertebral space
  • Management: Intravenous antibiotics + Surgical drainage, emergency endotracheal intubation as required

Parapharyngeal abscess presents similar to Retropharyngeal abscess and is best diagnosed on CT.

Steeple sign – Croup

Widened prevertebral space-Retropharyngeal abscess

Note:

The most common cause of epiglottitis:
In India - Hemophilus influenza.
Rest of the World - Strep. pneumonia.

Though Nelson mentions that H.influenza is not the most common cause of this condition, the latest edition of O.P Ghai still mentions H.influenza as the most common cause of acute epiglottitis. 
What it means is that, in India, even though cases of H. influenza are coming down due to increased vaccine coverage, still H. influenza remains the leading cause of acute epiglottitis in India.

Related Pearl: Acute stridor/ Noisy breathing

Stridor indicates an upper airway problem. Look for a history of foreign body aspiration and signs of toxicity.

Important differentials:

Condition  Findings
Croup

Non-toxic, viral prodrome, barking cough

X-ray neck shows steeple sign
Epiglottitis

Toxic child, drooling saliva

Lateral X-ray neck shows thumb sign
Diphtheria Cervical lymph nodes (bull neck), dirty grey/ white membrane, and un-immunized
Foreign body aspiration Choking, decreased air entry, unilateral hyperinflation

questions.text: A 32 year old lady is undergoing evaluation for polycystic ovary syndrome. Her sex hormone-binding globulin (SHBG) is low. The decrease in sex hormone-binding globulin will have the maximum effect on which of the following hormones?
questions.solution:
The decrease in sex hormone-binding globulin will have the maximum effect on testosterone.

Around 98% of the circulating testosterone is bound to plasma proteins such as sex hormone-binding globulin (65%) and albumin. So, the decrease in sex-hormone-binding globulin (SHBG) or gonadal steroid-binding globulin (GBG) will have the maximum effect on testosterone levels by increasing the levels of its free form.

Therefore patients with polycystic ovary syndrome will show features of hyperandrogenism (due to elevated free testosterone).

questions.text: Which of the following drugs gets deposited in cornea?
questions.solution:
Chloroquine, an anti-malarial drug may get deposited in the cornea leading to corneal opacity.

Ocular toxicity of chloroquine:

  • Short-term therapy - blurring of vision and diplopia, reversible on stoppage of drug.
  • Long-term use (high-dose): 
    • Keratopathy
    • Pigmentary retinopathy
    • Optic atrophy

Hydroxychloroquine has lower ocular toxicity compared to chloroquine. 

Drugs causing corneal opacity:

  • Amiodarone
  • Phenothiazine
  • Indomethacin
  • Chloroquine

Long-term treatment with these drugs can cause a whorl-like opacity in the corneal epithelium called cornea verticillata. It is also seen in Fabry's disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding Bowen’s disease?
questions.solution:
Bowen's disease has a low potential for invasive malignancy. 

It is an intraepidermal squamous cell carcinoma that is characterized by a persistent, non‐elevated, red, scaly, or crusted plaque with a small potential for invasive malignancy. Histologically, it is characterized by full-thickness epidermal dysplasia.

It usually grows progressively but sometimes undergoes spontaneous partial resolution. It can occur anywhere, but it occurs more in the head and neck region.

Human papilloma virus infection is associated with it.

Image: Red scaly plaque seen on the finger, in an 81-year-old woman with Bowen’s disease.

questions.text: Which of the following investigations is shown in the radiograph?
questions.solution:
The given image is a double contrast radiograph of barium meal. It is used to examine the lower half of the esophagus, stomach, and entire duodenum.

GI Imaging Preparations of barium Structures best visualized
Barium swallow Barium paste Esophagus
Barium meal 95% BaSO4 Stomach and duodenum
Barium meal follow-through 50% BaSO4 Small bowel
Barium enema 25% BaSO4 Large bowel

The below radiograph shows a barium follow-through study. It is useful in visualizing small bowel pathology and evaluating the function of the small bowel. It is inferior to enteroclysis enema where contrast is administered through a nasogastric tube.

The below radiograph is a double-contrast barium enema with a normal large bowel structure. The contrast is administered through a rectal tube and a series of radiographs are obtained.

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy presents with a history of injury to the eye caused while climbing a tree 5 days ago; the injury has caused pain, photophobia, and redness of the eye for 2 days. He is diagnosed with a fungal ulcer. What of the following will be seen in this patient?

choices.text: Dendritic ulcer on a fluorescien dye

questions.solution:
Satellite lesions are characteristic of fungal ulcer.

The given clinical vignette and the image of an ulcer with irregular feathery margins are suggestive of a fungal corneal ulcer. Satellite lesions are a feature of fungal ulcers.

A fungal corneal ulcer is usually caused by trauma with vegetative or organic matter. Signs are more pronounced than symptoms. The corneal ulcer appears dry.

Causative organisms:

  • Aspergillus
  • Fusarium
  • Candida albicans

Signs of a fungal ulcer:

  • Irregular margins of the ulcer
  • Presence of satellite lesions surrounding the ulcer.
  • An immune ring (Wesseley ring) may be seen around the ulcer due to the deposition of the immune complexes.
  • Slough is usually dry, with feathery borders surrounded by a yellow line of demarcation.
  • Hypopyon may be present or absent. If present, it is thick, and immobile due to the direct invasion of the fungal hyphae into the anterior chamber.

The image given below shows a fungal ulcer:

Treatment:

Topical drugs: These include topical natamycin, voriconazole, or amphotericin B drops, which are effective against Aspergillus and Fusarium. Nystatin is effective against Candida.
Systemic drugs: Severe ulcers with hypopyon, perforation, or suspected endophthalmitis might warrant the use of oral antifungal agents such as ketoconazole or voriconazole.

Related Pearl: Clinical differential diagnosis of corneal ulcer

  Bacterial Fungal Viral Parasitic
Risk factors

Contact lens wear

Trauma

Chronic steroid use

Anesthetic cornea

Dry eyes

Exposure keratopathy

 Trauma with vegetable matter

Low immunity

Recurrent attacks

Contact lens wear

Exposure to contaminated water (acanthamoeba)

 
Clinical features

Hypopyon is fluid and mobile

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is likely to have a rapid course, with deep corneal necrosis.

Less pain and watering compared to the extent of vision loss and signs. 

Tend to be indolent but progressive

Hypopyon is thick, immobile.

Relatively more pain and watering compared to the extent of vision loss and signs. 

Recurrences are characteristic.

Disproportionately severe pain is a characteristic feature.

Indolent course and in initial stages, often mistaken to be viral/ fungal infection, leading to a delay in diagnosis

questions.text: A 56-year-old man collapsed suddenly during dinner. He was brought to the emergency room but was declared dead on arrival. Prior to eating, he had been consuming alcohol. No signs of asphyxia were observed, but an autopsy revealed a bolus of food lodged in the larynx. Which of the following statements about this patient's condition is false?

choices.text: Mostly seen in well nourished businessmen
Autopsy often shows food, often steak, lodged in the pharynx or larynx
Death is due to mechanical asphyxia causing reflex cardiac inhibition
Death is often prolonged and happens hours later

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is most likely suggestive of cafe coronary syndrome. Death in café coronary syndrome occurs due to parasympathetic overactivity. It is sudden and unexpected and happens rapidly.

This is usually seen in well-built businessmen. In this syndrome, the victim dies during a meal with no signs of respiratory distress or classical signs of asphyxia.

The cause of death in these patients is mechanical asphyxia leading to vasovagal reflex causing reflex cardiac inhibition. The mode of death is cardiac arrest (not the cause of death) presumably from parasympathetic overactivity occurring from stimulation of the laryngeal or pharyngeal mucosa.

Suppressed gag reflex due to gross intoxication with alcohol or large doses of tranquilizers in mental institutions or hospitals might be the predisposing factors. Autopsy reveals a bolus of food, lodged in the pharynx or larynx.

Death in 'café coronary' syndrome are sudden and unexpected and happen rapidly.

'Café coronary' syndrome:

  • In this syndrome, the victim dies suddenly and unexpectedly during a meal with no signs of respiratory distress or 'classical signs of asphyxia.
  • Initially thought to be coronary heart disease, autopsy revealed a bolus of food, often steak, lodged in the pharynx or larynx.
  • The cause of death in these patients is mechanical asphyxia leading to vasovagal reflex causing reflex cardiac inhibition.
  • The mode of death is clearly cardiac arrest (not the cause of death) presumably from parasympathetic overactivity occuring from stimulation of the laryngeal or pharyngeal mucosa.

questions.text: A patient comes with long-standing non-pitting edema in the legs. What is the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
Lymphedema is the most probable cause of long standing non-pitting edema in the limbs.

Lymphedema is the abnormal accumulation of protein-rich fluid in the interstitial spaces of the tissues.

Usually, there is a balance between fluid formation and lymph transport capacity. With congenital hypoplasia or acquired obstruction, there is a reduction in transport capacity resulting in the accumulation of fluid and protein in the interstitium. 

This along with cellular debris and waste products of metabolism elicit an inflammatory response associated with fibrovascular proliferation and collagen deposition. This leads to firm, non-pitting swelling characteristic of chronic, long-standing edema.

Treatment mostly includes patient education and nonsurgical interventions, which include limb elevation, external compressive garments. When the above methods fail, surgery can be considered.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of the primary survey?

choices.text: Removing clothes to inspect for wounds
Taking CT scan of the patient

questions.solution:
Taking a CT scan of the patient is a part of secondary survey.

Primary survey is used to identify and manage the most immediately life-threatening pathologies first. 

The steps in the ATLS (Advanced Trauma Life Support) include:

  • Primary survey with simultaneous resuscitation – identify and treat what is killing the patient
  • Secondary survey – proceed to identify all other injuries
  • Definitive care – develop a definitive management plan

ABCDE of trauma care:

  • Airway assessment and protection (maintain cervical spine stabilization when appropriate)
  • Breathing and ventilation assessment (maintain adequate oxygenation)
  • Circulation assessment (control haemorrhage and maintain adequate end-organ perfusion)
  • Disability assessment (perform basic neurologic evaluation)
  • Exposure, with environmental control (undress patient and search everywhere for possible injury, while preventing hypothermia)

Adjuncts to the primary survey:

  • Blood - FBC, urea and electrolytes, clotting screen, glucose, toxicology, cross-match
  • ECG, pulse oximetry, ventilatory rate, capnography, ABG analysis
  • Two wide-bore cannulae for intravenous fluids
  • Urinary and gastric catheters
  • Radiographs of the chest and pelvis are done as a part of the primary survey preferably with a portable x-ray unit.
  • Radiographs of the cervical spine, chest AP view and pelvis AP view are done when necessary.
  • When required, all these x rays must also be done in pregnant women.

Other more specialized forms of imaging, such as ultrasound, computerized tomography, angiography, and diagnostic peritoneal lavage, should be considered after the secondary survey and only when the patient is stable after initial resuscitation.

questions.text: The appearance of USG at saphenofemoral junction, showing common femoral vein, common femoral artery and the great saphenous vein is called as:
questions.solution:
The normal anatomy of the femoral vessels and great saphenous vein at the saphenofemoral junction on USG is called the mickey mouse sign.

The given images below show the mickey mouse sign (FV- femoral vein; FA- femoral artery; GSV- great saphenous vein).

questions.text: A 1st-year medical student is studying the anatomy of the intestines in the dissection lab. Which of the following is the longest part of the large intestine?
questions.solution:
The transverse colon is the longest part of the large intestine, measuring 50 cm in length on an average. It is intraperitoneal in location and suspended by the transverse mesocolon.

Lengths of various parts of the large intestine are as follows:

Intestinal segment

6 cm

Ascending colon

 15 to 20 cm

Transverse colon

50 cm

Descending colon

25 to 30 cm

Sigmoid colon

37.5 cm

Rectum

15 cm

Anal canal

2 to 5 cm

questions.text: Large, friable, irregular vegetations on heart valves are seen in _______:
questions.solution:
Large, friable, irregular vegetations on heart valves are seen in infective endocarditis.

Infective endocarditis is characterized by the presence of large, friable, irregular vegetations on heart valves.. Aortic and mitral valves are the most commonly affected, however, in some cases, the right heart valves may be involved.

Vegetations may be single or multiple and may involve one or more valves. Embolization often occurs and may lead to septic infarcts or mycotic aneurysms at the site of lodgement due to the presence of virulent organisms in the emboli.

questions.text: All of the following are primary bile acids except?
questions.solution:
Deoxycholic acid is not a primary bile acid. It is a secondary bile acid.

The primary bile acids are cholic acid and chenodeoxycholic acid synthesised from cholesterol in the liver. They are next conjugated with glycine and taurine in the liver peroxisomes to form glycocholic, glycochenodeoxycholic, taurocholic, and taurochenodeoxycholic acids.

The secondary bile acids are formed in the intestine as they are deconjugated and dehydroxylated by the intestinal bacteria to form deoxycholic and lithocholic acid.

These are absorbed in the ileum and returned to the liver by enterohepatic circulation.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy was asked to blow-off a paper repeatedly while doing an EEG. The recording shows symmetric, 3-Hz spike-and-slow-wave discharges that begins and ends suddenly, superimposed on a normal EEG background. What is the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a child with a 3Hz spike and wave pattern on EEG, which was provoked by hyperventilation, suggests a diagnosis of absence seizures.

Absence seizures are the most common seizures in children. The electrophysiologic hallmark of typical absence seizures is a generalized, symmetric, 3-Hz spike-and-slow-wave discharge pattern.

These seizures are characterized by a sudden, brief lapse of consciousness with preserved postural control and without post-ictal confusion. Usually, the seizure lasts only a few seconds. The patient presents with subtle, bilateral motor signs such as rapid blinking of the eyelids, chewing movements, or small-amplitude, clonic movements of the hands. These can occur hundreds of times in a day. The child is often misunderstood to be 'daydreaming' and parents are often told that there is a decline in the child's performance at school.

The first line treatment drugs for absent seizures include valproic acid, ethosuximide and lamotrigine. 

Other options:

Option A: Generalised tonic-clonic seizure is characterized by tonic contractions of muscles followed by periods of muscle relaxation (clonic phase). It is associated with unresponsiveness, muscular flaccidity, excessive salivation, and incontinence. The EEG is characterized by an increase in generalized low-voltage fast waves after which generalized high-amplitude, polyspike discharges in the tonic phase. In the clonic phase, a spike and slow-wave pattern are observed. 

Option B: Atonic seizures are characterized by sudden loss of postural muscle tone. Consciousness may not be impaired and postictal confusion is not usually present. The EEG shows generalized spike-wave discharge followed by diffuse slow waves which correspond to the muscle tone. 

Option D: Myoclonic seizures are characterized by sudden and brief contraction of part of or the entire body. The EEG shows synchronous spike-and-slow-wave discharges just before the onset of myoclonic movements.

questions.text: The first case of a communicable disease introduced into a population unit is called as _________
questions.solution:
A primary case is the first case of a communicable disease introduced into a population unit.

Other options:

  • An index case is the first case of the disease that comes to the notice of an investigator or physician.
  • A suspect case is a case that has all the clinical features of the disease but has not been diagnosed with it.
  • A secondary case is one that develops after contact with the primary case.

questions.text: Chemical waste is disposed in _____ bags.
questions.solution:
Chemical waste is disposed of in yellow-colored containers or non-chlorinated plastic bags.

It is later treated by:

  • Plasma pyrolysis - A technique that uses the heat generated by the plasma to dispose of the waste
  • Encapsulation - Packing and sealing the waste in containers made of impervious and non-reactive material

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis for a patient presenting with a bone tumor showing a sunburst appearance on imaging?
questions.solution:
A bone tumor with a sunburst appearance on imaging is most likely osteosarcoma.

Osteosarcoma is the most common non-hematologic primary malignancy of bone. It occurs most commonly in the second decade of life. It is typically metaphyseal. The distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus are the commonly involved sites.

In osteosarcoma, the tumor lifts the periosteum and incites an intense periosteal reaction. The periosteal reaction is irregular and it may take the form of a Codman's triangle or it may have a sunburst (sunray) appearance on X-ray.

Other options:

Option A: Osteoclastoma or Giant cell tumor is commonly seen in the age group of 20-40 years with a slight female preponderance. The distal end of the femur is the most common location followed by the proximal tibia and distal radius. 

Radiographic findings: 

  • Eccentrically located solitary lytic lesion in the epiphysis
  • Soap bubble appearance
  • Periosteal new bone formation is absent.

Option B: Osteoid Osteoma

The image shows presence of metadiaphyseal cortical osteoid osteoma involving the upper end of the femur with radiolucent nidus surrounded by cortical sclerosis.

Nidus of osteoid osteoma is present in the cortex and hence CT scan will be the best investigation to diagnose osteoid osteoma.

Image:

  • Black arrow - Nidus
  • White arrow - Cortical sclerosis

Option D: Ewing's sarcoma is a primary malignant tumor of the bone commonly involving the age group of 4-25 years involving the diaphysis of the long bones like the femur, tibia, fibula, and humerus.

X-ray shows onion-peel appearance due to deposition of periosteal reaction in layers is the typical finding.

questions.text: Increased BMR is seen in _____
questions.solution:
Increased basal metabolic rate (BMR) is seen in Cachexia.

BMR is the energy required by an awake individual during rest. It is the minimum energy required to carry out vital functions of the body such as respiration, circulation, etc. It is dependent on the individual's weight, age, and gender.

Cachexia is a metabolic syndrome related to underlying illness and characterized by muscle mass loss with or without fat loss. In this condition, there is considerably more loss of body protein although protein synthesis is not affected.

In cachexia, the continuous release of cytokines in response to infections and cancer increases the catabolism of tissue protein by the ATP-dependent ubiquitin-proteasome pathway, thereby increasing energy expenditure. This leads to a considerable increase in the BMR.

Related Pearl: Basal Metabolic Rate

BMR is increased in

BMR is decreased in

Protein energy malnutrition

Hyperthyroidism

Hypothyroidism

Cold environment

Addison disease

Cushing’s syndrome

Starvation

Cachexia

questions.text: A 10-month-old baby is brought to the pediatric OPD with clinical findings as shown in the image. Further examination shows that the child has a loss of developmental milestones, truncal hypotonia, and failure to thrive. Which of the following enzymes is defective in this child?
questions.solution:
The given image reveals a child with sparse and kinky hair. Further examination shows that the child has a loss of developmental milestones and truncal hypotonia. These features strongly suggest a diagnosis of Menkes disease, which is caused by defective lysyl oxidase enzyme.

This results from a deficiency of its co-factor i.e copper due to a defect in the ATP7A gene, which prevents the absorption of copper from the intestine.

Note :

  • ATP7A deficiency: Menkes disease - X-linked recessive
  • ATP7B deficiency: Wilson's disease - Autosomal recessive

Related Pearl: Menkes disease

Related Pearl: Synthesis of collagen and its disorders

1. Collagen backbone Preprocollagen - Glycin-proline-lysine
2. Hydroxylation

Of proline and lysine in the presence of Vit C.

Deficiency of Vit C causes Scurvy.
3. Glycosylation Formation of procollagen and resulting triple helix
4. Cleavage of terminals of procollagen Resulting in the formation of tropocollagen
5. Cross-linking by lysyl oxidase (copper-containing enzyme)

Formation of mature collagen.

Defect causes Menkes disease and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome)

questions.text: A woman who underwent dilation and curettage following a missed abortion now presents with amenorrhoea. Urine pregnancy test is negative. Hysterosalpingography shows the findings seen in the image below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history along with the moth-eaten appearance on hysterosalpingography suggests a diagnosis of Asherman syndrome.

In Asherman syndrome, oligomenorrhoea, amenorrhoea, dysmenorrhoea, abortion and infertility are seen with uterine synechiae.

The synechiae are caused by the following factors:

  • Vigorous curettage following postpartum haemorrhage or abortion
  • Tubercular endometritis
  • Uterine infections with or without intra-uterine device

Asherman syndrome:

It refers to the presence of uterine synechiae, due to the destruction of the endometrium. It can occur as a result of trauma to the endometrium following vigorous curettages for elective abortion, tuberculous endometritis, and uterine surgeries.

Depending on the degree of scarring, patients may have amenorrhea, hypomenorrhea, or recurrent pregnancy loss because of inadequate placentation.

Hysterosalpingography is performed to assess the uterine cavity and tubal patency. Intrauterine adhesions are characteristically seen as irregular angulated filling defects in the uterine cavity with a classic 'moth-eaten' appearance. 

Definitive diagnosis (gold standard) and management are done by hysteroscopy. Hysteroscopic adhesiolysis is the surgical treatment of choice.

Hormonal assays also aid in the diagnosis of anatomical causes of amenorrhea such as Asherman syndrome. All women with amenorrhea in the reproductive age group are considered pregnant unless proven otherwise by negative urinary or serum β-HCG levels. Once negative for pregnancy, further testing is done by a progesterone challenge test.

This test is done by administering medroxyprogesterone acetate as a 10-mg daily oral dose for 10 days. If the woman bleeds, then she is assumed to produce estrogen and to have a developed endometrium, and the presence of a patent outflow tract is confirmed. If she does not bleed, then she is given estrogen followed by progesterone treatment in the form of combined OCPs. If she fails to bleed after completing the 21 hormone-containing pills, then an anatomic abnormality is diagnosed such as Asherman syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following features can be seen in a patient with cervical incompetence?

choices.text: Repeated third trimester painless cervical dilatation
Bleeding per vaginum in the first trimester

questions.solution:
Cervical incompetence or insufficiency is characterized by repeated mid-trimester painless cervical dilatation. Escape of amniotic fluid followed by painless expulsion of products of conception can also be seen.

Risk factors for cervical incompetence:

  • Congenital uterine anomalies
  • Acquired -
    • Dilatation and currettage 
    • Dilatation and evacuation
    • Vaginal operative delivery through an undilated cervix
    • Amputation of cervix 
  • Multiple gestations
  • Prior preterm birth

Cervical incompetence or insufficiency is a functional or anatomical impairment in the retentive power of the cervix (or internal os). It is characterized by repeated, mid-trimester painless cervical dilatation. It leads to the escape of amniotic fluid followed by painless expulsion of the products of conception.

Cerclage is the procedure done to strengthen the cervix in patients with cervical incompetence. Contraindications of cervical cerclage include:

  • Ruptured membranes
  • Intrauterine infection
  • Uterine contractions
  • Vaginal bleeding
  • Cervical dilatation >4 cm
  • Fetal death or defect

Cervical incompetence is associated with various risk factors such as prior preterm birth, congenital uterine anomalies, iatrogenic (dilatation and curettage, induced abortion by dilatation and evacuation, vaginal operative delivery through an undilated cervix, amputation of the cervix, etc), and multiple gestations.

In the interconceptional period, diagnosis is made with the passage of number 6-8 Hegar's dilator beyond the internal os without resistance or pain. Investigations for cervical incompetence during pregnancy include:

  • Per speculum examination - shows cervical dilatation with herniation of membranes
  • Transvaginal ultrasound - funneling of internal os >1 cm and cervical length <25 mm
Prophylactic cervical cerclage is done between 12-14 weeks of gestation. Rescue or emergency cerclage is done when there is bulging or prolapse of membranes through a dilated cervix.
 
Shirodkar and McDonald's methods of cervical cerclage are the commonly performed cerclage procedures during pregnancy. In McDonald's method, a non-absorbable (mersilene) suture material is placed as a purse-string suture at the level of the internal os, whereas in the Shirodkar method, non-absorbable (mersilene) tape is used. Removal of stitch should be done at the 37th week of gestation. It can be removed earlier in case of preterm labor or if signs of abortion are seen. Laparoscopic abdominal cerclage is used for non-pregnant patients.

questions.text: In a population study, the value of the mean is 200. If the standard deviation is 20, 68% of the population will lie between?
questions.solution:
68% of the population will lie between 180- 220.

In a normal distribution curve, 68% of the values lie within the median +/- 1 standard deviation and the mean=median=mode. Since the mean = 200 and the standard deviation = 20:

68% of population will lie between Median +/- 1SD, that is, 200 +/- 20 = 180-220

95% of population lies between Median+/-2SD, 200+/- 2*20 = 160- 240

99% of population lies between Median+/-3SD, 200+/- 3*20 = 140- 260

Related Pearl: Variance, Deviation Scores and Standard Deviation

  • Deviation Scores
    • Deviation score of an element in a distribution is the difference between the mean of the distribution and the element itself, i.e., subtracting the distribution’s mean from the element.
    • It is usually denoted by the letter x
    • For example, if 29 and 15 are elements in a distribution that has a mean of 22, the deviation score of 29 would be (29 – 22) = 7 and the deviation score of 15 would be (15 – 22) = - 7.
    • The sum of all the deviation scores of elements in a distribution will be zero. 
  • Variance
    • Variance is used to measure how far a data is spread out.
    • Technically, variance of a distribution is the mean of the squares of all the deviation scores of the distribution.
    • If the variance is zero, it indicates that all the elements in the distribution are the same and that there is no variability.
    • Variance is sometimes called mean square.
    • Thus variance is calculated by the following steps:
    • Finding the deviation score of each element in the distribution.
    • Squaring each of the deviation scores.
    • Obtain the mean of all these squared deviation scores.
    • Population variance is symbolized as σ2 and is given by the formula:
    • Sample variance is denoted by symbol s2. This is the more commonly used in statistics than the population variance. In the formula for sample variance, the denominator is n-1 (and not N as it is in population variance).
  • Standard Deviation
    • By definition, the standard deviation is the square root of variance (σ2 or s2).
    • Thus, the standard deviation of a population denoted by just σ and the standard deviation of a sample is denoted by just s. Sometimes, it is also denoted by SD.
    • The formula for standard deviation of a sample (usually <30) is:
    • In population standard deviation, the denominator would be replaced by just N.
    • The standard deviation is useful, especially but not only in normal or approximately normal distributions, as the proportion of population within the given SD can be calculated.
    • A low SD would mean that the data are close to the mean but a high SD would mean that the data are more spread out.
    • The empirical rule of a normal distribution states that:
      • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviations of the mean.
      • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean.
      • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean.

questions.text: The mechanism of action of MgSo4 includes all, except:

choices.text: It reduces motor endplate sensitivity to Ach

questions.solution:
MgSO4 blocks calcium influx, not sodium.

Mechanism of action of MgSO4:

  • It is a membrane stabilizer and acts as a neuroprotector by reducing motor endplate sensitivity to Ach.
  • It blocks neuronal calcium influx.
  • It reduces the presynaptic release of the neurotransmitter glutamate.
  • It blocks glutaminergic NMDA receptors and potentiates adenosine action.

MgSO4 is used as an anticonvulsant in the management of eclampsia and as prophylaxis in severe preeclampsia. The therapeutic level of magnesium in eclampsia is 4–7 mEq/L. Measurement of serum magnesium levels is indicated to monitor magnesium toxicity if serum creatinine >1.0 mg/dL.

Signs suggestive of magnesium toxicity include:

  • Loss of deep tendon reflexes
  • Decreased respiratory rate <12/min
  • Urine output <30 mL/h
  • Chest pain and heart block 
  • Visual changes, flushing, muscle paralysis, and drowsiness

It is treated by stopping magnesium therapy and giving slow IV calcium gluconate 10 mL (10% solution) infusion. Fluid loading and forced diuresis are done and estimation of serum magnesium and creatinine levels

Repeated/maintenance dose IM injections of magnesium sulfate are continued only under the following conditions:

  • The patellar reflex is present
  • Respiration is not depressed
  • Urine output >30 mL/h

 The two commonly used MgSO4 regimens are described below: 

Regimen

Loading Dose

Maintenance Dose

Intramuscular (Pritchard)

4 g (20% solution) IV over 3–5 minutes, followed by 10 g (50%) deep IM (5 g in each buttock)

5 g (50%) IM 4 hourly in the alternate buttock

Intravenous (Zuspan or Sibai)

4 g IV slow over 15–20 minute

questions.text: A study was done to assess nutritional status among young children in rural and urban areas. 30 children in rural and 20 children in urban areas were malnourished. Which of the following tests of significance is the most appropriate in this case?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate test of significance, in this case, is the chi-square test. It is used to compare qualitative data between 2 groups with independent measures.

The Chi-square statistic is a non-parametric (distribution-free) test designed to analyze group differences when the dependent variable is measured at a nominal level.

This statistical test can be used to determine whether the antibiotic was effective or not. The outcome of this study would be either "the antibiotics cured the disease" or "the antibiotics did not cure the disease". Hence this study is having two qualitative variables. Qualitative data, also known as “categorical data,” is defined by a category and grouped by characteristics and are then given a name rather than by a measured numeric expression.

If this study were to study the effect of antibiotics in terms of the growth of bacteria in culture, such as the number of colony-forming units grown with each antibiotic, the study would have quantitative/parametric variables. Then other tests like t-test or ANOVA would be used.

Option B: Paired t-test compares paired data or pre-intervention and post-intervention data of the same group. This doesn't apply here as the groups are not paired.

Option C: The standard error of the mean is calculated for quantitative data, with a measure of central tendency as mean.

Option D: ANOVA is used to compare more than 2 groups.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: The most common site of branchial cyst is ______.

choices.text: Junction of upper and middle third of the sternomastoid muscle
Junction of middle and lower third of the sternomastoid muscle
Between the two heads of the sternomastoid muscle

questions.solution:
The most common site of a branchial cyst is at the junction of the upper and middle third of the sternomastoid muscle at its anterior border.

Branchial cyst develops from the vestigial remnants of the second branchial cleft. It is usually lined by squamous epithelium and contains thick, turbid fluid full of cholesterol crystals. It is fluctuant and may transilluminate to a lesser extent when it contains clear fluid.

A branchial fistula may be acquired or congenital. The congenital fistula is seen at the junction of the middle and lower third of the sternomastoid. An acquired fistula is usually seen in cases of incomplete surgery for the branchial cyst or spontaneous rupture, and it is seen at the same site as the cyst.

The below image shows a large right-sided branchial cyst.

questions.text: What is the most common extra-articular manifestation of rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.solution:
The most common extra-articular manifestation of rheumatoid arthritis is subcutaneous nodules.

They occur in areas subjected to repeated trauma such as the forearm or Achilles tendon. They can also occur in the lungs, pleura, pericardium, and peritoneum. 

Some major manifestations of rheumatic fever are:

  • Migratory polyarthritis of the large joints 
  • Pancarditis (myocarditis, pericarditis, or endocarditis)
  • Subcutaneous nodules (typically on extensor surfaces of extremities)
  • Erythema marginatum, an irregular circinate skin rash 
  • Sydenham chorea, a neurologic disorder with involuntary rapid movements

Other extra-articular manifestations are:

  • Sjogren's syndrome
  • Pericarditis, mitral regurgitation
  • Pleuritis, interstitial lung disease
  • Vasculitis
  • Felty's syndrome
  • Diffuse large B cell lymphoma

Related Pearl: Most commons conditions in Rheumatoid Arthritis

M/C extra-articular manifestation Subcutaneous nodules
M/C pulmonary manifestation Pleuritis
M/C cardiac involvement Pericarditis
M/C valvular lesion Mitral regurgitation
M/C hematologic abnormality Normochromic, normocytic anemia
M/C part of the spine involved Cervical spine
M/C type of lymphoma Diffuse large B cell lymphoma
M/C cause of death Cardiovascular disease

Related Pearl: Revised Jones criteria for diagnosis of Acute Rheumatic Fever (ARF)

Revised Jones criteria for the diagnosis of rheumatic fever are as follows:

Major criteria
Low-risk populations* Moderate- and high-risk populations*
   
Carditis- Clinical or subclinical Carditis- Clinical or subclinical
Arthritis- Polyarthritis only Arthritis- Polyarthritis/polyarthralgia/monoarthritis
Chorea Chorea
Erythema marginatum Erythema marginatum
Subcutaneous nodules Subcutaneous nodules
   
Minor criteria 
Polyarthralgia Monoarthralgia
Fever (≥38.5°C) Fever (≥38°C)
ESR ≥60 mm in the first hour and/or CRP ≥3.0 mg/dL ESR ≥30 mm/hr and/or CRP ≥3.0 mg/dL
Prolonged PR interval, after accounting for age variability (unless carditis is a major criterion) Prolonged PR interval, after accounting for age variability (unless carditis is a major criterion) 
   
For all patient populations with evidence of preceding Group A Streptococcal infection:(Increased ASLO/ anti-DNAse B titer or positive throat culture for group A streptococcus or positive rapid streptococcal carbohydrate antigen test) 
Diagnosis of initial ARF 2 Major criteria or 1 major plus 2 minor criteria
Diagnosis of recurrent ARF 2 Major or 1 major and 2 minor or 3 minor criteria

*Low-risk populations are those with ARF incidence ≤2 per 100 000 school-aged children or all-age rheumatic heart disease prevalence of ≤1 per 1000 population per year. If the incidence exceeds the given limit, then it is moderate-high risk populations.

questions.text: The greenish-black color of the first stool in the newborn is due to :
questions.solution:
The greenish-black color of the first stool in the newborn is due to biliverdin.

Meconium is a dark, sticky material that is normally present in the intestine at birth and passed in the feces after birth. It is detected in the ileum at about 70–85 days of fetal life and begins to fill the colon and lower ileum late in the 4th month of gestation. The greenish color of the meconium is the consequence of the bile pigments excreted by the biliary tract. The main component responsible for the greenish color of the meconium is biliverdin (a pigment formed from the oxidation of bilirubin).

Up to the 22nd week of gestation, the intestinal content is not greenish and for this reason, fetal defecation would not stain the amniotic fluid. The production of biliverdin starts over the next weeks or at a time closer to labor, probably due to a biochemical switch related to the bilirubin oxidation system.

Bilirubin is responsible for the yellow color of the stools.

Neonates do not harbor gut flora at birth.

questions.text: Voriconazole is not effective against which one of the following?
questions.solution:
Voriconazole is not effective against mucormycosis.

Mucormycosis is treated by amphotericin B. Posaconazole can also be used. However, other azoles are not effective against this fungus.

Voriconazole is the drug of choice for the treatment of aspergillosis. It can also be used for Candida species (including glabrata and krusei), Scedosporium and Fusarium.

questions.text: A patient undergoes surgery of the lateral part of the base of the skull. Postoperatively, the patient presents with aspiration but does not have a change in voice. Which of the following is the reason?
questions.solution:
The patient has an injury of the Superior Laryngeal Nerve.

In SLN supplies, only the cricothyroid muscle which is used only in high-pitch vocalization, so in SLN injury normal speech will not be affected. SLN also provides sensory supply to the mucosa above vocal cords, hence it's lesion would lead to increased susceptibility to aspiration.

The patient presents with aspiration, which rules out glossopharyngeal nerve as an option here since it doesn't provide either sensory or motor supply to the larynx and therefore it's lesion wouldn't cause aspiration.

The patient has normal vocalization which rules out RLN and high vagal injury. RLN supplies all the intrinsic muscles of the larynx except cricothyroid, therefore an RLN lesion would lead to disordered vocalization. A high vagal injury would mean both the SLN and RLN functions are affected, therefore that can also be ruled out.

Related Pearl: Nerves of Larynx

Superior laryngeal nerve

---
Mucosa above vocal folds

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy undergoes bilateral adrenalectomy for phaeochromocytoma. On the third postoperative day, the boy feels lethargic and tired. Blood pressure is 80/60 mm Hg, there is no sign of bleed. What could be the cause of this?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Addisonian crisis. It is a life-threatening condition caused due to sudden insufficiency of adrenal hormones.

Normally, adrenal corticosteroids help to retain sodium and maintain normal intravascular volume. Sudden lack of these hormones causes:

  • Excessive loss of sodium
  • Decreased intravascular volume
  • Low blood pressure
  • Circulatory collapse

Primary causes of Addisonian crisis include:

  • Adrenal haemorrhage
  • Acute infection

Secondary causes of Addisonian crisis include:

  • Surgery
  • Cessation of steroid therapy
  • Postpartum pituitary necrosis.

Treatment includes fluid and glucocorticoid replacement.

Other options:

  • SIADH is a syndrome characterized by euvolemic hyponatremia due to a primary defect in osmoregulation. The causes of SIADH include neoplasms of the lung, duodenum, pancreas, ovary, head trauma, infections (tuberculosis, meningitis, pneumonia), and drug overdose (vasopressin, desmopressin).
  • Diabetes insipidus patients present with polyuria and polydipsia.
  • Cerebral salt wasting disease - Urine osmolality will be high.

 

Differentiating features of DI,Psychogenic polydypsia, SIADH & Cerebral salt wasting disease:

Parameter Diabetes insipidus Psychogenic polydipsia SIADH Cerebral salt wasting
clinically Polyuria Polydipsia Polydipsia Well hydtrated patient Dehydrated hypotensive patient
Plasma volume ↓ Slightly ↑ ↑ ↓
Plasma Na+ ↑ ↓ ↓ ↓
Plasma Osmolality ↑ ↓ ↓ ↓
Urine Osmolality ↓ ↓ ↑ ↑↑
Urine volume ↑ ↑ ↓ Initially ↑, later ↓
Plasma ADH ↓ ↓↓ ↑ ↓
Plasma aldosterone Normal Normal ↑ ↓
 ↑ - Increased; ↓ - Decreased

questions.text: In compound myopic astigmatism, with parallel rays of light entering the eye in relaxed accommodation, the image(s) formed is/are __________.

choices.text: One focal point in front of the retina
Two focal lines in front of the retina
Two focal lines behind the retina
Two focal lines, one behind and the other in front of retina

questions.solution:
In compound myopic astigmatism, parallel rays of light enter the eye in relaxed accommodation; therefore, two focal lines are formed in front of the retina.

Option A: One focal point in front of retina: describes myopia

Option C: Two focal lines behind the retina: Describes compound hypermetropic astigmatism

Option D: Two focal lines, one behind and one in front of the retina: Describes mixed astigmatism

questions.text: The muscle marked as " B" in the image is ______ and is innervated by ______
questions.solution:
The muscle marked in the image is inferior oblique and is innervated by the oculomotor nerve.

There are seven extraocular muscles present in the eye. They are:

  • Levator palpebrae superioris - Which elevates the upper eyelids
  • Four recti muscles - Superior, inferior, medial, and lateral recti
  • Two obliques - Superior and inferior oblique

The muscles originate from the back of the orbit in a common tendinous ring called the annulus of Zinn and are inserted into the sclera.

All the extraocular muscles (including inferior oblique) are innervated by the oculomotor (III) nerve except:

  • Lateral rectus which is supplied by abducens (VI) nerve
  • Superior oblique which is supplied by trochlear (IV) nerve
